questions.text: What is evident in the buccal mucosa of a 29-year-old female patient presenting with a Globus sensation characterized by a midline protrusion in the intermaxillary region, as observed by the resident doctor during examination in the ENT ward?
questions.solution:
Option A: Torus palatinus

  • This is a case of torus palatinus.
  • Torus means elevation.
  • It has different types according to the location.
  • Torus palatinus
    • Midline elevation of exaggerated bony growth at intermaxillary suture region, specifically in the midline.
  • Torus palatinus is a painless growth of the bone located on the hard palate. The mass is usually in the middle of the hard palate and can vary in size and shape.
  • About 20 to 25% of the population has torus palatinus. It occurs most frequently in women and those of Asian descent.

Option B: Torus maxillaris

  • Exaggerated bony growth at either the inner side of the alveolar process or the outer side of the alveolar process (either side of teeth)

Option C: Torus mandibularis

  • Exaggerated bony growth → near the premolar & above the mylohyoid line.

Option D: Torus tubaris

  • Mucosal elevation in the nasopharynx at the opening of the eustachian tube.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 22-day-old baby presenting with seizures, increased head size over the past week, and a sunset sign in the eyes, what is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aqueductal stenosis

  • Aqueductal Stenosis is one of the defined causes of hydrocephalus and the most common cause of congenital (present at birth) hydrocephalus.
    • Leads to internal hydrocephalus.
    • Lateral and  third ventricle dilates.
    • The forebrain will die due to the flattening effect.
    • Treatment can be through endoscopic third ventriculostomy, shunt placement, endoscopic aqueductoplasty,­ and stent placement.

  • Congenital hydrocephalus is a collection of excess cerebrospinal fluid in the brain at birth. The extra fluid may increase pressure in the brain and can result in brain damage. It can also cause mental and physical problems. Long-term effects mostly depend on what causes the fluid collection and how the baby responds to treatment.
  • Congenital hydrocephalus can be caused by.
    • Bleeding in the fetus before birth.
    • Certain maternal infections (toxoplasmosis or syphilis)
    • Other birth defects, like spina bifida.
    • Genetic defects or structural defects.

Option A: Cranium bifidum with meningoencephalocele

  • Doesn't cause congenital hydrocephalus.

Option B: Cranium bifidum with meningohydroencephalocele

  • Doesn't cause congenital hydrocephalus.

Option D: Arnold Chiari syndrome

  • It can cause hydrocephalus but is not a common cause of congenital hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient was brought in with complaints of postural instability. Post examination, you confirm that it has nothing to do with vertigo and suspect it could be of cerebellar origin. Which of the following symptoms cannot be seen in cerebellar lesions?
questions.solution:
Option C: Resting tremors

  1. This is a case of cerebellar degeneration.
  2. The structure involved in the patient's pathology is the cerebellum.
  3. Resting tremors are not seen in cerebellar disorders.
  4. Resting tremor is the manifestation of basal ganglia disorders like parkinsonism
  5. In cerebellar lesions, intentional tremors are seen.
  6. Cerebellar degeneration is a process in which the nerve cells in the cerebellum - the area of the brain that controls balance and coordination - deteriorate and die.
  • Diseases that cause cerebellar degeneration can also damage other areas of the CNS, including the medulla oblongata, spinal cord, brain stem, and cerebral cortex.
  1. Cerebellar degeneration can be the result of inherited genetic mutations that alter the normal production of specific proteins that are necessary for the survival of neurons.  
  2. In some cases, the disease is acquired (is non-hereditary or non-genetic).
  3. The most characteristic symptom of cerebellar degeneration is a wide-based, unsteady, lurching walk, often accompanied by a back-and-forth tremor in the trunk of the body.
  4. Other symptoms may include slow, unsteady, and jerky movement of the arms or legs, slowed and slurred speech, and nystagmus -- rapid, small movements of the eyes.

Option A: Ataxia

  • Due to injury to the spinocerebellar tract [anterior lobe]
  • Uncoordinated clumsy movements
    • Not able to walk in a straight line [loss of coordination]
    • Keep falling towards the side of the lesion

Option B: Nystagmus

  • Nystagmus refers to a disorder that results in involuntary eye movements
  • It can cause damage to the cerebellum
  • It can be caused due to stroke or a tumor in the cerebellum

Option D : Past pointing

  • The patient is asked to point/touch the target direction while the eyes are closed.
  • The inability to do so refers to damage to the cerebellum

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, double vision, the eyeball was looking down and out, the pupil dilated, and drooping eyelid over the last 2 hours. MRI angiography shows an aneurysm of a cerebral artery. Which artery gives rise to the aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Option D: Posterior communicating artery

  • The most commonly damaged nerve in the berry aneurysm on the posterior communicating artery is the oculomotor nerve
  • Posterior communicating artery(branch of ICA) anastomosis with posterior cerebral artery.
  • Oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve:
    • Originate from the midbrain.
    • Sandwiched between posterior cerebral artery and superior cerebellar artery.

  • Arteries making Circle of Willis.
    • 2 Posterior cerebral arteries.
    • 2 Posterior communicating arteries (20% incidence of Berry's aneurysm).
    • 2 Internal carotid arteries.
    • 2 Anterior cerebral arteries.
    • 1 Anterior communicating artery (40% incidence of Berry's aneurysm).

Option A: Anterior choroidal artery

  • Anterior choroidal artery → supplies the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
  • Limbic system: Amygdala, hippocampus, basal ganglia (globus pallidus, substantia nigra, caudate nucleus), and fimbria of the fornix.
  • Diencephalon: The hypothalamus and lateral geniculate body of the thalamus.
  • Midbrain: Red nucleus and crus cerebri of the midbrain.
  • Visual pathway: Optic tract and optic radiation.
  • Others: Tela choroidea.

Option B: Anterior communicating artery

  • Anterior communicating artery supplies:
    • Medial & superior parts of the frontal lobe.
    • Anterior parietal lobe.
    • Optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, preoptic and supraoptic areas of the hypothalamus, par-olfactory areas of the frontal cortex, anterior columns of fornix, and cingulate gyrus.

Option C: Anterior cerebral artery

  • The anterior cerebral artery innervates the anterior limb of the internal capsule, caudate nucleus, and putamen via the medial striate artery (of Heubner).
  • The anterior cerebral artery majorly supplies the medial surface of the cerebrum.
  • It supplies most of the medial surface of the cerebral cortex (anterior three-fourths), frontal pole (via cortical branches), and anterior parts of the corpus callosum.
  • Perforating branches (including the recurrent artery of Heubner and medial lenticulostriate Arteries) supply the anterior limb of the internal capsule, the inferior portions of the head of the caudate and the anterior globus pallidus.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female was brought unconscious to the emergency room by the Police, after reportedly being shot. She was pale, and her abdomen was tight and swollen. Emergency laparotomy revealed severe damage to the portal vein causing blood loss from all its following tributaries, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Renal Vein

  • The renal vein is not a tributary of the portal vein; hence if the portal vein suffers any damage, it won't be affected.

  • The renal veins are paired vessels that carry deoxygenated blood from the Kidney to the inferior vena cava. These veins run anterior to the renal arteries.
  • There are two renal veins that arise, each from the left and right Kidney. The right renal vein receives tributaries from the Kidney only. However, the left renal vein receives tributaries from the gonads, the left inferior phrenic vein, and the left adrenal veins.
  • Both renal veins drain directly into the inferior vena cava.
  • The portal vein, on the other hand, is formed by the fusion of the splenic vein and the superior mesenteric vein behind the neck of the pancreas and drains into the inferior vena cava.
  • Tributaries of the Portal vein include the following vessels.
    • Paraumbilical veins
    • Right gastric vein
    • Splenic vein
    • Superior mesenteric vein
    • Superior pancreatico-duodenal vein
    • Left gastric vein​​​​​​​

Option B: Para umbilical vein

  • It is a tributary of the portal vein.

Option C: Right gastric vein

  • It is a tributary of the portal vein.

Option D: Cystic vein

  • It is a tributary of the portal vein.
  • It drains into the right branch of the portal vein.

questions.text: The tendon of which of the following muscles will be involved in a fracture of the posterior surface of the talus bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Achilles tendon: The Achilles tendon attaches the calf muscles (gastrocnemius and soleus) to the back of the heel bone (calcaneus). It runs over the posterior aspect of the talus bone and is closely associated with it. In a traumatic injury like jumping from a height and landing on the sole of the foot, a fracture of the posterior surface of the talus bone can potentially damage or involve the Achilles tendon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Posterior talofibular ligament: This ligament connects the talus bone to the fibula, stabilizing the ankle joint. It is not a muscle tendon, so it would not be directly involved in this type of fracture.

Option B: Flexor digitorum longus: The flexor digitorum longus muscle's tendons primarily function to flex the toes. It does not directly attach to the talus bone and is unlikely to be involved in a fracture of the posterior surface of the talus.

Option C: Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is responsible for flexing the big toe and does not attach to the talus bone. It is not involved in this type of fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles attach to the anterior surface of the greater trochanter of the femur?
questions.solution:
Gluteus minimus is most anterior in attachment & Gluteus Maximus is most posterior.

Muscle Insertion
Gluteus maximus Gluteal tuberosity (1/4), Iliotibial tract (3/4)
Gluteus Medius Greater trochanter of femur (Lateral surface)
Gluteus minimus Greater trochanter of femur (anterior surface)
Piriformis Apex of greater trochanter of femur

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of pain during defecation. On examination, a perianal swelling is noted. The further detailed workup reveals a diagnosis of an Ischiorectal abscess secondary to an infected anal fissure. During the incision and drainage of the ischiorectal abscess, which of the following nerves can be damaged?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior rectal nerve

  • The ischiorectal fossa is a space that is present in the lateral part of the anal triangle, on the sides of the anal canal.
  • The following diagram shows the location of the ischiorectal fossa:

  • The ischiorectal fossa contains fat and is poorly vascularized. These can be infected secondary to the infection in the anal canal.
  • In the inferolateral wall of the ischiorectal fossa, a canal known as the pudendal canal is present.
  • During dissection of the ischiorectal fossa, the contents present in the ischiorectal fossa can be injured. The contents of the ischiorectal fossa include:
    • internal pudendal artery (within the pudendal canal)
    • internal pudendal vein (within the pudendal canal)
    • pudendal nerve (within the pudendal canal)
    • inferior rectal artery
    • inferior rectal vein
    • inferior rectal nerve
    • posterior scrotal/labial nerve
    • perineal branch of S4
    • perforating branches of S2, S3
  • As the inferior rectal nerve is a part of the ischiorectal fossa, it can be damaged by any surgical procedure involving this area.

Option A: Iliohypogastric nerve

  • The iliohypogastric nerve arises from the L1 spinal nerve root. It does not pass through the ischiorectal fossa and is unlikely to be damaged during surgical procedures involving the ischiorectal fossa.

Option C: Superior gluteal nerve

  • The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus. It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen but does not traverse the ischiorectal fossa.

Option D: Inferior gluteal nerve

  • The inferior gluteal nerve exits through the greater sciatic foramen from the pelvis and gives muscular branches to the gluteus maximus muscle. It is not a content of ischiorectal fossa.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the hospital complaining of fever, nausea, pain, and itching in the perineal region. On examination by a urologist, he is diagnosed as having infected bulbourethral (Cowper's) glands. He also finds that the infection has affected another thing as well. Which of the following is affected by this infection apart from the bulbourethral glands?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sphincter urethrae

  • The bulbourethral glands are present in the deep perineal space of the urogenital triangle.
  • Apart from the bulbourethral glands, the deep perineal space also contains the membranous urethra, sphincter urethrae, and deep transverse perineal muscles.
  • The bulbourethral glands are located on either side of the membranous urethra, embedded in the sphincter urethrae.
  • Their ducts open into the bulbous part of the penile urethra. If the infection affects the bulbourethral glands, it would also affect the sphincter urethrae as the bulbourethral glands are embedded in the sphincter urethrae.
  • In contrast, semen is a thick, yellowish-white, viscous, spermatozoa-containing fluid, which is a mixture of secretions from seminal vesicles, testes, prostate, and bulbourethral glands.
  • The sperm or spermatozoa are produced in seminiferous tubules of the testis and matured in the head of the epididymis.
  • The seminal vesicles are lobulated glandular structures, produce the alkaline constituent of seminal fluid that contains fructose and choline, and lie inferior and lateral to ampullae of ductus deferens against the fundus (base) of the bladder.
  • So, the infection of the bulbourethral glands would only affect the sphincter urethrae apart from the bulbourethral glands.

Option A: Superficial perineal space

  • The bulbourethral gland does not lie in the superficial perineal space.
  • It lies in the deep perineal space.
  • So, an infection of the bulbourethral gland cannot affect the superficial perineal space.

Option B: Production of sperm

  • The sperm or spermatozoa are produced in seminiferous tubules of the testis and matured in the head of the epididymis.
  • So, the infection of the bulbourethral glands cannot affect the production of the sperms.

Option D: Seminal vesicles

  • The seminal vesicles are lobulated glandular structures, produce the alkaline constituent of seminal fluid that contains fructose and choline, and lie inferior and lateral to ampullae of ductus deferens against the fundus (base) of the bladder.
  • So, the infection of the bulbourethral glands cannot affect the seminal vesicles.

questions.text: Which of the following statement correctly describes the anatomical relations with respect to the rectus abdominis muscle?

choices.text: The transversalis fascia posteriorly throughout its length.
Three tendinous intersections which are visible posteriorly
The aponeuroses of the three oblique abdominal muscles anterior to it below the arcuate line
The arcuate line, the lower free border of the anterior rectus sheath

questions.solution:
Option C: The aponeurosis of the three oblique abdominal muscles anterior to it below the arcuate line

  • The rectus abdominis is a pair of long straight muscles that make up the top layer of abdominal muscles, informally known as the abs muscle.
  • Below the arcuate line, the aponeuroses of all three oblique muscles pass in front of the rectus abdominis.
  • Above the arcuate line, the external oblique aponeurosis passes anterior, the transverse oblique aponeurosis passes behind, and the internal oblique aponeurosis splits to enclose the rectus muscle.
  • The transversalis fascia lies posteriorly along most of the length of the muscle (below the costal margin). Above the costal margin, however, posteriorly lie the 5th, 6th, and 7th costal cartilages.
  • The rectus abdominis has three tendinous intersections, which are visible on the anterior surface of the muscle. They join the muscle to the rectus sheath at the umbilicus, the xiphoid, and halfway in between. These intersections are not seen posteriorly, so the rectus muscle is completely free behind at these levels.
  • The arcuate line (of Douglas) lies halfway between the umbilicus and the pubis on the posterior surface of the rectus abdominis. At the arcuate line, the inferior epigastric vessels enter the rectus sheath and run up the posterior surface of the muscle
  • The linea alba is a line joining the two halves of the rectus muscle. It is an avascular structure that can therefore be incised bloodlessly in a midline abdominal incision.

Fig: Rectus sheath

Option A: The transversalis fascia posteriorly throughout its length

  • The transversalis fascia lies posteriorly along most of the length and not throughout the length of the muscle (below the costal margin).

Option B: Three tendinous intersections which are visible posteriorly

  •  The three tendinous intersections of the rectus abdomin is are visible on the anterior surface of the muscle.

Option D: The arcuate line, the lower free border of the anterior rectus sheath

  • The arcuate line lies halfway between the umbilicus and the pubis on the posterior surface of the rectus abdomin is and not the anterior.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was undergoing surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck. The surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery during the surgery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Costo-cervical trunk

  • The subclavian arteries are among the major arteries of the head, neck and upper limbs. The left subclavian artery arises directly from the aortic arch, just distal to the origin of the left common carotid artery. The right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery arising from the brachiocephalic trunk, a branch of the aortic arch. Although the left and the right subclavian arteries arise from different origins, they follow the same course in the neck region.
  • From the site of origin of subclavian arteries, they arch superolateral in the neck towards the axilla. They pass anterior to the middle scalene muscle and posterior to the anterior scalene muscle, which divides the arteries into 3 parts based on the relation with the anterior scalene muscle.
  • Pre-scalene part: The part before the medial border of the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off:-
  1. The vertebral artery supplies the upper part of the spinal cord, brainstem and cerebellum. It joins with the vertebral artery on the other side to form the basilar artery.
  2. The internal thoracic artery supplies the anterior thoracic wall and the breast.
  3. The thyrocervical trunk: The thyrocervical trunk gives off the suprascapular, transverse cervical and inferior thyroid artery. It supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • Retro-scalene part: The part behind the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off the costocervical trunk, which divides into the superior intercostal and deep cervical arteries. It is a short artery and supplies the deep muscles of the neck. Bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck can be controlled by ligating the costocervical trunk.
  • Post-scalene part: The part after the lateral border of the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off the dorsal scapular nerve, which supplies the upper back and shoulder muscle, including the trapezius, levator scapulae and rhomboids muscle.

Option B: Transverse cervical artery

  • The transverse cervical artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. It is not ligated to control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, which are supplied by the deep cervical branch of the costocervical trunk.

Option C: Thyrocervical trunk

  • The thyrocervical trunk gives off suprascapular, transverse cervical and inferior thyroid arteries. It supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • To control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, the costocervical artery is ligated.

Option D: Inferior thyroid artery

  • The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk which supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • Ascending cervical artery is a branch of the inferior thyroid artery.
  • The deep muscles of the neck are supplied by the deep cervical artery, a branch of the costocervical artery. To control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, the costocervical artery is ligated.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby was brought to the ED with complaints of painless bleeding per rectum for quite some time. Since the hospital was 10 Kms from their hometown, they did not seek a consult before this. A plain CT of the abdomen revealed the presence of Meckel’s diverticulum, a true diverticulum, which is derived from?
questions.solution:
Option B: Omphalo-mesenteric duct

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is derived from the omphalo-mesenteric duct.
  • This child presented with bleeding from Meckel’s diverticulum.
  • Midgut diverticulum attaching to developing gut tube is called vitelline duct / vitello-intestinal duct.
  • It is also known as the omphalomesenteric tube (antimesenteric towards the anterior abdominal wall).
  • Normally, it is the content of the umbilical cord & it is obliterated.
  • If it is not obliterated, it results in an anomaly called Meckel’s diverticulum.
  • If fecal matter/meconium is at the baby's umbilicus, then it is Meckel’s anomaly.

Option A: Allantoic diverticulum

  • There is a hindgut diverticulum called allantois, which is also a content of the umbilical cord.
  • If allantois is not obliterated, it results in urachal fistula (where urine comes out of the umbilicus)

Option C: Ventral mesogastrium

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is not derived from the ventral mesogastrium.
  • Ventral mesogastrium is from the ventral mesentery in the stomach and connects the stomach with the liver.

Option D: Ductus arteriosus

  • There is no relationship between Meckel’s diverticulum and ductus arteriosus.
  • Ductus arteriosus is present between the aorta and pulmonary artery in fetal life.
  • It bypasses the pulmonary circulation in the fetus and involutes after birth.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic for consultation. The main concern is bleeding gums. The mother states several episodes of excessive bleeding previously from minor injuries. You find out that the maternal grandfather has a clotting disorder. Physical examination of the child reveals slight tenderness over the knee with fluid accumulation in the knee joint. Which of the following coagulation factors is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Factor VIII:

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)
  • The physical examination suggests bleeding into the knee joint (hemarthrosis), frequently seen in hemophilia A.
  • Hemophilia A or Classic hemophilia is caused by factor VIII deficiency.
  • About 15% of cases of hemophilia are caused by deficiency of factor IX (Christmas factor)- Hemophilia B or Christmas disease.

Option A: Prothrombin activator

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)

Option B: Factor II

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)

Option D: Factor X

  • Vitamin K is an essential factor in liver carboxylase that adds a carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues on five of the important clotting factors: prothrombin, Factor VII, Factor IX, Factor X, and protein C.
  • Occurs in healthy persons as a result of the absence of vitamin K from the diet (except in neonates before they establish their intestinal bacterial flora). However, in persons with gastrointestinal disease, vitamin K deficiency often occurs as a result of poor absorption of fats from the gastrointestinal tract because vitamin K is fat-soluble and is ordinarily absorbed into the blood along with the fats. One of the most prevalent causes of vitamin K deficiency is the failure of the liver to secrete bile into the gastrointestinal tract (which occurs either as a result of obstruction of the bile ducts or as a result of liver disease). so it will depress the clotting system
  • There is no genetic transfer from parents to off springs

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the emergency with severe chest pain for the last 2 hours. ECG is performed. What will be his heart rate according to his lead II recording?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 70:

  • The heart rate can be calculated with the R-R interval. It is calculated by dividing '60' with the R-R interval of 0.86 sec.
  • This results in a heart rate of 70 beats/min. (1500/No. of small squares between R-R interval; 300/No. of large squares between R-R interval; but R-R interval should be regular).
  • So, as there are 21 small boxes in between two R-R intervals hence 1500/21 = 71
  • Approximately 70 heartbeats/min

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D: Refers to the option A explanation

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. He denies any fever or previous respiratory complaints. After making an appropriate diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning, treatment with hyperbaric oxygen therapy is initiated. The treatment increases arterial PO2 to 2000 mm Hg. Which of the following is the amount of dissolved oxygen in arterial blood (in ml / 100 ml)?
questions.solution:
Option D: 6

  • Since the solubility of oxygen is 0.003 ml O2 / 100 ml blood, an arterial PO2 of 2000 mm Hg increases the concentration of dissolved oxygen to 6 ml O2 / 100 ml blood.
  • Note that this exceeds the normal arterial-venous difference for oxygen concentration.

The oxygen content of the blood:

  • O2 content = (O2 bound to hemoglobin) + (O2 solubilized in plasma) = (1.34 × Hb × SaO2) + (0.003 × PaO2).
  • SaO2 = percent saturation of arterial blood with O2.
  • 0.003 = solubility constant of O2;
  • PaO2 = partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood.
  • Normally 1 g Hb can bind 1.34 mL O2; the normal Hb amount in the blood is 15 g/dL.
  • O2 binding (carrying) capacity ≈ 20 mL O2 /dL of blood.
  • With Hb, there is O2 content in arterial blood, but no change in O2 saturation and Pao2
  • O2 delivery to tissues = cardiac output × O2 content of the blood.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman has a GFR of 100 ml/min, her urine flow rate is 2.0 ml/min, and her plasma glucose concentration is 200 mg/100 ml. If the kidney transport maximum for glucose is 250 mg/min, what would be her approximate rate of glucose excretion?
questions.solution:
Option A: 0 mg/min

  • All of the filtered glucose would be reabsorbed and the renal excretion rate for glucose would be zero (0 mg/min).

Learning Objective

The filtration rate of glucose in this example is:

= GFR × Plasma glucose concentration

= (100 ml/min) × (200 mg/100 ml, or 2 mg/ml)

= 200 mg/min.
  • Because the transport maximum for glucose in this example is 250 mg/min,
  • All of the filtered glucose would be reabsorbed and the renal excretion rate for glucose would be zero(0 mg/min).
  • Glucose appears in urine when the blood glucose level increases above 180 mg/dL. Glycosuria (presence of glucose in urine) may be the first indicator of diabetes mellitus.

Absorption of Glucose

  • Glucose is transported from the lumen of small intestine into the epithelial cells in the mucus membrane of small intestine, by means of sodium cotransport. Energy for this is obtained by the binding process of sodium ion and glucose molecule to carrier protein.
  • From the epithelial cell, glucose is absorbed into the portal vein by facilitated diffusion. However, sodium ion moves laterally into the intercellular space. From here, it is transported into blood by active transport, utilizing the energy liberated by breakdown of ATP.
  • Tubular maximum for glucose (TmG): In adult male, TmG is 375 mg/minute and in adult females it about 300 mg/minute.
  • The renal threshold for glucose: Renal threshold for glucose is 180 mg/dL in venous blood. When the blood level reaches 180 mg/dL glucose is not reabsorbed completely and appears in urine.

questions.text: RIA is very sensitive in vitro assay technique used to measure concentrations of substances, usually measuring antigen concentrations (for example, hormone levels in the blood) by use of antibodies. If a radioimmunoassay is properly conducted and the amount of radioactive hormone bound to the antibody is low, what would this result indicate?

choices.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high
Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are low

questions.solution:
• In a radioimmunoassay, there is too little antibody to completely bind the radioactively tagged hormone and the hormone in the fluid (plasma) to be assayed.
  • Thus, there is a competition between the labeled and endogenous hormones for binding sites on the antibody. Consequently, if the amount of radioactive hormone bound to the antibody is low, this finding would indicate that plasma levels of the endogenous hormone are high.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation with ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration sense?
questions.solution:
Option D: Brown-Séquard Syndrome

  • If the spinal cord is transected entirely, all sensations and motor functions distal to the segment transected are blocked. However, if the spinal cord is transected on only one side, Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs. 
  • It results in ipsilateral loss of all sensation at the level of lesion
  • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron signs at the level of lesion
  • Ipsilateral upper motor neuron signs below the lesion level due to corticospinal tract damage.
  • Ipsilateral loss of proprioception, vibration and 2-point discrimination touch below the level of the lesion due to dorsal column damage
  • Contralateral loss of pain, temperature, and a crude touch below the level of the lesion due to spinothalamic tract damage
  • If the lesion occurs above T1, the patient may present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome due to damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.

Option A: Herpes zoster

  • Herpes zoster is a viral infection that develops when the varicella-zoster virus reactivates.
  • Typically, it is a painful, self-limiting dermatomal rash.
  • Pain along the afflicted dermatome is usually the first symptom, followed in 2–3 days by a vesicular eruption.
  • Herpetiform, painfully clustered vesicles with an erythematous base are typical physical features.
  • Antiviral drugs like acyclovir, famciclovir and valacyclovir are started within 72 hours of the onset of symptoms.

Option B: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome

  • Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome, is a disorder that occurs following a thalamic stroke.
  • Ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes can produce lesions in the thalamus or disturbances in one of the brain circuits that communicate temperature sensations.
  • As the initial stroke symptoms (numbness and tingling) fade, a sensation imbalance causes the later syndromes that characterise Dejerine-Roussy syndrome.
  • Symptoms are burning or tingling pain and significant discomfort with temperature changes.

Option C: Lateral medullary syndrome

  • The lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, is due to a stroke in the posterior Inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It can manifest as dysphagia, hoarseness, decreased gag reflex, hiccups, vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus.
  • Decreased pain and temperature sensation from the contralateral body and ipsilateral face.
  • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome.
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria

questions.text: The relation between intravesical pressure and volume can be studied by inserting a catheter, emptying the bladder, and then recording the pressure. At the same time, the bladder is filled with 50-mL increments of water or air (cytometry). A plot of intravesical pressure against the fluid volume in the bladder is called a Cystometrogram. The first urge to void is felt at which of the following point?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phase Ib of cystometrogram

  • It is the phase of the plateau which lasts till the bladder volume is 400 mL. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL. The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.

Option A: Bladder volume of 400 mL

  • The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL.

Option B: Phase Ia of cystometrogram

  • It is the initial phase of filling in which pressure rises from 0 to 10 cm H2O when about 50 mL of fluid is collected in the bladder.

Option D: Phase II of cystometrogram

  • This phase starts beyond 400 mL volume when the pressure begins to rise markedly triggering the micturition reflex.

Learning Objective

  • Cystometry refers to the process of studying the relationship between the intravesical volume and pressure, the Cystometrogram refers to a graphical record of this relationship.
  • Normal cystometrogram shows three phases of filling:
    • Phase Ia: It is the initial phase of filling in which pressure rises from 0 to 10 cm H2O when about 50 mL of fluid is collected in the bladder.
    • Phase Ib: It is the phase of the plateau which lasts till the bladder volume is 400 mL. The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL and a marked sense of fullness at about 400mL. The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.
    • Phase II: This phase starts beyond 400 mL volume when the pressure begins to rise markedly triggering the micturition reflex.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department due to COPD exacerbation. After being given supplemental oxygen at 90% FiO2, his pO2 changed from 40 mmHg to 52 mmHg, and pCO2 changed from 60 mmHg to 68 mmHg. What is the effect of supplemental oxygen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased the pulmonary excretion of CO2
Restored arterial dissolved O2 to normal.
Reduced the hypoxic stimulation of breathing.

questions.solution:
• Supplemental O2 reduced the hypoxic stimulation of breathing.
  • pO2 was raised but not to a normal level. pCO2 was also increased suggesting alveolar ventilation (Va) was decreased.
  • Va is driven by the decreased O2 levels in this case and there will be no change in pulmonary excretion of CO2even if pCO2 levels are increased.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath for the last three months. Her chest auscultation reveals a " blowing murmur" of relatively high pitch and is heard maximally over the left ventricle. An X-ray chest shows an enlarged heart, and arterial pressure in the aorta is 140/50 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Aortic valve regurgitation

  • Based on the symptoms of shortness of breath for the last three months, blowing murmur of relatively high pitch over the left ventricle, and enlarged heart on x-ray point towards aortic valve regurgitation.
  • Blowing murmurs of relatively high pitch are usually heard in valvular insufficiency.
  • Aortic valve regurgitation has a high pulse pressure (SBP - DBP), as seen in this case (90 mmHg).
  • Due to leakage of blood back into the left ventricle during diastole, the diastolic pressure decreases to a very low value (50 mmHg).
  • The aortic valve regurgitation is shown below:

Option A: Pulmonary valve stenosis

  • Mild pulmonary stenosis is asymptomatic.
  • Severe pulmonary stenosis may experience symptoms during exercise. A  whooshing sound (murmur) could be heard with a stethoscope.

Option B: Aortic valve stenosis

  • The murmur of aortic stenosis is a high-pitched, "diamond-shaped" crescendo-decrescendo, midsystolic ejection murmur.
  • It is best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the neck and carotid arteries.

Option C: Mitral valve stenosis

  • A pan systolic murmur could be heard in mitral valve stenosis.

questions.text: Panhypopituitarism in adults may lead to all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pigmentation of the skin

  • Pigmentation is due to the effect of MSH secreted by the pituitary.
  • Panhypopituitarism in adults leads to:
    • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold
    • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
    • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones
  • In panhypopituitarism, levels of MSH decrease, thus no pigmentation of the skin.

 

 

Option A: Loss of secondary sexual characteristic

  • MSH level is low in panhypopituitarism; therefore, no skin pigmentation is seen.
  • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold.
  • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
  • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones

 

Option C: Intolerance to cold

  • MSH level is low in panhypopituitarism; therefore, no skin pigmentation is seen.
  • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold.
  • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
  • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones

 

Option D: Infertility

  • MSH level is low in panhypopituitarism; therefore, no skin pigmentation is seen.
  • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold.
  • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
  • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones

questions.text: About 50 nerve fibers innervate each taste bud; conversely, each nerve fiber receives input from an average of 5 taste buds. The umami taste was added to the 4 classic tastes relatively recently, but it has been known for almost 100 years. It is triggered by spices used extensively in Asian cooking. Which of the following stimulates the receptors for umami taste?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Glutamate

  • The primary sensations of taste include sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami (recently added).
  • Umami taste is due to activating a truncated metabotropic receptor, mGluR4, in the taste buds.
  • Glutamate in food may also activate ionotropic glutamate receptors to depolarize umami receptors.
  • The taste sensation of sweetness is caused by a long list of chemicals, including sugars (sucrose), alcohols, aldehydes, esters, sulfonic acid, halogenated acids, inorganic salts of lead and beryllium, ketones, and amino acids.
  • The taste sensation of bitterness is caused by many organic substances containing nitrogen and alkaloids. Quinine is a nitrogen-containing compound.
  • The sour taste is mainly because of hydrogen ions.
  • The salty taste is caused by sodium ions mainly. Lysyl taurine is a compound that activates receptors for salty taste.
  • Salty and sour tastes are triggered by the activation of ionotropic receptors (ligand-gated ion channel)
  • Sour, bitter, and umami tastes are triggered by activating metabotropic receptors (GPCRs).

Option B: Sucrose

  • Sucrose is a sugar.
  • Sugars are responsible for stimulating sweet taste.

 

Option C: Quinine

  • Quinine is a nitrogen-containing compound.
  • Nitrogen-containing compounds are responsible for stimulating bitter taste receptors.

Option D: Lysyltaurine

  • Lysyltaurine is a compound that stimulates receptors for salty taste.

questions.text: Which diagram represents the changes (after osmotic equilibrium) in extracellular and intracellular fluid volumes and osmolarities after the infusion of 3% NaCl?
questions.solution:
Option C: C

  • Darrow Jannet Diagrams are shown in the figure.
  • 3% NaCl is hypertonic (0.9% NaCl is isotonic).
  • Infusion (intravenous, part of Extracellular fluid volume) increases the osmolality of plasma and blood volume.
  • Increased plasma osmolality will draw water from the intracellular compartment by osmosis, leading to increased osmolality and decreased volume of the intracellular compartment.

Body water and Body Fluid compartments 

Body fluid compartment  Fraction of TBW Markers used to Measure volume  Major Cations  Major Anions

  • Total body water (TBW) is approximately 60% of total body weight, or 42 L in a 70 kg man, ECF= extracellular fluid; ICF= intracellular fluid; RISA=  radioiodinated serum albumin. 

Changes in volume and Osmolarity of Body fluids 

Type  Key Examples  ECF Volume  ICF volume  ECF Osmolarity  Hct and Serum Na+
Isosmotic volume Expansion  Isotonic NaCI infusion  ↑ No change  No change  ↓Hct -[Na+]
Isosmotic volume contraction  Diarrhea  ↓ No change  No change  ↑Hct -[Na+]
Hyperosmotic volume expansion  High NaCI intake  ↑ ↓ ↑ ↓Hct ↑[Na+]
Hyperosmotic volume contraction  Sweating Fever diabetes insipidus  ↓ ↓ ↑ -Hct ↑[Na+]
Hyperosmotic volume Expansion  SIADH ↑ ↑ ↓ -Hct ↓[Na+]
Hyperosmotic volume contraction  Adrenal insufficiency  ↓ ↑ ↓ ↑Hct ↓[Na+]

 ECF = extracellular fluid; Hct = hematocrit; ICF = intracellular fluid; SIADH = Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone. 

Option A: A                                                                                                                           

  • This is a graph for the infusion of isotonic normal saline.
  • Because intracellular volume is unchanged while extracellular volume increases by isotonic saline infusion.
  • The Plasma osmolality remains the same as normal saline is isotonic.

Option B: B

  • This is a graph for SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone).
  • Excess anti-diuretic hormone cause free water retention, which causes an increase in both extracellular and intracellular volume.
  • An increase in both extracellular and intracellular volume decreases plasma osmolarity.

Option D: D

  • This graph depicts intracellular and extracellular volume depletion.
  • Causes are sweating fever and diabetes insipidus.
  • Volume depletion causes increased plasma osmolarity.

questions.text: Which transporter is responsible for the absorption of fructose?
questions.solution:
Option D: GLUT-5

  • As the patient’s liver enzymes are normal and her symptoms seem to correlate with her intake of fruit juices, most likely her problem is an inability to absorb fructose.
  • Lactase deficiency can be ruled out since the removal of cow’s milk from her diet did not eliminate the problem.
  • The primary transporter of fructose in the intestine is GLUT-5 and a deficiency in GLUT-5 would cause inability to absorb fructose in the gut. The fructose accumulated in the intestine will be fermented upon by bacteria to produce various gases, including hydrogen, as well as organic acids.
  • The most common carbohydrate sources for infant formula include lactose, sucrose & corn syrup. Fructose is present in sucrose and corn syrup also.

Option A: GLUT-2

  • GLUT-2 is involved passive absorption of glucose in Liver, pancreas and intestine. And its deficiency causes Fanconi Bickel Syndrome (Glycogen storage disease type XI)
  • Clinical features of this disease are
    • Hepatorenal glycogen accumulation
    • Growth retardation
    • Polyuria and polydipsia
    • Fasting hypoglycemia but post prandial hyperglycemia resembling diabetes

Option B and C: SGLT-1 and SGLT-2

  • SGLT-1 and SGLT-2 are secondary active transporters of glucose and galactose in intestine and kidneys, hence will not affect fructose absorption.
  • Deficiency of SGLT-1 and SGLT-2 causes glucose–galactose malabsorption and familial renal glycosuria respectively.

questions.text: Under which of the following conditions is the net ATP production from glycolysis zero in RBCs?

choices.text: Both A and B are correct options
Both A and B are false options

questions.solution:
Option C: Both A and B are correct options

Rapaport Luebbering shunt:

  • Occurs only in RBCs.
  • It does nothave a Phosphoglycerate Kinase (substrate level phosphorylation) step, so there will be a loss of 2 ATPs
  • So, total ATPs produced in Rapaport Luebbering shunt from Substrate level phosphorylation = 2.
  • But ATP used in the preparatory phase of glycolysis = 2
  • So, net ATP = (2-2) = 0

Arsenate poisoning:

  • Arsenate inhibits Glyceraldehyde-3-P dehydrogenase enzyme.
  • But glycolysis continues even in the presence of arsenite.
  • So, again total ATPs produced in Rapaport Luebbering shunt from substrate level phosphorylation = 2.
  • But ATP used in the preparatory phase of glycolysis = 2
  • So, net ATP = (2-2) = 0

Option A, B and D: Refer to explanation of option C

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with type I (DM) diabetes went to an ophthalmologist for assessment of developing a cataract. The results of his blood work are shown below:


	
		
			Fasting blood glucose
			180 gm/dl
		
	
	
		
			Hemoglobin A
			15 mg/dl
		
		
			Hemoglobin A1c
			10% of total Hb
		
		
			Urine ketones
			Positive
		
		
			Urine glucose
			Positive
		
	


Which of the following enzymes is most strongly associated with cataract formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aldose reductase

  • The blood examination with high fasting glucose (>126 mg/dl) and HBA1c >6.5% along with urine ketone bodies and urine glucose indicate diabetic condition.
  • In diabetic patients, excess blood glucose enters insulin-insensitive tissues and forms sorbitol by aldose reductase. But sorbitol dehydrogenase is absent in most of these cells, and sorbitol cannot be converted to fructose. Hence, sorbitol accumulation occurs.
  • Sorbitol is hygroscopic and will absorb water, causing cell swelling, ultimately leading to snowflake cataracts in diabetic patients.

Option A: Glucokinase

  • Glucokinase is an enzyme of glycolysis, and defects in these enzymes generally manifest as hemolysis and anemia.
  • Here, normal hemoglobin indicates no glucokinase deficiency.

Option C: Aldolase B

  • Aldolase B is involved in fructose metabolism
  • Its deficiency causes fructose intolerance with symptoms such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, and hypoglycemia but no cataract.

Option D: Galactokinase

  • Galactokinase is an enzyme of galactose metabolism.
  • Its deficiency causes galactosemia.
  • In galactosemia, this same enzyme converts excess galactose to galactitol accumulation which in the eye causes oil drop cataracts.

questions.text: A patient presents with yellowish eyes and skin. He also has itching, pain in the upper right side of the abdomen, and weight loss. Laboratory analysis of urine bilirubin indicates obstructive jaundice. The test of which of the following enzyme will substantiate these findings?
questions.solution:
Option A: ALP

  • ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) catalyzes the removal of phosphate group from organic phosphate esters at alkaline pH.
  • There are 4 isoenzymes for the ALP enzyme:
    • ALP-I → Intestinal
    • ALP-L → Tissue non-specific, present mainly in the liver, bone, and kidneys
    • ALP-P → Placental Iso enzyme present, also called Regan isoenzyme, increased during pregnancy.
    • GC type (Germ cell type) → Present in Germ cell
  • Very high levels of the enzyme alkaline phosphatase are seen in obstructive jaundice and are considered one of the best enzyme biomarkers for biliary obstruction.
  • ALP is mainly produced in hepatocytes of the liver and osteoblasts of bones.
  • It is present in the canalicular membranes of hepatocytes. When the release of bile is obstructed, causing obstructive jaundice, it increases the translation of ALP mRNA. This causes an increase in ALP, which moves to sinusoids. This can be seen as a high level of ALP in laboratory testing.
  • Increased ALP levels are seen in:
    • The liver diseases mainly biliary obstruction, hepatitis, and cirrhosis.
    • Bone → Paget’s disease, osteoporosis, osteoblastic bone tumor, osteomalacia
    • Hyperthyroidism
  • Decreased ALP is seen in:
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Women taking OCPs and estrogen therapy.

Option B: AST

  • AST is remarkably increased in hepatitis and liver cirrhosis.

Option C: ALT

  • ALT is remarkably increased in Budd-Chiari syndrome and autoimmune diseases of the liver.

Option D: Aminotransferase

  • Aminotransferases increase remarkably as compared to ALP in diseases of hepatocellular origin such as hepatitis, autoimmune diseases of the liver, alcohol-related diseases of the liver, and liver cirrhosis.

questions.text: A newborn is tested for phenylketonuria (PKU) using a blood sample taken from the umbilical cord. Based on the blood report, the newborn is declared negative for PKU, and the pediatrician imposes no dietary restrictions. The child is again brought to the pediatrician after 12 months. This time, the child is reported to have aggressive behavior and delayed milestones. Blood and urine tests for PKU are redone, and they are positive this time. Finally, a diagnosis of PKU is made. What is the most probable reason for misdiagnosis at birth in this case?

choices.text: Cord blood is not a good source of fetal blood
The Guthrie test used in diagnosis has low sensitivity
Maternal blood should have been used
The test was performed too early to be positive

questions.solution:
Option D: The test was performed too early to be positive

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by an inborn error in phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme or the co-factor, tetrahydrobiopterin or dihydropyridine reductase.
  • It results in elevated phenylalanine levels and metabolites in the blood and urine.
  • In newborns, maternal enzymes clear phenylalanine and its metabolites for the first 24-48 hours.
  • Thus, any screening test performed during this period may give false negative results.
  • In these circumstances, the neonatal screening test is performed after 24-48 hours when the infant has started taking a protein diet.
  • Furthermore, mass spectrometry is a relatively more credible way to diagnose PKU than the Guthrie test.

Option A: Cord blood is not a good source of fetal blood

  • Cord blood may contain more or less the same constituents as maternal blood. Nevertheless, the main reason for a false negative result is the wrong timing for drawing blood and not the wrong site.
  • Safe practice is to draw blood from the infant's heel on the 3rd day after birth.

Option B: Guthrie test used in diagnosis has low sensitivity

  • For the Guthrie test, a sample from the infant’s heel is taken after three days of birth and then used for diagnosis. So, it can not be false negative due to low levels of phenylalanine.

Option C: Maternal blood should have been used

  • Maternal blood is usually not used to diagnose PKU as she has normally functioning enzymes and normal levels of phenylalanine.
  • However, maternal blood can diagnose 'maternal PKU Syndrome.'
  • If women with PKU who are not on a low-phenylalanine diet become pregnant, the offspring are affected with "maternal PKU syndrome."
  • As phenylalanine is a teratogen, higher levels of phenylalanine in the mother cause microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart anomalies in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in the lipid profile will most probably confirm the diagnosis of  Tangier's disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low or absence of HDL

Tangier's disease/ Familial alpha-lipoprotein deficiency/Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia.

  • It's a disease that causes a severe reduction in HDL.
  • 9q31 chromosome mutation leads to defects in ABC-A1 receptors, which helps in giving cholesterol from peripheral tissue to HDL.
  • HDL is not properly formed → HDL ↓
  • Higher the risk of coronary artery disease.
  • Other lipoproteins are normal.
  • ↓ Apo A1.
  • Cholesterol accumulates in the reticuloendothelial system.
  • Clinical features:
    • Peripheral neuropathy
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils

Option B: Low LDL concentration

  • Tangier's disease/hypo alpha lipoproteinemia inherited disorder which is characterized by low the low density of HDL.
  • Low LDL concentration is not used for the diagnosis of Tangier's disease.
  • LDL remains normal in hypo alpha lipoproteinemia.

Option C: Raised chylomicrons

  • Chylomicronemia is a genetic disorder of the LPL enzyme.
  • Chylomicrons are raised due to the deficiency of the LPL enzyme.
  • Chylomicronemia is not useful for the diagnosis of Tangier's disease.

Option D: Deficiency of LPL

  • Chylomicronemia is a genetic disorder of the LPL enzyme.
  • Chylomicrons were raised due to the deficiency of the LPL enzyme.
  • Deficiency of LPL or raised chylomicronemia is not useful for diagnosing Tangier's disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to a pediatrician with complaints of muscle pain and weakness.  Further investigations revealed hepatomegaly and cardiomegaly. Liver biopsy analysis showed nonspecific fatty changes and a muscle biopsy revealed large amounts of cytoplasmic vacuoles containing neutral lipids. Additionally, during a one-day fast, the child experienced hypoglycemia with a normal blood pH and the absence of ketone bodies. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Option C: Systemic carnitine deficiency

  • The patient feels muscle weakness in the playground; actually, it’s the release of epinephrine that activates the hormone-sensitive lipase and breakdown of triglycerides. Free fatty acid from triglyceride breakdown enters the liver and muscles mitochondria in the absence of carnitine shuttle leading to accumulation and pain eventually.
  • Skeletal muscles (slow-twitch fibers) use free fatty acids at rest.
  • As carnitine is required for the oxidation of long chain fatty acids, Carnitine deficiency leads to defective fatty acid oxidation and hypoglycemia (no activation of gluconeogenic enzymes by acetyl-CoA) and no ketone bodies (no acetyl-CoA from fatty acid oxidation).

Option A: Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency

  • This option is incorrect.
  • Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency causes the breakdown of red blood cells.
  • It’s an inherited metabolic disease that includes types Ia and IIb.
  • It causes fasting intolerance, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of fat and glycogen in the liver.

Option B: 3-hydroxy 3-methylglutaryl-CoA reductase deficiency

  • This is an incorrect option.
  • Mitochondrial 3-hydroxy 3-methylglutaryl-CoA synthase deficiency is a by-birth mitochondrial defect that affects ketone bodies synthesis.
  • It can cause vomiting, hepatomegaly, and lethargy.

Option D: Bilirubin diglucuronide transporter deficiency

  • This option is incorrect.
  • Bilirubin diglucuronide transporter is a conjugated form of bilirubin that is formed by bilirubin metabolism.
  • It is secreted in the bile.
  • It is water soluble.
  • Conjugated bilirubin deficiency can cause white matter lesions, which can lead to dementia and heart disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is being evaluated for developmental delay and poor muscle control. The parents are concerned since the child has started to bite his lips and fingers. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of serum uric acid. Which of the following specific reactions is not catalyzed in the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Guanine + 5′PRPP → GMP + PPi

  • The child exhibits the symptoms of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome, which are
    • Mental retardation
    • Self-mutilation
    • Impaired function of kidneys
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase enzyme.
  • The pattern of inheritance: X linked recessive
  • HGPRT converts the free bases hypoxanthine, or guanine, plus PRPP (5′-phosphoribosyl 1′-pyrophosphate) to the nucleotides IMP, or GMP, plus pyrophosphate (see fig).

Option A: Thymine + deoxyribose 1-phosphate → deoxythymidine + PPi

  • Conversion of Thymine into deoxythymidine is a step in the synthesis of nucleoside formation for DNA synthesis.

Option B: Adenine + 5′-PRPP → AMP + PPi

  • Adenine can be converted to AMP by enzyme adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRTase).
  • It is also an enzyme of purine salvage pathway.
  • When APRTase has reduced or nonexistent activity, adenine accumulates.

Option C: Uracil + ribose 1-phosphate → uridine +phosphate

  • Conversion of uracil into uridine is a step in the synthesis of nucleoside for RNA synthesis.

questions.text: A 25 year old female patient is brought to the emergency department with symptoms suggestive of a panic attack. Which of the following arterial blood pHs would be most consistent with her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: 7.55

  • The patient is having a panic attack (due to driving in tunnels) and is hyperventilating, causing an acute respiratory alkalosis. It is the most common acid-base abnormality.
  • The loss of CO2 pushes the carbonic anhydrase reaction toward CO2 production, which reduces the proton concentration (thereby raising the pH).

  • The patient would lose consciousness with a more severe attack.
  • Respiratory alkalosis is usually mild as compared to metabolic alkalosis. For this reason, tFor this reason, the pH increase is smaller (7.55 is more likely than a pH of 8.10, which could occur via a metabolic alkalosis).
  • Acute respiratory alkalosis is treated by finding the underlying cause, initially by monitoring and maintaining blood gases, some patients may require anxiolytics, and other causes like embolism may require anticoagulation.
  • It is important to counsel the patient for future prevention by breathing techniques and relaxation methods like meditation.

Option A: 8.10 - refer to explanation of B

Option C, D and E:  7.15, 6.40 and 6.10

  • All these pH are lower than physiologic pH (7.4), and would be considered acidosis, instead of alkalosis.

questions.text: RFLP analysis using site flanking the ApoB100 gene on chromosome 2 among members of a family with a history of Hypercholesterolemia yielded one large fragment and one smaller fragment that is also seen in controls. What is the probable inheritance mechanism in this family?
questions.solution:
Option B: Autosomal dominant

  • Restriction fragment length polymorphism(RFLP) is used in determining disease-related specific genes on a chromosome. RFLP probe is frequently used in the diagnosis of hereditary diseases.

The findings in RFLP in this question are features of the autosomal dominant disease:

  • The large fragment could either have been derived from a mutation removing one flanking restriction site or from extra DNA inserted between the restriction sites. The fact that there are two DNA fragment sizes in the affected individual but one in controls suggests alteration of only one of the two homologous apolipoprotein B 100 genes on chromosome 2.
  • Only in an autosomal or sex-linked dominant inheritance is the disease produced when even one of the alleles of a gene is mutated. As the gene apolipoprotein B 100 mentioned here is present on an autosomal chromosome so this is a case of autosomal dominant mutation.

Option A: X-linked recessive

  • In X-linked recessive inheritance, disease phenotype is produced when both the alleles are mutated in a female and in male even when only one of the alleles is mutated.

Option C: Autosomal recessive

  • In autosomal recessive inheritance, disease phenotype is produced only when both the alleles are mutated in both male and females. Individual with a single mutant allele is considered as a carrier for the disease.

Option D: Multifactorial

  • Multifactorial inheritance means that "many factors" (multifactorial) are involved in causing a phenotypic defect. The factors are usually both genetic and environmental, where a combination of genes from both parents, in addition to unknown environmental factors, produce the trait or condition.

questions.text: A sixty-nine-year-old male presented to your clinic with complaints of tremors, stiffness of his limbs and a change in his gait. He also complains of having difficulty initiating movements. He says these symptoms have been slowly progressing and have made it difficult for him to perform his daily activities. Investigations are performed, and a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease is made. During increased cellular stress, the energy-depleted cell eats its cellular components to compensate for nutrient depletion. Which of the following is a good marker to look for in cells to detect this process?
questions.solution:
Option C: LC3

  • Autophagy ("self-eating") is the process in which the starved cell eats its components to reduce nutrient demand to match the supply.
  • Some cell debris within the autophagic vacuoles may resist digestion and persist in the cytoplasm as membrane-bound residual bodies. An example of residual bodies is lipofuscin granules, as shown in the below image.

  • Pathological accumulation of lipofuscin is seen in Parkinson’s disease.
  • The most important gene that we associate with autophagy is ATG-3.
  • Autophagy is a process that is also stimulated by a protein called BECLIN-1.
  • The most important gene responsible for inhibiting apoptosis is BCL-2.
  • BCL-2 interacts with BECLIN-1 and forms a complex responsible for inhibiting autophagy.
  • Inhibition of autophagy increases the risk of malignancy.
  • The marker for autophagy is a microtubular protein called LC-3 (Microtubule-associated protein light chain 3). LC-3 plays an important role in the closure of the autophagosomal membrane and also in the elongation step.

Option A: BAK

  • BAK, BAX, and BID are involved with cellular apoptosis.
  • These are proapoptotic genes.

Option B: BAX

  • BAK, BAX, and BID are involved with cellular apoptosis.
  • These are proapoptotic genes.

Option D: BID

  • BAK, BAX, and BID are involved with cellular apoptosis.
  • These are proapoptotic genes.

questions.text: An 83-year-old thin-built male is presented to the emergency department by her son. She is unconscious. Upon examination, Pulse was feeble, BP unrecordable, and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was 3/15. ECG showed a Flatline in all leads. An autopsy was done. Histopathologic examination of cardiac tissue revealed peri-nuclear brown pigment. This finding occurs due to which reason?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lipofuscin

  • Lipofuscin is an insoluble pigment known as Lipochrome or Wear and tear pigment. Derived from the Latin word meaning brown lipid.

  • It's a sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.

  • The sectioned tissue appears yellow-brown, finely granular cytoplasmic, often perinuclear pigment.

  • It is seen in ageing cells and is particularly prominent in the liver and heart of ageing patients.

  • Also seen in patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

Brown atrophy of the heart

Option A: Melanin

  • A pigmented polymer is produced by melanocytes, stored in organelles called melanosomes, and then transferred to keratinocytes. Protects against ultraviolet radiation and determines the colour of the skin and iris.

  • Melanin is an endogenous brown-black pigment that absorbs and protects against potentially harmful ultraviolet radiation in sunlight.

Option B: Hemosiderin

  • Hemosiderin, a haemoglobin-derived golden yellow to brown granular, is a storage form of iron.

  • It is a partially digested ferritin and lysosomes

Option C: Bilirubin

  • A haemoglobin breakdown product and parameter of cholestasis. Serum total bilirubin consists of unconjugated bilirubin and conjugated bilirubin.

  • After iron removal from haemoglobin, the heme moiety is converted to biliverdin (green bile) and then to bilirubin (red bile).

questions.text: You’re an intern in dermatology OPD. The dermatology resident on OPD firmly strokes the skin of a patient, which initially produces a red line followed by a flare around that line and then finally a wheel. The following response is caused due to?
questions.solution:
Option A: Histamine

  • The given clinical sign is Lewis’s triple response.
  • Lewis's triple response is caused due to histamine
  • The triple response of Lewis is a cutaneous response that occurs from the firm stroking of the skin. This produces firstly a red line, followed by a flare around that initial line, and then finally, wheal develops.

  • When histamine is injected intradermally, it causes a triple response
    • Red spot: Because of capillary dilatation.
    • Wheal: Due to the exudation of fluid from capillaries and venules.
    • Flare: Redness in the surrounding area is due to arteriolar dilation mediated by axon reflex

A ‘Triple response’ is elicited by firm stroking of the skin of the forearm with a pencil.

B   Diagrammatic view of microscopic features of triple response of the skin

Option B: Axon reflex

  • The axon reflex (or the flare response) is the response stimulated by peripheral nerves of the body that travels away from the nerve cell body and branches to stimulate target organs

Option C: Injury to endothelium

  • Endothelial dysfunction is characterized by a shift in the actions of the endothelium toward reduced vasodilation, a proinflammatory state, and prothrombic properties.
  • The endothelium is directly involved in peripheral vascular disease, stroke, heart disease, diabetes, insulin resistance, chronic kidney failure, tumour growth, metastasis, venous thrombosis, and severe viral infectious diseases. Dysfunction of the vascular endothelium is thus a hallmark of human diseases.

Option D: Increased permeability

  • Increased permeability of post-capillary venules into the interstitial space cause leakage of fluid. 
  • This leads to oedema and swelling

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with a history of recurrent bacterial infections presents with a fever and a productive cough. Biochemical analysis of his neutrophils shows the problem in an oxidative burst. This patient most likely has inherited a mutation in the gene that encodes which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Option D: NADPH oxidase

  • Defect in the NADPH oxidase contributes to the chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease:

  • Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is characterised by poor oxygen-dependent killing.
  • Due to NADPH oxidase defect (X-linked or autosomal recessive)
  • This leads to recurrent infection and granuloma formation with catalase-positive organisms, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas cepacia, Serratia marcescens, Nocardia, and Aspergillus
  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test is used to screen for CGD.
  • Leukocytes are incubated with NBT dye, which turns blue if NADPH oxidase can convert oxygen to its free radical form but remains colourless if NADPH oxidase is defective.
  • The most common variants are an X-linked defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) and autosomal recessive defects in the genes encoding two cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox).
  • The name of this disease comes from the macrophage-rich chronic inflammatory reaction that tries to control the infection when the initial neutrophil defence is inadequate.
  • This often leads to collections of activated macrophages that wall off the microbes, forming granulomas.

Option A: Catalase

  • Acatalasemia is a genetically heterogeneous disease characterised by an inherited absence of the enzyme catalase.
  • Affected infants cannot degrade endogenous or exogenous hydrogen peroxide, which accumulates, resulting in oxidation deprivation.
  • Oxidative burst is intact

Option B: Cytochrome P450

  • Cytochrome P450 is involved in detoxifying toxins and drugs in the microsomal, mainly in the liver.
  • It has not linked with the oxidative burst mechanism.

Option C: Myeloperoxidase

  • MPO deficiency results in defective conversion of H202 to HOCl
  • Increased risk for Candida infections; however, most patients are asymptomatic.
  • NBT is normal; respiratory burst (02 to H202) is intact.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with swelling of his left parotid gland and pain, especially during chewing. He had experienced ten such episodes lasting 10–15 days each in the previous 2 years. Physical examination revealed a swollen left parotid gland with local tenderness and erythema of the overlying skin. The immunological evaluation revealed an IgA level of less than 7 mg/dl. The remaining immunoglobulin IgE, IgM, and IgG were within normal limits. Which of the following is the most important risk about the given condition?

choices.text: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease
Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea
Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

questions.solution:
Option D: Anaphylactic reaction on blood transfusion

  • The given clinical features and laboratory investigations point towards Isolated IgA deficiency.
  • The normal range for IgA is 36–268 mg/dl.
  • Common immunodeficiency is caused by impaired differentiation of naïve B lymphocytes to IgA-producing plasma cells.
  • Affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA.
  • Most individuals with IgA deficiency disease are asymptomatic. Because IgA is the major antibody in external secretions, mucosal defences are weakened, and infections occur in the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts.
  • The symptomatic patient commonly presents with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea.
  • When IgA-deficient patients are transfused with blood containing normal IgA, some of these patients develop severe, even fatal, anaphylactic reactions because the IgA behaves like a foreign antigen (since the patients do not produce it and are not tolerant to it).

Option A: It is the second most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease

  • IgA deficiency is the most common immunoglobulin deficiency disease.

Option B: Decreased risk of sinopulmonary infections and diarrhoea

  • IgA deficiency increases the risk of sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections.

Option C: Reduced risk of SLE and rheumatoid arthritis

  • IgA-deficient patients have a high frequency of respiratory tract allergy and a variety of autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presented to an outpatient clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing. He has a history of IV drug abuse. An examination of his oral cavity revealed that most of his tongue and palate are covered in yellowish membranes. Several white, ulcerated lesions in the oesophagus are also discovered during endoscopy. The primary cause of these pathologic findings in this patient is the loss of which of the following immune cells?
questions.solution:
Option B: Helper T lymphocytes 

  • The patient has AIDS, which is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).
  • HIV affects many body organs, but the primary target is the immune cells (helper T cells).
  • HIV enters the body via the mucous membrane. 
  • It is detected first by dendritic cells, macrophages, and T cells. 
  • The virus stays latent in lymphoid tissues and can get activated later on. 
  • HIV infects cells by using CD4 receptors. 
  • Receptors on CD4 cells are CXCR4 and CCR5. 
  • The HIV protein that binds to receptors is gp120. 
  • Different strains of HIV use different receptors 
    • R5 strains
      • Infect macrophage/monocyte lineage 
      • Attaches to CCR5 receptors 
      • Also known as M-tropic
    • X4 strains 
      • Infect T - cells 
      • Attaches to CXCR4 receptors
      • Also known as T - tropic (Thymic T -cell precursors)
      • Dominant virus in most the cases 
      • Causes depletion of T -cells. 

 

Option A: B lymphocytes

  • B - Lymphocytes are not primarily affected by HIV 
  • It produces plasma cells that produce antibodies.

Option C: Killer T lymphocytes

  • Natural killer T lymphocytes are part of innate immunity. 
  • They Protect against many viruses and intracellular bacteria. 

Option D: Monocytes/macrophages

  • They are phagocytes and can rapidly act in case of infection or inflammation. 
  • Monocytes, when entering into tissues, converted into macrophages.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents in an anxious state to the Pediatric department complaining that her 2-year-old male child has intellectual disabilities, kinky and tangled hair, pudgy rosy cheeks with sagging facial skin since birth. She is hesitant about her children having kinky hair disease because her two sisters who had sons died from kinky hair disease. Her mother's elder brother also died of the same disorder. Which of the following could be the possible mode of inheritance in her family?
questions.solution:
Option A: X-linked recessive

  • Based on the symptoms of intellectual disability, kinky or tangled hair, pudgy rosy cheeks with sagging facial skin since birth, along with a family of kinky hair disease, the patient is most probably suffering from Menkes syndrome.
  • In any situation when the previous generation of the affected individual is not affected, the condition is recessive.
  • It occurs due to mutations in genes encoding for copper-transporting protein ATP7A, leading to copper deficiency.
  • In X-linked recessive disease, the female won't have the disease, but she will transmit it to her son.
  • If there is selective male-to-female transmission, it is most likely an X-linked condition.
  • Male-to-male transmission is seen in the autosomal condition.
  • Kinky hair disease /Menkes syndrome is:
    • X- Linked Recessive disorder.
    • Mutations are genes encoding for copper-transporting protein ATP7A, leading to copper deficiency.
    • Characteristic findings include:
      • Pudgy, rosy cheeks, sagging facial skin
      • Feeding difficulties and irritability
      • Lack of muscle tone and floppiness
      • Hypothermia
      • Brittle, kinky, or tangled hair
      • Intellectual disability and developmental delay
      • Seizures
    • Manifested only in males.
    • Females are not affected, so they must be carriers.

Option B: Autosomal dominant

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance is how a genetic trait or disorder can be passed down from parent to child.
  • One copy of a mutated gene from one of the parents can cause the genetic condition.
  • An example is a Familial hypercholesterolemia.

Option C: Autosomal recessive

  • Autosomal recessive inheritance is a genetic condition.
  • It occurs when the child receives one mutated gene copy from each parent.
  • The parents usually do not have autosomal recessive inheritance, a genetic condition when the child receives one mutated gene copy from each parent.
  • An example is G6pD.

Option D: X linked dominant

  • The X-linked dominant pattern is rare. 
  • Both male and female children of an affected female can have the trait.
  • An example is a resistant rickets.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old black girl is brought to the emergency department complaining of severe painful swelling in her hands and feet from the last week and pallor of the conjunctiva, fatigue, and weakness from the last two weeks. Some family members had a history of the same symptoms. Physical examination shows yellowing of eyes, skin, conjunctiva pallor, and swelling in hands and feet. A Complete blood count reveals normocytic anaemia with marked poikilocytosis. A peripheral blood film is shown in the image.



Which of the following is most likely finding on haemoglobin electrophoresis?

choices.text: Increase HbA2, HbS, and HbF and Decrease HbA

questions.solution:
Option B: Increase HbA2, HbS, and HbF and Decrease HbA

  • This is a case of sickle cell disease (SCD) that presents with severe painful swelling in hands/feet, conjunctiva pallor, fatigue, weakness and yellowing of eyes and skin.

  • Sickle cell disease occurs due to single amino acid replacement in the beta chain, leading to extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.

  • HbS polymerizes when deoxygenated (hypoxemia, dehydration, acidosis); polymers aggregate into needle-like structures, resulting in sickle cells.

  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis:

    • Increase: HbA2, HbS, HbF

    • Decrease: HbA

  • Blood smear:

    • Blood smears reveal sickle cells and target cells.

Option A: Increased HbA and HbA2

  • SCD is associated with a decrease in HbA, not an increase in HbA.

  • HbA2 level is increased in sickle cell disease.

  • HbA2 is made of 2 alpha and 2 delta chains and is present in small amounts in a normal adult.

Option C: Increase HbA and decrease HbF

  • SCD is associated with an increase in HBF and a decrease in HbA.

  • HbF is the main haemoglobin in the fetus.

  • HbA replaces HbF in the first six months of infancy.

Option D: Increase HbC and HbS

  • SCD is not associated with an increase in HBC

  • HbC levels are increased in HbC disease and HbSC disease.

  • Blood smear in HBC reveals Hb crystals inside red blood cells and target cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman reports fatigue and hematuria. Physical examination reveals significant pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, and numerous upper and lower extremities ecchymoses. A complete blood count (CBC) reveals normocytic normochromic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, and a significant leukocytosis composed primarily of myeloblasts. Which of the following is the most directly related to the major clinical problems associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC).

Explanation:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is associated with various clinical problems, but the most directly related major clinical problem is Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC). DIC is a complication seen in AML due to the release of procoagulant substances from leukemic cells. This leads to widespread and uncontrolled activation of the coagulation cascade, resulting in the formation of blood clots in small blood vessels throughout the body.

As a result of DIC, the following clinical problems can occur in AML:
