  • Bleeding: DIC can lead to both bleeding (due to consumption of clotting factors and platelets) and clotting (microthrombi formation). This can manifest as petechiae, ecchymoses, and mucosal bleeding.

  • Organ Dysfunction: The microthrombi formation and consumption of clotting factors can lead to organ dysfunction, affecting organs like the liver, kidneys, and lungs.

  • Hematopoietic Suppression: While AML is characterized by increased myeloblasts in the bone marrow, DIC can further suppress normal hematopoiesis (production of blood cells).

Avascular necrosis of bone, hypersplenism, and increased hematopoiesis are not the primary clinical problems associated with AML but can be related to other hematologic conditions or complications. In AML, the primary issue is the overproduction of abnormal myeloblasts and the associated DIC and its consequences.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to medical OPD with a pruritic rash that had been bothering him for several years. The rash was first scaly, erythematous, eczematoid patches distributed asymmetrically over his chest and abdomen. It later changed to hard and raised plaques. The plaque biopsy was done, which revealed atypical CD4+T cells with cerebriform nuclei. Which of the following statements about this disease is correct?

choices.text: The disease eventually disseminates to lymph nodes and internal organs
The neoplastic cells most commonly display cell markers of CD19 and CD20
The skin rash most commonly disappears over time
This disease is caused by chronic fungal infection in the skin

questions.solution:
Option A: The disease eventually disseminates to lymph nodes and internal organs

  • Mycosis fungiodes presented as a pruritic skin rash on non-sun exposed areas and later progressed to hard and raised erythematous plagues, histologically composed of atypical CD4+T cells with cerebriform nuclei; it is a malignant condition and will likely spread to lymph nodes and internal organs if not treated.
  • Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by a red rash that can appear anywhere on the body.
  • In Sezary syndrome, cancerous T- lymphocytes are seen on a blood smear.
  • It has 3 phases:
    • Premycotic phase: asymptomatic scaly red rash on non-sun exposed area.
    • Plaque phase: thin red eczema-like rash.
    • Tumour phase: tumours form on the skin surface that may get ulcerated or infective. 
  • Pautrier's microabscess is a collection of malignant lymphocytes in the epidermis that manifests as solid intraepidermal nodules.
  • Treatment is usually palliative as cases present late. 

Option B: The neoplastic cells most commonly display cell markers of CD19 and CD20

  • Seen mostly in B-Cell lymphoma.
  • Mycosis fungiodes is a cutaneous T-Cell lymphoma.

Option C: The skin rash most commonly disappears over time

  • It is a malignant disorder.
  • The disease is more likely to spread and metastasize over time.

Option D: This disease is caused by a chronic fungal infection in the skin

  • The cause of mycosis fungiodes is unknown.
  • It is a malignant disease, not a fungal infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student is discovered to have a prolonged bleeding time during a laboratory exercise on coagulation testing. She has a history of "easy bleeding," including recurrent gum bleeding, epistaxis, cutaneous bleeding, and menorrhagia. Examination reveals large bruises on her skin. Her history is significant for eczema and pneumonia. Further tests revealed a Von Willebrand factor deficiency. Which of the following platelet-related thrombogenic processes is most directly harmed?
questions.solution:
Option A: Decreased platelet adhesion

  • It is a mild but most common coagulation disorder. It is an autosomal dominant disease.
  • Endothelial injury leads to transient vasoconstriction and endothelin release from the damaged cells. VWF binds to the exposed collagen. Platelets bind vWF via the GP Ib receptor at the site of injury.

  • Von Willebrand disease is characterized by a decrease in the levels of von Willebrand factor.
  • Signs and symptoms of Von Willebrand disease include large bruises, epistaxis, menorrhagia, bleeding gums, and heavy bleeding after cuts.
  • Decreased vWF leads to platelet plug formation defects due to platelet-to-vWF adhesion. Subendothelial von Willebrand factor (vWF) and collagen, which increase platelet adhesion and activation, are exposed when the endothelium is disrupted.
  • A deficiency of Von Willebrand factor (VWF) causes decreased platelet adhesion and increases the bleeding time of the patient.
  • Intrinsic coagulation defect leads to an increase in PTT as vWF carries and protects factor 8.
  • Platelet count and PT remain normal.
  • There is no coagulation with the ristocetin coagulation assay.
  • Treatment includes desmopressin, which releases vWF stored in the endothelium.

 

Option B: Formation of fibrinogen bridges

  • Low fibrinogen levels may lead to defects in the formation of fibrinogen bridges.
  • Fibrinogen binds glycoprotein IIb/IIIa and links the platelets.

 

Option C: Release reaction

  • Platelets are reactive to different stimuli and release various mediators stored in their granules. This is known as the release reaction.
  • It is an important step in primary hemostasis.

Option D: Fibrinolysis

  • Plasmin is an important enzyme that activates fibrinolysis.
  • Defects in fibrinolysis are seen in liver cirrhosis, amyloidosis, acute promyelocytic leukaemia, some solid tumours

questions.text: On self-examination, a 43-year-old woman discovers a single, freely movable mass in her right breast, confirmed by physical examination. Mammography reveals focal calcification with a linear configuration in the mass breast region. A biopsy of the breast (shown in the image) reveals large pleomorphic epithelial cells confined to dilated ducts with central zones of necrosis. What is the appropriate pathologic diagnosis?

choices.text: Ductal carcinoma in situ, comedocarcinoma type

questions.solution:
Option B: Ductal carcinoma in situ, comedocarcinoma type. 

  • Ductal carcinoma in situ originates from the proliferation of epithelium and does not invade the basement membrane. 
  • It may spread throughout the ductal system, but myoepithelial cells are preserved. 
  • Mammography helps diagnose the majority of cases. 
    • Calcification is the common finding 
    • Necrosis can be present 
    • Periductal fibrosis.
  • It does not produce nipple discharge from the nipple except in the papillary type. 
  • There are four different types of DCIS based on morphology 
    • Comedo DCIS 
    • Micropapillary DCIS 
    • Papillary DCIS 
    • Cribriform DCIS 
  • Comedo DCIS - Morphological signs are 
    • Nodularity 
    • Calcification with clustering or linear branching. 
    • Tumour cells with pleomorphism 
    • Central necrosis 
  • Micropapillar DCIS - Morphological signs are 
    • Complex projections 
    • Lack fibrovascular core
  • Papillary DCIS - Morphological signs are 
    • True papillae 
    • Fibrovascular core 
    • Lack of myoepithelial cells. 
  • Cribriform DCIS - Morphological signs are 
    • Look like a cookie 
    • Spaces sometimes filled with calcification 

Option A: Colloid carcinoma

  • It appears as a soft mass with the consistency of pale grey-blue gelatin. 
  • Tumour cells are seen floating in a lake of mucin on histopathology.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinoma develops due to BRCA1 gene hypermethylation, which causes a decrease in expression. 
  • It has a better prognosis. 

Option D: Phyllodes tumour

  • It is caused by stromal proliferation. 
  • It is biphasic because it contains non-carcinoma sections stimulated by growth factors. 
  • A mutation in the MED12 gene causes it.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • The tumours are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumour typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

  • Image on the left showing perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Image on the right showing Perineuronal satellitosis.

Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • It is a low-grade astrocytoma. Most common primary brain tumour in childhood.
  • Usually well circumscribed.
  • In children, most often found in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellum), but supratentorial can also be found.
  • It has a benign course and a good prognosis.
  • Histology shows it is of astrocyte origin, GFAP positive, with bipolar neoplastic cells with hairlike projections.
  • Associated with microcysts and Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew fibres)

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has hypertension with headache, diaphoresis, and palpitation. She does not complain of any weight gain. She further states that his symptoms are episodic. Which diagnostic procedures would be most useful in evaluating the possibility that pheochromocytoma might cause these findings?
questions.solution:
Option C: Urinary vanillylmandelic acid

  • Urinary vanillylmandelic acid & metanephrines are metabolites of epinephrine & norepinephrine: Markedly elevated in pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour that typically develops in the adrenal medulla.
  • Pheochromocytomas are usually benign (∼ 90% of cases) but may also be malignant.
  • Classic clinical features are due to excess sympathetic nervous system stimulation and involve episodic blood pressure crises with paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.
  • However, pheochromocytomas may also be asymptomatic or manifest with persistent hypertension.
  • Elevated catecholamine metabolites in the plasma or urine confirm the diagnosis, while imaging studies in patients with positive biochemistry are used to determine the tumour's location.
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice but is only carried out once alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine has become effective.

Option A: Serum C-peptide

  • Serum C peptide is used to evaluate insulin production from the pancreas in diabetic patients.
  • It is released along with insulin in equal quantity from the pancreas
  • A low level indicates insufficient production of insulin

Option B: Serum calcitonin

  • Used to evaluate hypocalcemia causes.
  • Calcitonin is produced by the thyroid gland, which lowers calcium levels.

Option D: Serum aldosterone

  • Serum aldosterone is high in conn syndrome.
  • However, it is not used; there is persistent, not episodic, hypertension in conn syndrome

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology outpatient department for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no presenting complaints, and her menstrual cycles are regular. Menarche occurred at the age of 15. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses oral contraceptive pills for contraception. A Pap smear is performed, and the examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: LSIL

  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) is a pre-malignant cervical lesion.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a risk factor for LSIL and cervical carcinoma.
  • The diagnosis of LSIL is based on the identification of nuclear atypia characterised by nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia (dark staining), coarse chromatin granules, and variation in nuclear size and shape.
  • Nuclear alterations with an associated perinuclear halo are termed pilocytic atypia.
  • The risk of HSIL is 6.9 %, and the risk of cervical cancer is 1%

Option B: HSIL

 

  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) is characterised by a high nuclear-to-cytoplasm ratio and hyperchromatic nuclei without nucleoli.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • The basement membrane is invaded by the tumour cells in cervical carcinoma. Whereas in the cervical intraepithelial lesions, the basement membrane is intact.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma

 

  • Adenocarcinoma presents with glandular cells. Cervical adenocarcinoma is uncommon. This patient’s PAP smear result is consistent with LSIN.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of the right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever. Physical examination reveals signs of jaundice. He has no history of pancreatitis or any alcohol or drug abuse. His vitals show mild tachycardia with normal blood pressure. Laboratory investigations revealed leukocytosis, normal haemoglobin, increased direct bilirubin, normal serum indirect bilirubin, and increased alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Biliary duct obstruction

  • This is the case of common bile duct obstruction seen in patients with the signs and symptoms of RUQ abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and high-grade fever, along with jaundice.
  • The common bile duct obstruction usually presents clinically with biliary colic (severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain), jaundice, and high fever due to cholangitis. This is known as Charcot’s triad.
  • Jaundice, due to extrahepatic obstruction, will commonly result in leukocytosis and increased levels of direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase, but normal levels of haemoglobin and serum indirect bilirubin, as seen in the laboratory investigations.
  • Gallstones are the most common cause of bile duct obstruction, and the other is carcinoma in the head of the pancreas, which can be ruled out as the patient has no history of pancreatitis or drug or alcohol abuse.
  • Most patients with gallstones usually have cholecystitis, which is characterized by a thickened gallbladder wall preventing the gallbladder from dilating. Therefore, if the obstruction is due to a gallstone, dilation of the gallbladder will not occur, and it will not be palpable.

 

Option A: Acute cholecystitis

  • In the case of acute cholecystitis, the obstruction is usually seen at the level of the cystic duct, which results in only the clinical manifestations of gall bladder obstruction with no hepatic manifestations.
  • Signs of inflammation/infection of the gallbladder are seen in acute cholecystitis with a positive Murphy sign.
  • Acute cholecystitis is typically associated with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, but it may not present with elevated alkaline phosphatase.
  • Alkaline phosphatase not specific for acute cholecystitis

 

Option B: Appendicitis

  • It is an inflammatory reaction to the appendix, which usually results in right lower quadrant pain starting from the stomach and moving to the right side, along with low-grade fever.
  • Pain at McBurney’s point, along with the signs and symptoms, establish the diagnosis.

 

Option D: Chronic cholecystitis

  • Chronic cholecystitis can occur as a result of gallstone formation, and resultant cystic duct obstruction can lead to inflammation and oedema in the gallbladder wall.
  • There is usually a general worsening of clinical symptoms and a history of similar episodes in the past, with fever and tachycardia occurring rarely.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who previously experienced an overactive bladder visited his family physician after eight years. He was prescribed oxybutynin but experienced dry mouth and increased water intake despite fearing excessive urination. What action does the drug in this scenario take to treat overactive bladder?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cholinergic muscarinic receptor antagonist

  • This is a case of overactive bladder syndrome in which the patient presents for a regular check-up with his family physician.
  • The patient has been on oxybutynin for eight years due to an overactive bladder.
  • In the case of an overactive bladder, the patient usually has excessive urination and dribbling.
  • The overactive bladder, in this case, is caused due to decreased tone of the detrusor muscle.
  • Oxybutynin is a cholinergic muscarinic receptor antagonist. Because of this action, it is used for an overactive bladder.

Option A: Cholinergic muscarinic receptor agonist

  • The drugs that act as cholinergic muscarinic receptor agonists include:
    • Bethanechol
    • Pilocarpine

Option C: Cholinergic nicotinic receptor antagonist

  • The drugs that act as cholinergic nicotinic receptor antagonists include:
    • Bupropion
    • Mecamylamine​​​​​​​

Option D: Cholinergic nicotinic receptor agonist

  • The drugs that act as cholinergic nicotinic receptor agonists include:
    • Nicotine
    • Epibatidine

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with frequent headaches, palpitations, and nausea for the last 2 weeks. She has gestational amenorrhea of 4 weeks. She has a blood pressure of 150/90mmHg. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs is not safe for gestational hypertension?
questions.solution:
Option C: Enalapril

  • In the clinical scenario, the patient gets pregnant with the help of an IVF treatment. IVF treatment is reported to have a 70% greater incidence of gestation hypertension and eclampsia. Furthermore, her examination also reveals high blood pressure.
  • Enalapril is contraindicated for gestational hypertension.
  • Enalapril is an Angiotensin Converting Enzyme Inhibitor (ACE inhibitor).
  • ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • Because they cause renal and pulmonary damage to the fetus by decreasing amniotic fluid.

Option A: Hydralazine

  • Hydralazine is an anti-hypertensive drug.
  • It inhibits vasoconstriction by inhibiting smooth muscles of the arterioles.
  • It is safe during pregnancy.

Option B: Methyl-dopa

  • Methyl-dopa is an alpha-2 selective agonist.
  • It is one of the earliest drugs used to manage hypertension in pregnancy.
  • It has a slow onset of action but is safe in pregnancy.

Option D: Amlodipine

  • It is a Ca++ channel blocker.
  • It is safe to use for the treatment of hypertension in pregnancy.
  • By inhibiting the calcium channels, these agents result in vasodilation and decreased heart activity (decreased heart rate, AV conduction and contractility).
  • The dihydropyridine (DHP) group has little direct cardiac activity and acts mainly on blood vessels, therefore is also called a peripherally acting calcium channel blocker.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 2-3 months. The patient sought a consultation since he had two episodes of bedwetting in the past week. On examination, you noticed that the patient had dry skin and also complained of mild constipation. You order fasting, random blood sugar, and an ultrasound of kidney, ureters, and, bladder (KUB), all of which turn out to be normal. Urinary and serum osmolality is consistent with diabetes insipidus. What would be the rationale for opting intranasal desmopressin spray over vasopressin?

choices.text: It causes less formation of factor VIII
It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype
Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

questions.solution:
Option C: It is more selective for the V2 receptor subtype

  • Desmopressin is a selective agonist of V2 receptors of vasopressin. V2 receptors are present in the kidney and on the endothelium, whereas V1 receptors are present in blood vessels. Therefore, Desmopressin is less likely to cause vasoconstriction than vasopressin.

Option A: It causes less formation of factor VIII

  • Desmopressin can release factor VIII and vWF, similar to vasopressin.

Option B: It causes less hypernatremia

  • Desmopressin has a similar risk of causing hyponatremia due to the retention of water.

Option D: Provides greater relief of excessive thirst the patient is experiencing

  • Both desmopressin and vasopressin can provide similar relief from excessive thirst.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female reports epigastric pain for six months, worsening with food intake and stress. She's tried a medication suggested by a friend, but it hasn't alleviated her symptoms and instead caused dry eyes and mouth, blurred vision, and constipation. Which medication might she have used?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pirenzepine

  • Epigastric pain that worsens with meals is commonly seen in peptic ulcer disease (PUD).
  • Reduced sweating, salivation and lacrimation are common side effects of anticholinergic drugs, e.g. pirenzepine.
  • Pirenzepine is a selective M1 receptor antagonist available for treating PUD in Europe. It acts by decreasing gastric acid secretion; however, effective doses for ulcer healing produce intolerable side effects.
  • Its use for PUD is now obsolete, replaced with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and H2 receptor blockers.

Option A: Cimetidine

  • Cimetidine is a competitive antagonist of histamine at H2 receptors in parietal cells. It inhibits histamine-induced gastric secretion.
  • Side effects are rare and seen in less than 5% of the population. They include headache, dizziness, fatigue and myalgias.

Option C: Misoprostol

  • It is a prostaglandin analogue that promotes mucous and bicarbonate secretion and decreases gastric acid secretion providing cytoprotective effects.
  • It causes diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, uterine bleeding and miscarriages and has been primarily replaced by PPIs as a treatment for PUD.

Option D: Omeprazole

  • Omeprazole is a PPI. It binds irreversibly to the parietal H+/K+ ATPase and inhibits gastric acid secretion.
  • Relatively safe, it may cause nausea, diarrhoea, abdominal pain and increased risk of clostridium difficile infection.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presents to your clinic with complaints of irregular menses. Though she claims to eat well, you notice that her weight is significantly low. Probing further, you learn that she often gets anxious doing her job and starts sweating profusely. On examination, you notice that she has tremors on her outstretched hands and is tachycardic. You make a provisional diagnosis of hyperthyroidism, order for thyroid profile and give her a beta blocker. What is the mechanism of action of beta-blockers on hyperthyroidism?

choices.text: As short-term, symptomatic therapy till the effect of carbimazole develops
As long-term therapy after subtotal thyroidectomy
In patient not responding to carbimazole
To potentiate the effect of radioactive iodine

questions.solution:
Option A: As short-term, symptomatic therapy till the effect of carbimazole develops

  • This patient has clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
  • Hyperthyroidism is an endocrine disorder characterized by the thyroid gland's excess synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones, which results in the hypermetabolic state of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hyperthyroidism is associated with increased beta-adrenergic receptors, which results in an increase in beta-adrenergic activity, which is responsible for many of the sympathetic symptoms related to hyperthyroidism.
  • Some of the sympathetic symptoms of hyperthyroidism include:
    • Anxiety
    • Palpitations
    • Tachycardia
    • Hyperactivity
    • Heat intolerance
  • Beta-blockers can relieve many of the neurologic and cardiovascular symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
  • These agents help to modify the severity of hyperadrenergic symptoms.
  • The mechanism by which these clinical changes are affected is unknown.
  • They do not alter the thyroid gland's synthesis or secretion of thyroid hormone, but some of the beta blockers, e.g. propranolol, inhibit 5’- deiodinase which converts T4 to T3.
  • Before beta-blocker therapy is initiated, signs of dehydration should be examined, which often occurs with hyperthyroidism.

Option B: As long-term therapy after subtotal thyroidectomy

  • It is used up to and after surgery until thyroid function limits return to normal levels.

Option C: In patient not responding to carbimazole

  • In patients not responding to carbimazole, alternatives such as radioactive iodine treatment or surgery may be recommended

Option D: To potentiate the effect of radioactive iodine

  • Beta-blockers do not potentiate the effect of radioactive iodine; however, they may be used before and after the administration of radioactive iodine while waiting for its therapeutic effect.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a 13-year history of antipsychotic medications for schizophrenia presents to a psychiatrist for her routine follow-up and complains of blurred vision. The psychiatrist seeks an ophthalmology consult, which reveals corneal and lenticular opacities in both eyes, causing blurry vision. The psychiatrist explains the situation to the family and decides to switch to a different antipsychotic with fewer side effects. Which of the following drugs is the main culprit for corneal and lenticular opacities in this lady?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thioridazine

  • Thioridazine belongs to a class of first-generation antipsychotics (FGAs) and is the drug of choice for schizophrenia.
    • Thioridazine is a low-potency FGA dosed in hundreds of milligrams to be therapeutically effective.
    • It makes thioridazine vulnerable to being overdosed and causing adverse effects due to having high histaminic and muscarinic activity with a corresponding increased prevalence of sedation and anticholinergic effects but a lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.
    • Low-potency FGAs (including thioridazine and chlorpromazine) are notorious for their antimuscarinic side effects, including dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, or urinary retention.
    • Ocular effects: May cause pigmentary retinopathy, characterized by diminution of visual acuity, the brownish colouring of vision, and impairment of night vision, in patients exceeding recommended doses.
      • Periodic eye examinations are recommended in patients receiving 600 mg/day or more
    • These side effects are managed by dose adjustments, medication changes, or appropriate medical therapy.

Option B: Haloperdiol

  • Haloperidol is a high-potency FGA, dosed in 1 to 10s milligrams and the usual side effects include sedation, weight gain, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option C: Flupenthixol

  • Flupenthixol is a high-potency FGA, dosed in 1 to 10s milligrams and the usual side effects include palpitations, extrapyramidal symptoms, contact dermatitis, amenorrhea, constipation, impotence, and blurred vision.

Option D: Pimozide

  • Pimozide is a high-potency FGA, dosed in 1 to 10s milligrams and the usual side effects include sedation, xerostomia, impotence, akinesia, and visual disturbances.

questions.text: Heparin and warfarin are anticoagulants. Heparin is a highly ionizing molecule that does not cross the blood-brain barrier. Warfarin is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor. It inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. In which of the following clinical conditions the use of an anticoagulant provides maximum benefit?

choices.text: Prevention of recurrences of myocardial infarction
Prevention of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

questions.solution:
Option B: Prevention of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

  • Anticoagulants, e.g. heparin and warfarin, are mainly used for prophylaxis of deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
  • Heparin is a large, highly ionizing molecule. It does not cross the blood-brain barrier or placenta; therefore, it is safe in pregnancy.
  • It is metabolized in the liver and excreted in the urine.Warfarin is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor. It inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. It can cross the blood-brain barrier, which is not safe during pregnancy.
  • The common side effect of anticoagulants is bleeding.
  • The antagonist of heparin is protamine sulfate, and warfarin is vitamin K.

Option A: Prevention of recurrences of myocardial infarction

  • Heparin and warfarin are mainly used in the prophylaxis of venous thrombosis.
  • Antiplatelet drugs, e.g. aspirin and clopidogrel, are used to prevent the recurrence of myocardial infarction.

Option C: Cerebrovascular accident

  • A stroke usually occurs due to arterial thrombosis.
  • Antiplatelet drugs, e.g. aspirin and clopidogrel, reduce the incidence of cerebrovascular accidents.
  • Dipyridamole enhances the action of aspirin. This combination is used to reduce the risk of stroke in patients with transient ischemic attacks.

Option D: Retinal artery occlusion

  • Retinal artery occlusion occurs due to emboli. Its risk factors include; diabetes, hyperlipidemia, stroke, hypertension, and arteriosclerosis.
  • Antiplatelet drugs are used to reduce the risk of retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not recommended for pseudomonal infections?
questions.solution:
Option D: Cefadroxil

  • Cefadroxil is a first-generation cephalosporin, which has no anti-pseudomonas coverage.

Antipseudomonal cell wall synthesis inhibitors are:

Cephalosporins:
  • 3rd generation - Ceftazidime, ceftolozane
  • 4th generation - Cefepime, Cefpirome.
Extended-spectrum penicillins:
  • Carboxypenicillins: Carbenicillin, Ticarcillin
  • Ureidopenicillins: Piperacillin, Mezlocillin
  • The antipseudomonal are antibiotic drugs that are effective against gram-negative rods, including Pseudomonas species.
  •  They are divided into carboxypenicillins, which include ticarcillin and carbenicillin, and the uridopenicillins, which include piperacillin.
  •  Like penicillins, the cephalosporin antipseudomonal are bactericidal beta-lactam antibiotics, which work by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis.
  •  The carboxypenicillins are inherently beta-lactamase resistant, but piperacillin requires the addition of a beta-lactamase inhibitor such as tazobactam since it is beta-lactamase sensitive.
  • Other drugs that can be used against pseudomonas infection are carbapenems like imipenem and fluoroquinolones

Option A: Piperacillin

  • Piperacillin is Extended spectrum penicillin with good coverage of the pseudomonas infections

Option B: Cefoperazone

  • Cefoperazone is a third-generation cephalosporin and has good coverage against pseudomonas infections

Option C: Ceftazidime

  • Ceftazidime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin, and it is used for pseudomonas infections

questions.text: Which of the following tetracyclines is associated with vestibular toxicity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Minocycline

  • Vestibular toxicity of Minocycline is exhibited as dizziness, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting.
  • The tetracycline causing maximum vestibular toxicity is Minocycline.

Option B: Demeclocycline

  • Demeclocycline is not associated with vestibular toxicity.
  • It causes diabetes inspidus.

Option C: Doxycycline

  • Doxycycline is not associated with vestibular toxicity. Side effects of doxycycline are the same as those of tetracyclines, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, tooth discolouration in children, phototoxicity, teratogenicity, liver failure and Fanconi syndrome.
  • Doxycycline is safe for renal failure.

Option D: Tetracycline

  • Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea are the most common reasons for discontinuing tetracyclines due to direct local irritation of the intestinal tract.
  • Oral tetracyclines can cause oesophageal ulceration.
  • Tetracyclines alter the normal gastrointestinal flora and increase the risk of Clostridium difficle colitis.
  • Other side effects include tooth discolouration in children, phototoxicity, teratogenicity, liver and kidney failure and Fanconi syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of a painless swelling on her right breast for 2 months. She further explains that the swelling is progressive in nature. The is vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The patient is diagnosed with breast carcinoma. She was operated and was prescribed tamoxifen. Which of the following is the risk factor of the drug involved in the patient’s pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Development of endometrial carcinoma

  • This is a case of breast cancer in which the patient presents with complaints of a painless swelling on her right breast for 2 months.
  • The swelling is progressive in nature.
  • The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • The patient was diagnosed with breast cancer and was operated on.
  • Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers in women.
  • The patient was prescribed tamoxifen for the treatment of breast cancer.
  • Tamoxifen and toremifene are selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) that are useful for chemoprevention as well as treatment of both early-stage and metastatic breast carcinoma.
  • These increase the risk of endometrial carcinoma.

Option A: Development of bleeding disorder

  • The bleeding disorders are usually caused due to the following drugs:
    • Aspirin
    • Streptokinase
      • Capreomycin

 

Option C: Development of ovarian carcinoma

  • Ovarian carcinoma may be caused by the following drugs
    • Clomiphene citrate
    • Gonadotropins

 

Option D: Development of cervical cancer

  • Cervical cancer is less likely to be caused by drugs.
  • The most common cause of cervical cancer is the human papillomavirus

questions.text: Avoid which anesthesia medications in a 25-year-old male patient diagnosed with pheochromocytoma, presenting with episodic headache, palpitations, perspiration, blood pressure of 188/92 mm Hg, pulse of 110/min, hematocrit of 50%, and elevated catecholamine levels, with normal renal and liver function tests?
questions.solution:
Option C: Halothane

  • Halothane makes cardiac muscles more sensitive and increases the effect of epinephrine and catecholamine. 
  • Pheochromocytoma patients have elevated catecholamine levels in their blood, which can cause arrhythmia with halothane. 
  • In patients with pheochromocytoma, halothane should be avoided. 
  • Halothane can result in malignant hyperthermia.
  • Susceptibility for malignant hyperthermia is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion​​​​​​​

Option A: Desflurane 

  • Inhaled desflurane is used to cause general anaesthesia. It is also used as maintenance anaesthesia in adults and children after receiving other anaesthetics before and during surgery.
  • Desflurane does not have a significant sensitising effect on the myocardium. 
  • It can cause adverse respiratory reactions, including coughing, laryngospasm, and secretions.

Option B: Fentanyl 

  • Fentanyl is an opioid commonly used to treat chronic pain in patients. 
  • It can cause respiratory depression, urinary retention, drowsiness and confusion.

Option D: Midazolam 

  • Midazolam belongs to the benzodiazepine class and lowers blood pressure. 
  • It can be used to induce anaesthesia in patients with pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: Two antihistaminics, terfenadine and Astemizole, were withdrawn from the market following the occurrence of cardiac arrhythmias when they were present in high concentrations in the blood. These effects were explained by which of the following?

choices.text: Use of these drugs by addicts
Genetic predisposition to metabolise succinylcholine slowly
Concurrent treatment with erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic

questions.solution:
Option D: Concurrent treatment with erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic

  • Microsomal enzymes metabolise Astemizole and terfenadine. When administered in high doses or when co-administered with CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g. erythromycin, clarithromycin, ketoconazole, itraconazole), it leads to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (Torsades de pointes)
  • This toxicity occurs due to the blockade of delayed rectifier potassium channels in the heart at higher concentrations.
  • Erythromycin inhibits these enzymes and raises the plasma concentration of these drugs.
  • At high levels, these agents block cardiac K+ channels leading to arrhythmias.

Option A: Use of these drugs by addicts

  • The effects of these drugs occur due to co-administration with CYP3A4 inhibitors, thus causing arrhythmias and deaths, leading to their withdrawal from the market.

Option B: Genetic predisposition to metabolise succinylcholine slowly

  • The cardiac arrhythmias due to Astemizole and terfenadine occur due to the blockade of cardiac potassium channels causing QT interval prolongation. As a result, Torsades de pointes occur in such patients. It has no involvement with the metabolism of succinylcholine.

Option C: Concurrent treatment with phenobarbital

  • The cardiac arrhythmias due to Astemizole and terfenadine occur due to co-administration with microsomal enzyme CYP3A4 inhibitors (erythromycin, clarithromycin, ketoconazole, itraconazole). Phenobarbital is a CYP3A4 inducer, thus increasing the metabolism of decreasing levels of Astemizole and terfenadine.
  • As a result, it would decrease ventricular arrhythmia occurrence.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of progressive shortness of breath, on and off fever, weight loss, and cough with greenish sputum production for 3 months. The patient's vital signs are stable. The doctor advised the patient to have a sputum culture. His sputum sample was collected and sent to the laboratory for testing. Which of the following can disinfect the sputum involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Autoclaving

  • This is a case of tuberculosis in which the patient complains of progressive shortness of breath, fever, weight loss, and cough with greenish sputum production.
  • Following are the characteristics of an autoclave:
    • Autoclaving is a process of sterilization that uses time, temperature, and pressure to kill all forms of microorganisms.
    • Autoclaving is the safest and most effective method for sputum disinfection.
    • Incineration is an effective alternative.
    • Boiling is used after initial disinfection by 5% phenol (carbolic acid) or its derivatives like Lysol and cresol.

Option B: Chlorhexidine

  • The sputum cannot be disinfected with Chlorhexidine.
  • It is usually used as a mouth wash

Option C: Boiling

  • The research has shown that the boiling method has failed to disinfect sputum.
  • Boiling is not sterilization; it is more effectively described as pasteurisation.

Option D: Normal saline

  • The normal saline doesn't contain any surfactants that effectively disinfect bacteria and debris from the wound.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the outpatient department with complaints of vomiting and confusion. She is on holiday with her grandparents. She is unusually tired and complains of muscle aches, fever, a headache, and a stiff neck. This morning, her grandparents noticed, and so they had to come to the clinic for a check-up. This condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Late complement component deficiency

  • The above-given case is meningitis.

  • It is caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

  • Neisserial infections are associated with a deficiency of late complements (C5-C9).

Complement deficiencies:

  • MAC deficiency (C5-C9) → leads to recurrent Neisseria infections.

  • D & I absence → leads to pyogenic infections.

  • H absence → leads to the hemolytic uremic syndrome.

  • C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency → Hereditary angioneurotic edema → reason for ACE inhibitor side effects.

Option A: Early complement component deficiency

  • Early complement component (C1, C2, C3, C4) deficiency: SLE, glomerulonephritis and pyogenic infections.

Option C: There is no such association

  • This patient’s condition is associated with a late complement component deficiency.

Option D: Any deficiency can be associated

  • This patient only has the deficiency of late complement component deficiency.

  • There is no other deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female visits the hospital with complaints of runny nose, fever, headache, and chills since 4 days. Fever is measured at 102°F, and blood pressure and heartbeat are measured within normal limits. Clinical examination is suggestive of viral infection. Which one of the following is the feature of this virus?

choices.text: They contain either DNA or RNA, but never both

questions.solution:
Option C: They contain either DNA or RNA, but never both

  • The virus is an acellular infective agent consisting of nucleic acid and proteins.
  • Viruses have either few or no enzymes for their replication and are completely dependent on the host for the synthesis of their own parts.
  • As they replicate by using host assembly, they cannot multiply by division methods such as binary fission.
  • The nucleic acid in a virus can either be RNA or DNA.
  • The complete infectious virus is known as Virion consisting of either RNA/DNA inside the capsid (made up>
  • Some viruses enclose themselves with the lipids, carbohydrates and proteins of the host and are termed enveloped viruses.

Option A: They are non-filterable agents.

  • Viruses are filterable agents because they pass through the unglazed porcelain with the filtrate and remain virulent.
  • They are considered smaller than bacteria.

Option B: They are obligate extracellular parasites.

  • Viruses are considered obligate intracellular parasites.
  • They cannot replicate outside the host and show crystalline nature.
  • They are dependent on the host for their replication and use host machinery (enzymes) for the synthesis of their nucleic acid and proteins for multiplication.

Option D:  Multiply by binary fission

  • They replicate by using host assembly.
  • They cannot multiply by division methods such as binary fission.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient from Sierra Leone presented to ER with fever, stomach pain, headache, weakness and fatigue for a week. Now he has developed diarrhoea and has started coughing up blood. He works as a nurse and has been doing shifts in isolation wards. However, he reported no breach of PPE. The temperature was 37.1 degrees Celsius on physical examination, and red spots were seen all over the body. Laboratory blood tests showed renal impairment, raised transaminases, elevated creatinine kinase (CK), thrombocytopenia, a prolonged prothrombin time, and prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time, suggesting organ dysfunction. He was admitted and initiated treatment, but over the next few days, his renal impairment and encephalopathy developed. The underlying image shows an infective agent. What is the disease this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ebola virus disease (EVD)

  • The Ebola virus is a deadly human disease most commonly affecting people and nonhuman primates (monkeys and gorillas).

Species of genus Ebolavirus:

  • Zaire ebolavirus (Type virus: EBOV).
  • Sudan ebolavirus (Type virus: Sudan virus; SUDV)
  • Bundibugyo ebolavirus (Type virus: Bundibugyo virus; BDBV)
  • Taï Forest ebolavirus (Cote d’Ivoire) (Type virus: Taï Forest virus; TAFV)
  • Reston ebolavirus (Type virus: Reston virus; RESTV)
  • Only 4 species i.e., Zaire, Sudan, Tai, and Bundibugyovirus cause disease in people.
  • The Reston virus is known to cause disease in nonhuman primates and pigs but not in people. 
  • Four of the six known ebolaviruses, including EBOV, cause a severe and often fatal hemorrhagic fever in humans and other mammals, known as Ebola virus disease (EVD)
  • The natural reservoir of the Ebola virus is believed to be bats, particularly fruit bats, and it is primarily transmitted between humans and from animals to humans through body fluids.
  • The Ebola virus (EVD) is a deadly disease in people and nonhuman primates. The viruses that cause EVD are located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa.
  • The Ebola virus was first discovered in 1976 near the Ebola River in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Since then, the virus has been infecting people from time to time, leading to outbreaks in several African countries.

Symptoms

  • The incubation period is from 2 to 21 days.
  • A person infected with Ebola cannot spread the disease until they develop symptoms.
  • Symptoms of EVD can be sudden and include:
  • Fever
  • Fatigue
  • Muscle pain
  • Headache
  • Sore throat

This is followed by:

  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rash
  • Symptoms of impaired kidney and liver function
  • In some cases, internal and external bleeding (for example, oozing from the gums or blood in the stools).

Diagnostic methods:

  • Antibody-capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)
  • Antigen-capture detection tests
  • Serum neutralization test
  • Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay
  • Electron microscopy
  • Virus isolation by cell culture.

Treatment:

  • Supportive care – rehydration with oral or intravenous fluids – and treatment of specific symptoms improve survival.
  • Two monoclonal antibodies (Inmazeb and Ebanga) were approved for treating Zaire ebolavirus (Ebolavirus) infection in adults and children.

Vaccination:

  • The Ervebo vaccine is effective in protecting people from the species Zaire ebolavirus.
  • Zabdeno-and-Mvabea for individuals 1 year and older.
  • The vaccine is delivered in 2 doses: Zabdeno is administered first, and Mvabea is given approximately 8 weeks later as a second dose.

Option B: Marburg virus infection

  • The causative agent of Marburg virus disease (MVD) is the Marburg virus.
  • Marburg and Ebola viruses are members of the Filoviridae family (filovirus). Though caused by different viruses, the two diseases are clinically similar.
  • Initially, human MVD infection results from prolonged exposure to mines or caves inhabited by Rousettus bat colonies.
  • Marburg spreads through human-to-human transmission via direct contact (through broken skin or mucous membranes) with infected people's blood, secretions, organs or other bodily fluids and surfaces and materials (e.g. bedding, clothing) contaminated with these fluids.
  • Illness caused by the Marburg virus begins abruptly with
    • High fever
    • Severe headache
    • Severe malaise.
    • Muscle aches and pains are common features.
    • Severe watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain with cramping, nausea, and vomiting can begin on the third day.
  • The appearance of patients at this phase has been described as showing “ghost-like” drawn features, deep-set eyes, expressionless faces, and extreme lethargy.
  • Patients develop severe haemorrhagic manifestations between 5 and 7 days, and fatal cases usually have some form of bleeding, often from multiple areas.
  • Currently, there are no vaccines or antiviral treatments approved for MVD. However, supportive care – rehydration with oral or intravenous fluids and treatment of specific symptoms improve survival.

Option C: Yellow fever

  • The yellow fever virus is present in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America. The virus can spread to people by the bite of an infected mosquito.
  • Illness ranges from a fever, aches and pains to severe liver disease with bleeding and yellowing skin (jaundice).
  • Yellow fever infection is diagnosed on laboratory testing, a person’s symptoms, and travel history.
  • There is no medicine to treat or cure infection from yellow fever.
  • Rest, drink fluids, and use pain relievers and medication to reduce fever and relieve aching.
  • Avoid certain medications, such as aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, for example, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), or naproxen (Aleve), which may increase the risk of bleeding.

Option D: Dengue fever

  • Dengue viruses can spread to people through the bite of an infected Aedes species (Ae. Aegypti or Ae. Albopictus) mosquito.
  • Mild symptoms of dengue can be confused with other illnesses that cause fever, aches, and pains, or a rash.
  • The most common symptom of dengue is fever with any of the following;
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Rash
    • Aches and pains (eye pain, typically behind the eyes, muscle, joint, or bone pain)
  • There is no specific treatment for dengue. Rest and supportive treatment is done.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient from rural India presents to the outpatient department with complaints of chills, headache, muscle aches,  diarrhoea, and fever every three days. There is jaundice and splenomegaly on physical examination. There is no history of drinking or smoking. On blood smear examination, band-shaped trophozoites are seen. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option D: P. malariae

  • In the above-given case, the symptoms of fever with chills every 3rd day, fatigue, jaundice, and band-shaped trophozoites are suggestive of malaria caused by P. malariae.
  • Other three-ring forms are seen in the late trophozoite stage.
  • Microscopic tests for malaria:
    • Examination of peripheral blood smears (thin and thick blood films):
    • Gold standard method:
      • Thick smear: Used for quantification and malaria pigment detection.
      • Thin smears: Used for speciation, Late trophozoite (band-like slightly amoeboid) of P. malariae can be demonstrated. P. malariae trophozoites have compact cytoplasm and a large chromatin dot.
      • Occasional band forms and/or “basket” forms with coarse, dark-brown pigment can be seen.
      • Quantitative buffy coat examination (QBC): Rapid method for detection of parasites
“Band-form” trophozoites in a thin smear “Basket-form” trophozoites in a thin smear

 

Option A: P. ovale

  • It causes tertian malaria 7-42 days after incubation.
  • It causes periodic fever every 48 hours.
  • Ovale hypnozoites can persist in the liver and can cause reinfection.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option B: P. vivax

  • It also causes tertian malaria with periodic fever at 48 hours intervals.
  • Chloroquine is used for the treatment of P. vivax infection. ​​​​​​​

Option C: P. falciparum

  • Falciparum invades and destroy RBCs and cause severe malaria.
  • It can also cause organ dysfunction by causing microinfarctions.
  • Trophozoite ring formation in RBCs can be seen on blood smear examination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who has had HIV for 2 years and has a CD4 count of 150 cells//µL presents with the complaint of fatigue, weight loss, and cough for several days. He is also complaining of chest tightness on breathing. The patient says that the symptoms are getting worse every day. The doctor ordered sputum microscopy. The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain of his sample showed black-coloured cysts, as shown in the image below. Select the true statement about the pathogen causing the above-mentioned disease as shown in the image.

choices.text: Ampicillin is the drug of choice
Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option A: Stain : - Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS)

The given image shows Pneumocystis jirovecii

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii) causes PCP (Pneumocystis pneumonia)
  • It most commonly infects HIV patients (with CD4+ cell count below 200/µL) and patients on long-term immunosuppressive regimens.
  • It mostly affects only immunocompromised individuals.
  • Patients with hematologic and non-hematologic malignancies.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiographs show perihilar haziness with diffuse mottling.
  • Sputum induced by inhalation of a hypertonic saline solution is a useful specimen for microscopic demonstration of the organism.
  • Gomori’s methenamine silver (GMS) staining is the method of choice to demonstrate the cysts of P. jirovecii. The cysts resemble black-coloured crushed ping-pong balls against the green background.
  • Cotrimoxazole is the DOC for Pneumocystis pneumonia.

Image: The spore cases (cysts) of pneumocystis stained with the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain.

Other Options

Option B: Ampicillin is the drug of choice

  • The drug of choice for pneumocystis jirovecii is amphotericin B.
  • Ampicillin is the drug of choice in infections caused by a beta-lactamase-negative type of H. influenza, enterococci, and L. monocytogenes.

Option C: Occurs in patients with CD4+ count 400/µL

  • It usually occurs in patients with a CD4+ count below 200/µL.
  • Recurrent bacterial pneumonia occurs when CD 4 count is 200-500/ µL.

Option D: Diagnosed on X-Ray imaging

  • This disease is most commonly diagnosed through sputum microscopy.
  • The X-ray can show consolidation, but diagnosis is confirmed by sputum culture,

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the OPD with abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea. His examination reveals a blood pressure of 110/70mmHg with a regular pulse rate of 70 beats per minute. A stool analysis is requested for examination in the microbiology laboratory, revealing the egg floats on a saturated salt solution. Identify the organism present in the patient whose egg is shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Option C: H.Nana

  • The egg of Hymenolepis nana is shown in the image above, and Hymenolepis diminuta infections are most often asymptomatic.
  • Heavy infections with H. nana cause weakness, headaches, anorexia, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. Polar filaments with central hooklets feature the non-Bile stained egg of hymenolepis nana.
  • Praziquantel and niclosamide are the mainstays of treatment. Infective form: Eggs are ingested with contaminated food and water.                                                                                  

Option A: Ascaris

  • Eggs with rugosity.
  • Fertilised egg of Ascaris

  • Unfertilised egg of Ascaris

Option B: Enterobius vermicularis

  • Planoconvex egg having tadpole-like larvae.

Option D: Ancylostoma duodenale

  • Eggs with a thin transparent shell having 4-8 blastomeres, non-bile stained

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of fever and vomiting for the last 5 hours. He also added that he had eaten pastries from the restaurant 5 hours ago, after which the symptoms began to appear. On examination, he looks lethargic, dehydrated, and febrile. The doctor diagnosed the condition as food poisoning. Which enterotoxin is mainly responsible in this case of food poisoning?
questions.solution:
Option D: Type A

  • The above case is suggestive of Staphylococcal food poisoning.
  • Type A enterotoxin is responsible for most cases of food poisoning by staphylococcus.
  • Points in favour of Staphylococcal food poisoning:
    • Ingestion of pastries from a restaurant.
    • 5 hours ago
  • Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus:
    • Antigenic types A–E, G–I, R-T and V.
  • Toxin-mediated illnesses
    • Food poisoning:
        • Type A Enterotoxin is responsible for most cases of food poisoning.
        • Incubatory Period: 1-6 hours due to preformed toxin.
        • Site of action: The toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain. It also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.
        • Heat stable (not destroyed after heating food).
        • Detected by ELISA, Latex agglutination test and Toxin gene detection by PCR.
  • SSSS (staphylococcal skin scalded syndrome):
    • Due to exfoliative toxins A & B.
  • TSS [toxic shock syndrome]:
    • Due to TSS toxin (enterotoxin F).
    • It is a super-antigen (non-MHC restricted): that activates > 20% of lymphocytes leading to massive lymphokine release and shock.

Option A: Type E

  • Staphylococcal enterotoxins type E cause toxic shock-like syndromes.
  • It has been associated with food poisoning

Option B: Type C

  • It causes a wide range of diseases, mainly food intoxication.
  • Type C causes other infections like:
    • Toxic shock syndrome (TSS)
    • Hemorrhagic pneumonia

Option C: Type B

  • One of the most potent bacterial super-antigens, staphylococcal enterotoxin B, stimulates cytokine release and inflammation by having a profoundly damaging effect on the immune system. In humans, it has been associated with:
    • Atopic dermatitis
    • Nasal polyps
    • Asthma
    • Food poisoning

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever and a painful pimple on the back of his thigh. He further explains that the pimple is tender, and he has difficulty sitting. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. On examination, there is a pustule on the posterior surface of the patient's left thigh. Which of the following stains is useful for demonstrating the organism from a smear made from the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Polychrome methylene blue

  • This is a case of anthrax in which the patient presents with complaints of a painful pustule on the posterior surface of the thigh.
  • Polychrome methylene blue is useful for the demonstration of the organism from a smear made from the pustule.
  • In Abattoir (slaughterhouses)- Infected animals or contaminated animal products (hides, wool etc.) are the important sources of anthrax- primarily a zoonotic disease.
  • McFadyen’s reaction (presumptive diagnosis of anthrax in animals): Polychrome methylene blue-stained smears of blood show an amorphous purplish material, a remnant of the capsular material around the bacillus.

Option B: Calcofluor white

  • Calcofluor white is a fluorescence blue dye test.

Option C: Albert stain

  • Albert stain is used for staining the metachromatic granules or food granules found in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Option D: Modified Kinyoun stain

  • Modified kinyoun stain is a cold acid-fast stain.
  • It is used for acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active female presents to the physician with complaints of wart-like growth on the vulva, rashes on the skin, and swollen lymph nodes for 1 week. She is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. After further examinations and investigations, the condition was diagnosed as syphilis. After giving treatment for syphilis, the response to treatment can be best assessed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: VDRL

  • This is a case of syphilis in which the patient presents with complaints of wart-like growth on the vulva, rashes on the skin, and swollen lymph nodes for 1 week.

  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease.

  • It is usually transmitted after having unprotected intercourse multiple times.

  • Unprotected sexual intercourse multiple times doesn't really cause it; the main factor is having unprotected intercourse multiple times with different sex partners.

  • Condoms are a very effective preventive measure against syphilis.

  • VDRL can be used for treatment monitoring as specific tests remains positive (reactive) after the treatment.

  • A fourfold decrease in titre following therapy suggests adequate therapy, whereas a fourfold increase in titre of reaginic antibodies following therapy suggests reinfection or relapse.

Option A: FTA-ABS

  • The fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is a test which is used to detect antibodies to the bacteria Treponema pallidum. It is not used to assess the treatment of syphilis,

Option C: TPHA

  • Treponema pallidum haemagglutination (TPHA) test is a hemagglutination assay which is used for the measurement of antibodies against Treponema pallidum.

Option D: Immobilization test

  • The immobilisation test is a serological test.

  • It is used for the diagnosis of syphilis.

  • It is not used for the assessment or treatment of syphilis.

questions.text: Medical Confidentiality is a set of rules that limits access to information discussed between a person and their healthcare practitioners. With only a few exceptions, anything you discuss with your doctor must, by law, be kept private between the two of you and the organization they work for. In the few exception scenarios, the doctor is eligible for Privileged communication. But a plea for privileged communication would fail if?

choices.text: Disclosure made to the court in negligence cases
Disclosure made in the special interests of doctor
Disclosure of notifiable diseases to authority
Disclosure of infectious diseases to employer

questions.solution:
Option B: Disclosure made in the special interests of doctor

  • It is a statement, made bonafide upon any subject matter by a doctor to the concerned authority having corresponding interest, due to his legal, social or moral duty to protect the interests of the community or of the state.
  • This is the only exception to professional secrecy.

Option A: Disclosure made to the court in negligence cases

  • In the Court of law: He has to answer the questions to avoid contempt of court.

Option C: Disclosure of notifiable diseases to authority

  • Doctors are permitted privileged communication in case of a notifiable disease.
  • A doctor has a statutory duty to notify births, deaths, stillbirths, infectious diseases, therapeutic abortions, drug addictions, epidemic and food poisoning to public health authorities.

Option D: Disclosure of infectious diseases to employer

  • Privileged communication is applied when it’s done for
    • Patient’s interest: In case of suicidal tendencies.
    • Self-interest: An reveal in the court of law.
    • Community interest, 39 CrPC: In case of any crime → Inform the police
      1. Notifiable disease.
      2. Infectious disease (e.g.: Enteric fever of chief, epilepsy of a driver etc.).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who had gone camping in Manali on New year's eve was found dead in a lake the next morning. He had been part of the celebrations the previous night and was seen drinking and smoking hookah with his group of friends. Autopsy reports confirm that he died of drowning in cold water. Among the following, what causes the death in cold water drowning?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vagal inhibition of heart

  • Vagal stimulation leads to asystolic cardiac arrest (‘diving reflex’), or ventricular fibrillation secondary to QT prolongation after a massive release of catecholamine on contact with cold water.
  • The resultant loss of consciousness leads to secondary drowning.
  • Alcohol increases such effects.

Option B: Pulmonary edema

  • In both freshwater and saltwater drowning, there is terminal pulmonary edema. It is an incorrect option.

Option C: Loss of consciousness

  • Vagal inhibition of the heart causes death when drowning in cold water, not loss of consciousness.
  • There may be loss of consciousness due to drinking and smoking hooka, but it is not the cause of death.

Option D: Ventricular fibrillation

  • In freshwater drowning, death results from ventricular fibrillation.
  • While in salt water, it is due to cardiac arrest from fulminant pulmonary edema and associated changes.

questions.text: Kevorkian sign is one of the earliest changes seen after death. It is seen in the retina and it is the fragmented appearance of the blood in retinal vessels. All of the following statements about the sign are true, except?

choices.text: Persist even after 1 day of death

questions.solution:
Option A: Persist even after 1 day of death

  • The blood in retinal vessels appears fragmented or segmented (cattle trucking or shunting) within seconds to minutes after death, and persists for about an hour (Kevorkian sign).

Option B: Appear within minutes of death

  • Kevorkian sign appears within seconds to minutes after death and persists for about an hour.

Option C: Visualized using ophthalmoscope

  • Blood in the retinal vessels appears fragmented and can be seen only in the retina by an ophthalmoscope.

Option D: Cattle tracking sign

  • The blood in retinal vessels appears fragmented or segmented known as cattle trucking or shunting.

questions.text: A 35 year old man is brought to you dressed in woman’s clothing. On further questioning you find that he gets sexual pleasure from doing so. It is a case of:
questions.solution:
Option A: Eonism

  • Transvestism/ Eonism: by wearing the dressing of the opposite sex, mostly seen among males.

Option B: Ipsation

  • Onanism/ Ipsation / masturbation: Self-stimulation which affects sexual arousal.

Option C: Peeping tom

  • Voyeurism: There is a morbid desire of the individual to observe unsuspecting people undress or naked, taking bath, see the genitalia or watch intercourse to get erotic excitement and sexual gratification. It is commonly seen in males.
  • Voyeurs frequently peep into the bedrooms of others, and are called ‘Peeping Toms’.

Option D: Mixoscopia

  • Mixoscopia: Getting sexual gratification by observing another couple performing sexual intercourse.

questions.text: Which among the following metals are found on histochemical techniques in hepatic and pulmonary lesions in patients with vineyard sprayer lung disease.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Copper:

  • Vineyard sprayer lung: Due to inhalation of copper sulphate spray, which is characterized by histiocytic granulomatous lung.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mercury:

  • Acute exposure to elemental mercury vapor may produce corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea. It may progress to pulmonary edema and fibrosis. Sometimes, manifestations similar to Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) are seen especially in children.
  • Chronic Mercury Poisoning (Hydrargyrism):
    • Intention tremors (Danbury tremors/shaking palsy).
    • Mercurial erethism is seen in persons working with mercury in minor manufacturing firms. This term is used to refer to the psychological effects of mercury toxicity.
    • Mercurialentis: It is a peculiar eye change due to exposure to mercury vapor.
    • Acrodynia or pink disease (because it is characterized by a generalized body rash) is thought to be an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction particularly seen in children. This can be caused by chronic mercury exposure in any form.
    • Minimata disease is a type of organic mercurial poisoning due to the eating of fish poisoned by mercury.

Option C - Lead:

  • Signs and Symptoms: Anemia, Burtonian line/Basophilic stippling, Bone lines, Colic, Constipation (dry belly ache); Drop (wrist/Foot drop) - Lead palsy, Encephalopathy, Facial pallor (earliest sign), Gout (saturnine gout), Hypertension, Impotence.

Option D - Phosphorous:

  • Signs and Symptoms of acute phosphorus poisoning.
    • Garlicky odour.
    • Luminous vomit and stool because of the presence of phosphorus.
    • Fumes emanate from the stools (smoking or smoky stool syndrome).
    • Acute poisoning causes liver cell necrosis, fatty liver and acute yellow atrophy.
  • Chronic Phosphorus Poisoning (Phossy Jaw/Glass Jaw/Lucifer’s Jaw):
    • Due to inhalation of fumes over years.
    • Toothache (earliest symptom) & swelling of the jaw.
    • Loosening of the teeth &Necrosis of the lower jaw.
    • Sequestration of bone in the mandible & multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

questions.text: A 22 year old woman was examined by the medical officer post allegations of being physically and sexually assaulted by her boyfriend. To assist in confirming the allegation, the doctor began a thorough physical examination. The doctor preferred to document the abrasion wounds over contusions. All of the following are true about contusions except?

choices.text: They may become visible several hours after injury
They may not indicate the site of trauma
They do not indicate the direction of force
They are visible immediately after an injury

questions.solution:
Option D: They are visible immediately after an injury

  • It is advisable that a medical officer should re-examine the patient after 24 hours, as by this time the bruises are clearly visible.

Option A: They may become visible several hours after injury

  • They may become visible after a few hours to 1–2 days after the injury has happened.

Option B: They may not indicate the site of trauma

  • They may appear at a distance away from the actual site of injury eg. Black eye

Option C: They do not indicate the direction of force

  • Bruises/Contusions do not indicate the direction of the applied force.

questions.text:
While testing the deleterious health hazards on a group of people after giving a drug and a placebo, the following results were obtained:


	
		
			 
			Number of people
			Number of people affected
		
		
			Placebo
			15225
			1605
		
		
			Drug
			15225
			1804
		
	


Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Relative risk reduction (RRR) 11%, Absolute risk reduction (ARR) 11%

questions.solution:
Option B: RRR 11%, ARR 1%

  • Event rate for drug (Ed) = 1804/15225 x 100= 0.118
  • Event rate for placebo (Ep)= 1605/15225 x 100= 0.105
  • ARR = Ed – Ep = 0.013 =1.3%
  • RRR = Ed – Ep/Ed = 0.013/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%

questions.text: A 25-year-old male after being bitten by a street dog presented to the hospital to take the rabies vaccine. Which of the following is the intramuscular Rabies vaccine schedule for Post-exposure prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Option B: 1-1-1-1-1

  • The intramuscular Rabies vaccine schedule for Post-exposure prophylaxis is Essen Regimen (1-1-1-1-1).
  • 5 dose regimen prescribes 1 dose on each day 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28.

Other options

Option A: 2-2-2-0-2

  • It is Updated Thai Red Cross Regimen (2-2-2-0-2).
  • It is not an intramuscular regimen, it is intradermal.
  • It is given on Day 0,3,7,28.

Option C: 1-1-0-1-1

  • 1-1-0-1-1 is not in use. 
  • The Essen Regimen (1-1-1-1-1) is the intramuscular Rabies vaccine schedule for Post-exposure prophylaxis.

Option D: 8-0-4-0-0-4

  • No such regimen is in use.
  • The intramuscular Rabies vaccine schedule for Post-exposure prophylaxis is Essen Regimen (1-1-1-1-1).

questions.text: Cyclopropagative life cycle is defined as the disease agent which undergoes cyclical change and multiplies in the body of the arthropod. This type of life cycle is seen in which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Malaria

  • Cyclopropagative life cycle is defined as the disease agent which undergoes cyclical change and multiplies in the body of the arthropod.
  • Malaria shows cyclopropagative cycle i.e., Multiplication + development.

Option B: Plague

  • Plague shows propagative cycle i.e., multiplication only.

Option C: Filarial

  • Filaria shows cyclo development cycle i.e., only development.

Option D: Yellow fever

  • Yellow fever shows cyclo development cycle i.e., only development.

Learning Objective

Biological transmission of arthropod– Borne disease

Transmission Definition Propagative (Only multiplication) Cyclo propagative (Multiplication + development) Cyclo development (Only development)
Examples

Plague

Yellow fever

 Malaria

Filaria

Guinea worm

questions.text: A total of 130 patients were screened for vertebral disc prolapse by CT scan and confirmation of the disease was made by discectomy operation. Out of 56 patients who screened positive in CT-scan, 46 were confirmed for disease in operation. Rest 74 patients were screened negative in CT scan and only 40 patients were confirmed negative for the disease in operation. Calculate the Positive and Negative likelihood ratio.
questions.solution:
Option A: 2.875 and 0.531

  • Positive likelihood ratio: It is the probability that a positive test would be expected in a disease divided by the probability of that test would positive in a healthy patient.
  • Negative likelihood ratio: It is the probability that a negative test would be expected in a disease divided by the probability of that test would be negative in a healthy patient.

 

Screening test Disease positive Disease negative Total
Positive a (46) b (10) 56
Negative c (34) d (40) 74

 

Sensitivity = a/a+cx 100

= 46/80 x 100

= 0.575

Specificity = d/b+dx 100

= 40/50 x100

= 0.80

 

LR+ [likelihood Ratio positive] = Sensitivity/1-Specificity

= 0.575/ (1-0.80)

= 2.875

 

LR- [likelihood ratio negative] = 1-Sensitivity/specificity

= 1-0.575 / 0.80

= 0.531

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with bilaterally symmetrical discrete, keratotic, follicular, brown colored, acuminate papules with a central keratinous plug as shown in the image below. The given condition is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
EFA

Essential Fatty Acid (EFA) deficiency:

  • Essential fatty acid deficiency leads to toad like skin which is also called as Phrynoderma.
  • Phrynoderma can also seen in Vitamin A deficiency.
  • It presents with bilaterally symmetrical discrete, keratotic, follicular, brown-colored, acuminate papules with a central keratinous plug.

Zinc

  • Zinc deficiency can lead to Acrodermatitis enteropathica.

Selenium

  • Selenium deficiency leads to Endemic cardiomyopathy (Keshan's disease).

Iodine

  • Iodine deficiency can lead to hypothyroidism, retarded physical development and impaired mental function, increased rate of spontaneous abortion and stillbirth neurological cretinism, including deaf-mutism; and myxoedematous cretinism, including dwarfism and severe mental retardation.

Vitamin B2

Cheilosis, glossitis and dermatitis

Zinc

Acrodermatitis enteropathica

Vitamin B6

Seizures (infant)

Vitamin E

Progressive external ophthalmoplegia

Chromium

Impaired glucose metabolism

EFA

Phrynoderma (toad-like skin) - Treated by supplementing B-complex vitamin & safflower oil.
Selenium

Endemic cardiomyopathy (Keshan's disease)

Learning Objective

  • Essential fatty acid deficiency leads to toad like skin which is also called as Phrynoderma.
  • Selenium deficiency leads to Endemic cardiomyopathy (Keshan's disease).
  • Iodine deficiency can lead to hypothyroidism.
  • Vitamin E deficiency can lead to Progressive external ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with persistent cough for 3 weeks, fever, night sweats and extreme weight loss is diagnosed with tuberculosis infection. ASHA worker visited him and gave him DOTS therapy. What is the role of ASHA in DOTS therapy?
questions.solution:
DOTS provider

  • ASHA is the central component of the national rural health mission (NRHM).

Responsibilities of ASHA worker:

  • Create awareness and mobilize a community for local health planning
  • Promote good health practices
  • Counsel women on RCH
  • Act as depot holder for essential medicines
  • Act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Accompany pregnant women and children to the nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY and help reduce MMR.

questions.text: In a population of 1000, there are 200 eligible couples. Among the eligible couples, 30 use condoms, 20 use IUCD, 20 use OC pills and 70 have undergone female sterilization. The rest of the couples do not use any method. Calculate the Couple protection rate.
questions.solution:
Option D: 70%

  • Values given are:
    • Total eligible couples = 200
    • Eligible couples protected by any of the approved methods = 30+20+20+70 =140
  • Couple protection rate (CPR) = Total number of eligible couples protected by any of the approved methods / Total number of eligible couples in the community × 100
  • CPR =140/200 X 100= 70%

Therefore, other options (A, B, and D) can be ruled out.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of pseudo membrane formation, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes and difficulty in breathing. On culture examination, the causative organism showed a Chinese letter pattern of arrangement. Which of the following is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Nasal carriers are more dangerous than cases
Cases are the most important source of infection
The hemagglutination test has been replaced by the Schick test

questions.solution:
Option A: Nasal carriers are more dangerous than cases

  • Carriers are a more important source of infection (dangerous) than cases.

Option B: Immunization prevents carrier state - Incorrect statement

  • Immunization does not prevent the carrier state.

Option C: Cases are the most important source of the infection - Incorrect statement

  • Carriers are a more important source of infection (dangerous) than cases.

Option D: The hemagglutination test has been replaced by the Schick test - Incorrect statement

  • The Schick test has been replaced by the hemagglutination test.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male from a rural village presented to the hospital with a high fever, chills, muscle pain, rash, nausea, and vomiting for 5 days. Which of the following can best diagnose the given condition during the first week of infection?
questions.solution:
Option A: NS1 antigen detection

  • The above-given clinical features point towards the diagnosis of dengue.
  • Dengue caused by Group-B Arbovirus- D1, D2, D3, D4 (MC subtype - D1)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinically Seen 10 spots in Tourniquet test- Dengue fever; seen more than or equal to 20 spots seen in Dengue hemorrhagic fever.
    • Serologically- NS-1 Antigen Test comes positive even in 1st week.

Option B: Viral nucleic acid detection

  • Real-time RT-PCR and reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assays may both identify the RNA-based dengue virus genome. Several RT-PCR tests for diagnosing dengue virus have been described in recent years. They have a considerably quicker turnaround time than virus isolation and offer superior specificity and sensitivity.

Option C: Both 

  • Only, Serologically- NS-1 Antigen Test comes positive even in 1st week.

Option D: None of the above

  • This is not the appropriate answer to the above-given question.

questions.text: What is the incubation period of typhoid fever?
questions.solution:
