Option C: Country ‘X’ has more number of younger women than country ‘Y’

  • Based on the above statistical data, OPTION C is the true statement.
  • A secondary rise in frequency often occurs after the age of 65. Women who developed their first breast cancer under the age of 40, had three times the risk of developing a second breast cancer than those who developed their first cancer after the age of 40 Indeed the etiologies of pre-menopausal & post-menopausal breast cancer appears to be different.

Learning Objective

  • Age is the most important risk factor for breast cancer.
  • Breast cancer is uncommon below age of 35, its incidence is increasing rapidly b/w ages of 35 to 50.
  • A slight bimodal trend in the age distribution has been observed with a dip in incidence at the time of menopause.
  • A secondary rise in frequency often occurs after the age of 65. Women who developed their first breast cancer under the age of 40, had three times the risk of developing a second breast cancer than those who developed their first cancer after the age of 40 Indeed the etiologies of pre-menopausal & post-menopausal breast cancer appears to be different.
  • Other Risk factors of breast cancer:
    • Family history of breast cancer
    • Delayed first pregnancy
    • Early menarche and late menopause
    • Elevated estrogen & progesterone levels
    • Prior breast biopsy
    • Higher socio-economic status
    • Radiation exposure etc.

questions.text: Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health & Family welfare on 25th Dec 2014 to improve full immunization coverage from 65% of infants in 2014 to 90 % by 2020. Which of the following disease is not included in Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
Option C: Meningococcal meningitis

  • Meningococcal meningitis disease is not included in Mission Indradhanush.

Option A/ B/ D: Tuberculosis/ Measles/ Diphtheria

  • Options A, B, and D are included in Mission Indradhanush.

Learning Objective

Mission Indradhanush:

  • Launched by the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare on 25th Dec 2014 to improve full immunization coverage from 65% infants in 2014 to 90 % by 2020.
  • Includes vaccination against 7 life-threatening diseases in the entire country. They are:
    1. Diphtheria
    2. Whooping cough
    3. Tetanus
    4. Polio
    5. Tuberculosis
    6. Measles and
    7. Hepatitis B
  • In addition, vaccines for Japanese Encephalitis (JE) and Hae­mophilus influenza type B (Hib) are also provided in selected states.

questions.text: Employees' State Insurance Scheme of India is an integrated social security scheme tailored to provide social protection to workers and their dependents. The duration of Extended sickness benefit under the ESI Act 1948 is?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2 years

  • 70% of the average daily wages and is payable for 91 days (in any continuous period of 365 days).
  • Extended sickness benefit: Payable for 2 years (set of 34 diseases).
  • Enhanced sickness benefit: Full average daily wage for a duration of 7 days in Vasectomy and 14 days in Tubectomy.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to explain the frequency distribution. Which of the following correctly defines the frequency distribution?

choices.text: It is a table that displays frequency of various outcomes in a sample
It is a frequency polygon presenting variation by line, it shows the trend of events over a period of time
It is a graph of cumulative frequency distribution
It is an area diagram of frequency distribution developed over a histogram

questions.solution:
Answer

Option A: It is a table that displays frequency of various outcomes in a sample

  • In statstics a frequency of distribution is a table that displays the frequency of various outcomes in sample/

Other options

Option B: It is a frequency polygon presenting variation by line, it shows the trend of events over a period of time.

  • This options is incorrect

Option C: It is a graph of cumulative frequency distribution

  • This options is incorrect

Option D: It is an area diagram of frequency distribution developed over a histogram

  • This options is incorrect

questions.text: While calculating the incubation period for measles in a group of 25 kids, the standard deviation is 2 and the mean incubation period is 8 days. Calculate Standard error.
questions.solution:
Option A: 0.4

  • In the given question, n =25 kids, Standard deviation (σ) = 2, Mean incubation period (µ) = 8 days
  • Thus, standard error = 2/5 = 0.4

questions.text: A cold chain is a temperature-controlled supply chain used to transport vaccines. At which of the following level the risk of cold chain failure is the greatest?
questions.solution:
Option D: Subcentre & village level

  • The risk of cold chain failure is greatest at the Subcentre and village levels.

  • In the subcenter, the cold chain is maintained with a Vaccine carrier at temperatures +2oC to +8 oC.

  • In the village, the cold chain is maintained with an ice pack at temperatures +2oC to +8 oC.

other options

Option A: Regional level

  • At the regional level, the cold chain is maintained with the help of 

    • WIC (Walk in Cold room) +2oC to +8 oC

    • WIF (Walk in Freezer) -15 oC to -25 oC.

Option B: District Level

  • At the district level, the cold chain is maintained with the help of 

    • Large ILR (Ice Lined Refrigerator) +2oC to +8 oC

    • Large DF (Deep Freezer) -15 oC to -25 oC

Option C: PHC level

  • At the district level, the cold chain is maintained with the help of 

    • ILR (Ice Lined Refrigerator) +2oC to +8 oC

    • DF (Deep Freezer) -15 oC to -25 oC

questions.text: A 29-year-old suspected TB patient was sent for a sputum examination. Two boxes were given for sputum sample collection. In which of the following method these boxes will be labeled?
questions.solution:
Option A: a, b

  • Diagnosis of TB patients as well as follow-up samples are labeled with a single LSN with a suffix ‘a’ for the spot sample and ‘b’ for the morning sample.
  • Two sputum samples over a period of 2 days are collected in patients, with a history of cough >2 weeks.
  • Spot sample is collected on Day 1; Morning sample is collected on Day 2.
  • Labeling of sputum samples in RNTCP:
    • Diagnosis, as well as follow-up samples, are labeled with a single LSN with a suffix ‘a’ for the spot sample and ‘b’ for the morning sample.

Option B: A, B

  • It does not align with the standard labeling convention for sputum samples in the context of TB diagnosis.

Option C: 1, 2

  • Option C does not follow the typical labeling method used for sputum samples in TB diagnosis, which involves the 'a' and 'b' suffixes to differentiate between spot and morning samples.

Option D: Y, Z

  • This does not follow the typical labeling method used for sputum samples in TB diagnosis, which involves the 'a' and 'b' suffixes to differentiate between spot and morning samples.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of weakness and fatigue, dyspnea on lying down and palpitations. Symptoms aggravate at night time when he tries to sleep in the bed. He gives the history of Rheumatic heart disease in the past. On examination, his blood pressure is 116/ 80 mm Hg. Pulse is 86bpm. There is elevated JVP, hyperdynamic apex beat with apical thrill on palpation. An echo is done, which reveals mitral regurgitation. A diagnosis of Mitral regurgitation is made. Which of the following auscultatory finding is true regarding Mitral Regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pansystolic murmur radiating to axilla
Mitral regurgitation:

  • S1 is generally absent, soft, or buried in the holosystolic murmur of chronic, severe MR.
  • In patients with severe MR, the aortic valve may close prematurely, resulting in the wide but physiologic splitting of S2.
  • A low-pitched S3 occurring 0.12–0.17 secs after the aortic valve closure sound, i.e., after the rapid-filling phase of the LV, is believed to be caused by the sudden tensing of the papillary muscles, chordae tendineae, and valve leaflets.
  • It may be followed by a short, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur, even in the absence of structural MS.
  • In patients with ischemic or dilated cardiomyopathy, however, a third sound (S3 ) may also signify ventricular dysfunction.
  • A fourth heart sound is often audible in patients with acute severe MR who are in sinus rhythm.
  • A presystolic murmur is not ordinarily heard with isolated MR.
  • A systolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity is the most characteristic auscultatory finding in chronic severe MR.
  • It is usually holosystolic, is decrescendo and ceases in mid-to-late systole in patients with acute severe MR.
  • The systolic murmur of chronic MR is usually most prominent at the apex and radiates to the axilla.
  • However, in patients with ruptured chordae tendineae or primary involvement of the posterior mitral leaflet with prolapse or flail, the regurgitant jet is eccentric, directed anteriorly, and strikes the LA wall adjacent to the aortic root.
  • In this situation, the systolic murmur is transmitted to the base of the heart and, therefore, may be confused with the murmur of AS.
  • In patients with ruptured chordae tendineae, the systolic murmur may have a cooing or "seagull" quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality.

Option A: Mid-diastolic murmur in early mild disease

  • Murmur is pansystolic in MR.
  • A mid diastolic murmur is seen in mitral stenosis, severe MR and atrial myxoma

Option B: Wide split S2

  • Wide splitting of S2 sound is seen in ASD.

Option D: Narrow split S1

  • Narrow split S1 is a feature of Mitral Stenosis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents to the cardiac OPD with complaints of dyspnea and chest pain following exercise. His elder brother had the same symptoms, and he died 2 years ago of sudden collapse while participating in a marathon event. On examination, a Jerky pulse and double apical impulse on palpation, narrow split S2 and a crescendo-decrescendo murmur are heard during auscultation. Genetic analysis shows that the disease is associated with multiple genes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy

  • Familial HOCM is an Autosomal dominant Mendelian inherited disease in approximately 50% of cases.
  • MC gene involved is β-myosin heavy chain > Myosin-binding protein C > Troponin T.
  • In HOCM, thickening of the interventricular septum occurs. As a person does exertion, the thickened IVS blocks the blood causing sudden cardiac death.

Clinical features of HOCM:

  • Dyspnea (earliest symptoms) due to Diastolic malfunction (due to small LV cavity), pooling of blood in lungs, Pulmonary Oedema present
  • Chest pain on exertion: Sub. Endocardial Ischemia
  • Effort intolerance
  • Sudden collapse/death on exercise/ running due to ischemic ventricular fibrillation, Twitching, Loss of Pulse / BP, Sustained arrhythmias (Atrial Fibrillation)

Examination findings include: 

  • Pulsus Bisferiens (aka) "Jerky Pulse”
  • Double apical impulse (5th + 6th Intercostal space)
  • Apex beat
  • S2: Narrow split/ single S2 / Reverse Split S2
  • S4 is heard due to outflow obstruction and left atrial hypertrophy occurs. The extra force generated by the left atrium explains the occurrence of S4.
  • Ejection systolic murmur

Option A: Mitral Valve Prolapse

  • Mitral valve prolapse is not related to a family history of the disease.

Option C: Dilated Cardiomyopathy

  • The clinical presentation of HOCM is somewhat similar to DCM, but DCM is not a genetic defect.

Option D: Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy

  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is not a genetic disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the physician’s office after he developed an excruciating headache. On examination, he had nuchal rigidity. Non-contrast CT scan performed after 4 hours showed blood in the Sylvain fissure. What does the ECG show?
questions.solution:
Option A: T-wave inversion 

This patient presented with severe headache and nuchal rigidity, with brain imaging showing blood likely has subarachnoid haemorrhage.

  • Electrocardiogram (ECG) alterations have long been known to be related to subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). However, the underlying pathophysiology, aetiology, and prognosis of cardiac anomalies are still largely unknown. Autonomic dysfunctions and hypothalamic stimulations have been related, although the connection has not been demonstrated to be causal. These factors may have an impact on therapeutic approaches since patients with impaired hearts may suffer negative effects from receiving massive fluid infusions or vasopressors.
  • The patient's life may very possibly be in jeopardy if therapeutic thrombolytic treatment, anticoagulation, and life-saving neurosurgery are not performed.
  • T-wave inversion and ST-segment elevation have been observed as ECG alterations in subarachnoid haemorrhage, frequently implying ischemic heart disease.
  • In particular, if the corrected QT (QTc) interval is prolonged, SAH has been linked to malignant ventricular arrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia, torsades de pointes, and ventricular fibrillation, which frequently jeopardise a patient with hemodynamic instability.
  • ECG changes with Subarachnoid haemorrhage are
    • Left axis deviation
    • U waves
    • T-wave- Deep, symmetrical T wave inversion
    • R-wave abnormalities
    • Non-specific ST-T changes

Option B: Artifact

  • SAH shows ECG changes resembling myocardial ischemia, and this presentation is not an artefact.

Option C: Premature ventricular complexes

  • The ECG changes in SAH do not include premature ventricular complexes.
  • It may be caused by other conditions, e.g. drugs and injury to the heart.

Option D: Prominent U wave

  • U wave corresponds to after depolarisation of the ventricles.
  • A prominent U wave is seen in:
    • Hypokalemia
    • Associated with other drugs, e.g. Quinidine and type 1A antiarrhythmics
    • CNS disease with long QT intervals
    • Mitral valve prolapse
    • Hyperthyroidism

questions.text: A 78-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of substernal chest pain. He says that the pain started 4 hours ago and rates it as 7 on a scale of 0-10. Nitroglycerin and aspirin were given in the ambulance on the way to the hospital. He also reports passing dark stools for the past 15 days. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, peptic ulcer disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history and drinks alcohol occasionally.   The patient appears pale and diaphoretic. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg, and his pulse is 114 beats/min regular. His ECG shows widespread ST depression in all leads except aVR, which shows ST elevation. Blood tests demonstrate haemoglobin of 3.6g/l and a high-sensitivity troponin of 140ng/l. What is the best initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Beta blocker to slow heart rate and reduce ischaemia

questions.solution:
Option B: Packed RBC transfusion

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with NSTEMI, possibly due to cardiac ischemia secondary to low haemoglobin. Low haemoglobin in this patient is due to upper gastrointestinal bleeding in the setting of a perforated peptic ulcer. Signs of upper gastrointestinal bleeding include low haemoglobin and dark stools.
  • This patient’s haemoglobin level of 3.6g/dl is a strong indication for RBC transfusion. Low haemoglobin level predisposes to cardiac ischemia and can lead to acute coronary syndrome. Therefore, packed RBC transfusion can prevent cardiac tissues from further injury.
  • Delay in blood transfusion can have fatal consequences in this patient.

Criteria of packed RBC transfusion:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10g/dl or hematocrit less than 30% in a patient with cardiovascular disease, sepsis or hemoglobinopathy.
  • Haemoglobin level less than 8g/dl in case of active bleeding like upper gastrointestinal bleeding in this patient.
  • Haemoglobin level less than 7g/dl or hematocrit less than 21% in a patient with uncompromised patient.

Option A: Aggressive treatment with dual antiplatelet therapy

  • Antiplatelet therapy is indicated in the management of acute coronary syndrome.
  • However, severe anaemia in this patient warrants a packed RBC transfusion immediately to prevent further cardiac ischemia.
  • Aspirin, an antiplatelet, has always been given to him before his hospital arrival.

Option C: Nitrates to relieve ischemia

  • Nitrates are vasodilators, which are given in acute coronary syndrome to decrease preload on the heart. However, this patient has been given nitroglycerin already, so the best initial management would be to transfuse packed RBCs.

Option D: Beta-blocker to slow heart rate and reduce ischemia

  • Beta-blockers are given to treat tachycardia. However, this patient's tachycardia is due to low cardiac output, which reflexively increases heart rate to compensate for cardiac output.
  • In this scenario, transfusion of packed RBC will likely improve tachycardia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man came to the outpatient department complaining of recurrent muscle cramps for the past 1 year. He also reports an increased frequency of urination and getting up several times at night to urinate for the past 4-6 months. On examination, his blood pressure was 170/90 mmHg, his temperature was 98°F, and his pulse was 90 beats per minute. Initial investigations were performed, which showed decreased serum K+ levels. What is the best next step to diagnose the disease this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Option B: Plasma Aldosterone to Renin Ratio

  • This patient has signs and symptoms of hyperaldosteronism.
  • The most common cause of Conn syndrome is an adrenal adenoma.
  • In an adrenal adenoma, endogenous production of aldosterone is increased.
  • This leads to a negative feedback effect on plasma renin activity. Therefore, the plasma renin activity is decreased.
  • The most important screening test to find the cause of hyperaldosteronism is the plasma aldosterone to renin ratio.
  • In Conn syndrome, the plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity ratio is high.
  • But the Gold Standard test for Conn’s syndrome is the Salt-loading test/Saline infusion test.

Option A: Urinary Metanephrines

  • Urinary metanephrine levels are an important screening test in diagnosing pheochromocytoma, which is also a tumour of the adrenal gland. But, it produces catecholamines, which cause periodically increased blood pressure and does not affect serum potassium levels.

Option C: Urinary electrolytes

  • Urinary electrolytes test can be deranged in Conn’s syndrome, but its specificity is very low. Several disorders (including infections) can cause the derangement of urinary electrolytes. Therefore, it is not used to diagnose primary hyperaldosteronism.

Option D: Renal Vein Renin Levels

  • Renal vein renin level is the test that is often used in the workup of renal arterial stenosis. Unilateral renal arterial stenosis causes the renin levels to be increased in the ipsilateral renal vein.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic complaining of short height, fatigue, and weight gain. An order is made for blood tests of TSH and T4 levels.  Her Free T4 was low, and her TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Primary hypothyroidism

  • The clinical picture of short stature with low T4 and elevated TSH suggests primary hypothyroidism. 

Other options

Option A: Pituitary adenoma

  • Pituitary adenoma can produce any hormone, and if it produces TSH, then T4 should be elevated

Option B: TSH-secreting pituitary tumour

  • Both TSH and T4 levels should have been elevated if it was TSH secreting tumour

Option C: Thyroid target receptor insensitivity

  • It is characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and inappropriately normal or elevated TSH.
  • The clinical features of Resistance to Thyroid Hormone include goitre, attention deficit disorder, mild reduction in I.Q., delayed skeletal maturation, tachycardia, and impaired metabolic responses to thyroid hormone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent diarrhoea episodes for the past 3 hours. On examination, his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 88 bpm. ABGs analysis shows a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following condition can have a similar acid-base imbalance?
questions.solution:
Option A: Small bowel fistula

  • A small bowel fistula causes metabolic acidosis by increasing the strong ion difference due to the loss of a large number of strong cations (sodium and potassium) with a relatively small loss of chloride

Option B: Metformin

  • Metformin causes lactic acidosis.
  • This results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Option C: Ethylene glycol poisoning

  • Ethylene glycol results in the formation of oxalic acid, glycolic acid, and other organic acids.
  • This raises the anion gap.

Option D: DKA

  • DKA results in the formation of ketoacids.
  • This raises the anion gap.
  • Hence increased anion gap metabolic acidosis is seen in DKA

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the clinic with the complaint of chronic productive cough, progressive dyspnea on exertion, and purulent sputum. Examination revealed clubbing and coarse rales. She stated that she had had respiratory problems since childhood. A CT scan image is given below. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bilateral varicose bronchiectasis

  • The image shows bilaterally multiple cystic clusters of thin-walled cystic spaces in the lung parenchyma.
  • It can be seen to be bigger on the left side as the left lower lobe is more commonly involved in bronchiectasis.
  • Varicose bronchiectasis term implies non-uniform bronchial dilatation.
  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic respiratory disease defined as progressive, irreversible dilation of the bronchial trees resulting in permanently dilated airways.
  • It is characterized by productive cough and recurrent respiratory infections.
  • Infection, airway obstruction, and peribronchial fibrosis contribute to the pathogenesis of bronchiectasis.
  • Bronchiectasis is classified into the following types based on morphology:
    • Cylindrical (tram-track bronchiectasis: bronchi are enlarged and cylindrical. Dilated airways are seen in horizontal orientation.
    • Varicose bronchiectasis: bronchi are irregular with areas of dilatation and constriction. It refers to non-uniform bronchial dilatation.
    • Cystic/saccular bronchiectasis: dilated bronchi form clusters of a cyst, a cluster of thin-walled cystic spaces.

Other options

Option B: Multiple cavitating secondaries

  • It refers to pulmonary metastases, which then tend to cavitate.
  • Cavitation occurs in about 4% of total metastasis to the lung.
  • The above history does not give any information about the primary source of malignancy; hence this choice is ruled out.

Option C: Interstitial fibrosis

  • Presents with a chronic cough and clubbing but fine crepitations, and CT shows Honeycombing with ground glass appearance.

Option D: Miliary tuberculosis

  • It is the fatal form of disseminated disease of tuberculosis to the lungs and other organs.
  • CT shows a Millet seed appearance.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue, nausea, and cola-coloured urine developing over 1 week. She was afebrile and hemodynamically stable on admission. On physical examination, the patient did not present signs of chronic liver disease. Investigations revealed a significant elevation of ALT & AST. Renal function was normal. She is found to have HbsAg positive & IgM HBc positive. Which of the following is the drug of choice in patients having hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tenofovir

  • The above clinical history & laboratory findings are suggestive of Acute Hepatitis B infection.
  • Tenofovir is regarded as the first-line agent in the treatment of hepatitis B.
  • It is a nucleotide analogue, and it inhibits Hepatitis B polymerase by preventing the formation of 5' to 3' phosphodiester linkage essential for DNA chain elongation.
  • It thus causes premature termination of DNA transcription.

Option A: Beta interferon

  • Alpha interferon is the only licensed drug for Hepatitis B with immunomodulatory and inhibitory properties.
  • Beta interferon is not recommended.

Option B: Sofosbuvir

  • It targets the catalytic site of NS5B and is activated through phosphorylation, then competes with nucleotides and results in chain termination.
  • NS5B is an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase necessary for the replication of the Hepatitis C virus.
  • So, this drug is recommended against the Hepatitis C virus and not Hepatitis B.

Option C: Simeprevir

  • It is an inhibitor of NS3/4A protease, an enzyme involved in the post-translational processing and replication of HCV.
  • This drug is also recommended against the Hepatitis C virus and not Hepatitis B.

questions.text: A forty-eight years old male patient presents to the emergency department with a sudden loss of vision and acute abdominal pain, mainly around the epigastric area radiating to the back. He has had a history of alcohol abuse for the past twenty years. Physical examination is performed, and he is found to be tachypnoeic and tachycardic. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum amylase and leucocytes. Given the patient's condition, what is the cause of this patient's vision loss?
questions.solution:
Option A: Purtscher retinopathy

  • The patient's history and findings suggest a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.
  • Inflammation of the pancreas over a short period of time is known as acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis commonly presents with fever, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.
  • Elevated levels of serum pancreatic enzymes are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Purtscher retinopathy is a relatively unusual complication of acute pancreatitis.
  • It is manifested by a sudden and severe loss of vision.
  • Fundoscopic findings include cotton-wool spots and haemorrhages confined to an area limited by the optic disc and macula.
  • It is believed to be due to occlusion of the posterior retinal artery with aggregated granulocytes.

Option B: Hyperglycaemia

  • Elevated levels of pancreatic enzymes and white blood cells suggest the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis.
  • Even though hyperglycaemia can cause problems in the eyes, the patient's laboratory findings do not show any evidence of hyperglycaemia.

Option C: Hypoxia

  • Even though the patient is tachypnoeic, acute pancreatitis causing retinopathy is the more likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Option D: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion

  • Even though central retinal vein occlusion can cause the patient's eye symptoms, acute pancreatitis causing retinopathy is the more likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of a rash on her face, joint pain associated with the rash, itching on exposure to sunlight, and arthralgia, which can be difficult to distinguish from many other illnesses because of their overlap. On lab investigation, antinuclear antibodies were positive (+). The patient responded well to corticosteroids, and after tapering off the steroids, disease-modifying anti-rheumatic medications (DMARDs) will be administered to the patient. Which of the following is seen with the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Seizures

  • A seizure is an uncontrolled, sudden electrical disturbance in the brain.
  • It may cause changes in your behavior, movements or feelings, and levels of consciousness.
  • Inflammation of the synovium, the membrane that lines your joints, is referred to as synovitis in medical terminology.
  • The most likely diagnosis in the clinical scenario is SLE because it is characterized by inflammation of the fat cells under the skin, causing a tender red lump or nodules, itching, and joint pain.
  • Polyarthritis refers to joint disease with one or more signs of inflammation, including pain, movement restriction, swelling, warmth, and redness.
  • Alopecia, seizures, and leucopenia are seen in SLE.

Diagnosis:

  • Trauma: Verify that the source of pain is the joint, not the surrounding soft tissues.
  • The most common causes of mono-arthritis are crystals (i.e., gout and pseudo gout), infection and trauma
  • Diagnostic studies often are only supportive, so a careful history and physical examination are important.

Symptoms:

  • Some mono-arthritis symptoms may include: The pain usually worsens with movement, warm feelings in the joint, swelling, and weakness.

Option A: Mono-arthritis

  • The main lesion in SLE is synovitis and not mono-arthritis.
  • SLE is associated with polyarthritis but not mono Arthritis.

Option B:  Dementia

  • It is a term for the inability to remember or to make a decision.
  • It is present in older age.
  • It is common in Alzheimer's disease.

Option D: Night blindness

  • Night blindness is caused by a deficiency of vitamin A.
  • Rod photoreceptor cells are present in the retina and are responsible for low-light vision.
  • Vitamin A supplements can prevent night blindness due to vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese male patient presents to OPD with severe right great toe pain that suddenly started late at night and woke him up from sleep. The patient has a history of pain in small joint hands as well, nearly all the time, unaffected by the use of joints. He remembers his father used to have the same symptoms in old age. An X-ray of the foot was done, which showed lytic punched-out lesions. Identify the disease and the sign associated with it.
questions.solution:
Option A: Gout - Martel Sign

  • The given radiograph shows Martel's hook sign and is associated with gout.
  • Gouty erosions have raised margins or lips that radiologically are referred to as Martel’s hook or Martel’s Sign.
  • No loss of bone density is expected.
  • The osteological signs of gout can be located on the joint surfaces, around the joint itself, or at a distance from the joint.
  • Lesions from gout have a diagnostic appearance on radiographs- referred to as a "punched out" appearance: crescent-shaped erosions, with smooth, well-remodeled margins, on dry bone.
  • Lesions vary in size, are usually rounded or oval, and may have a sclerotic border.
  • Diagnostic tests for gout include serum uric acid levels, X-ray joints, joint fluid tests, and other imaging techniques. Gout crystals are needle-like which, on polarising microscopy, appear negatively birefringent.
  • Gout is treated with the use of NSAIDs, colchicine, and corticosteroids. Drugs reducing uric acid production, such as allopurinol, and medicines that increase uric acid excretion from kidneys, Like probenecid, are also used effectively.

Option B: Osteoarthritis- Froment’s sign

  • Formento's sign is a physical sign during the examination of the hand to test for ulnar nerve palsy.
  • A positive test is when the patient compensates by flexing the flexor pollicis longus to maintain the grip due to weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • Formats sign is seen in patients with osteoarthritis.

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis- Swan neck deformity

  • Swan neck deformity is the most common change in people with Rheumatoid arthritis due to a tear of ligaments.
  • It results in laxity of the finger's middle joint (proximal interphalangeal joint) and flexion of the distal joint.

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis- Boutonniere deformity

  • Boutonnière deformity is when a finger's middle or proximal interphalangeal joint is flexed, and the distal interphalangeal joint is hyperextended.
  • In early diagnosed cases wearing a splint can cure.
  • In more severe cases, surgery is performed to repair tendons and straighten the middle joint.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with multiple episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizure for the last 10 days. On general examination, he has multiple hyper-pigmented papules over the nasolabial region and cheeks, multiple hypo-pigmented macules over the lower limbs and a Shagreen patch over the lateral aspect of the right buttock. A diagnosis of Tuberous Sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following findings in his computed tomography (CT) scan is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sub-Ependymal Nodules

  • Tuberous Sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in either the TSC-1 gene (chromosome 9) encoding hamartin or the TSC-2 gene (chromosome 16) encoding tuberin.
  • Classic triad of clinical features comprises learning disability, epilepsy and skin lesions, but there is a wide spectrum of clinical features.
  • Patients with tuberous sclerosis may present with the following clinical features:
    • Seizures
    • Mental retardation
  • Hypomelanotic macules are small white oval (ash-leaf) macules usually present in early childhood.
  • Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), occurring later in adolescence,​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
  • These patients have an increased incidence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs). Patients frequently require anticonvulsants for seizures.
  • Magnetic resonance images showing subependymal nodules (arrows) with a ‘papaya seed’ appearance in two patients with tuberous sclerosis. 

Option A: Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

  • Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is characterized by angiogenesis and vascular proliferation situated within the posterior nasal cavity, sphenopalatine foramen, and nasopharynx.
  • A clinical exam with nasal endoscopy shows a firm, reddish-purple mass within the nasal cavity.
  • Radiographs can also show bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus from mass effect.

Option B: Meningioma

  • A meningioma is a primary central nervous system (CNS) tumour.
  • Meningiomas are grouped into three grades based on their characteristics.
  • Each grade includes different meningioma subtypes.
    • Grade I meningiomas are low-grade tumours and are the most common. This means the tumour cells grow slowly.
    • Grade II atypical meningiomas are mid-grade tumours. This means the tumours have a higher chance of coming back after being removed. The subtypes include choroid and clear cell meningioma.
    • Grade III anaplastic meningiomas are malignant (cancerous). This means they are fast-growing tumours. The subtypes include papillary and rhabdoid meningioma.

Option D: Vestibular Schwannoma

  • Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumour that develops on the main (vestibular) nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain.

Major features of TSC

Minor features of TSC
  • Facial angiofibroma’s or forehead plaque
  • Non-traumatic ungual or periungual fibroma
  • Hypomelanotic macules (>3)
  • Shagreen patch
  • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
  • Cortical tuber
  • Subependymal nodule
  • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma, single or multiple
  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Renal angiomyolipomas
  • Multiple randomly distributed pits in dental enamel
  • Hamartomatous rectal polyps
  • Bone Cysts
  • Cerebral white matter radial migration lines
  • Gingival fibromas
  • Retinal achromic patch
  • "Confetti" skin lesions
  • Multiple renal cysts

questions.text: A 62-year-old male was found to have clinical features of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia(CML) on a peripheral blood smear. On detailed evaluation, the patient also had a T315I mutation in BCR-ABL. What is the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ponatinib

  • T315I mutation is a mutation in the critical BCR-ABL kinase in the ATP-binding pocket.
  • This prevents imatinib binding and hence leads to resistance to imatinib, nilotinib, bosutinib, and dasatinib.
  • The only drug effective for T315I mutation CML is ponatinib.
  • Otherwise, the drug if the choice for CML is imatinib.
  • The drug of choice in case of failure of > 2 Tyrosine kinase inhibitor is omacetaxine

Option A: Bosutinib

  • The drug of choice for imatinib-resistant CML is bosutinib

Option B: Tofacitinib

  • Tofacitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor; it works by blocking the action of the Janus kinase enzyme.
  • It treats moderately active rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ulcerative colitis, ankylosing spondylitis and polyarticular course juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Option D: Nilotinib

  • T315I mutation is a mutation in the critical BCR-ABL kinase in the ATP-binding pocket
  • This prevents imatinib binding and hence leads to resistance to nilotinib.

questions.text: 33 years male presented to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, there is mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation over the lips. Histopathological examination showed arborisation and pseudo invasion. Genetic analysis revealed that the gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. Colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Peutz – Jeghers syndrome

  • It is an autosomal dominant disease
  • The most com­mon location in the small intestine is the jejunum. Although, it may occur in the stomach or colon & with much lower frequency in the bladder and lungs
  • There is germline loss of function mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene.
  • There are multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps along with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.
  • Grossly the polyps are large and pedunculated with lobulated contour
  • On histopathology, they are characterised by the proliferation of the muscularis mucosae to form branching configurations covered by hypertrophic but normal mucosa

 

Option A: Familial adenomatous polyposis

  • FAP, also known as familial polyposis coli (FPC), is an autosomal dominant polyposis condition with different degrees of penetrance.
  • If left untreated, patients will grow hundreds to thousands of polyps throughout the colon and rectum.
  • Polyps commonly appear in the early adolescent years and, if left untreated, result in a nearly 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer by the age of forty.
  • Colectomy is required to significantly reduce the chance of developing colorectal cancer.
  • FAP is linked to various cancers, including gastric and duodenal cancers, hepatoblastomas, and desmoid tumours.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer

  • Lynch syndrome, commonly known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant trait and the most common cause of inherited colorectal cancer (CRC).
  • It is distinguished by a substantial family history of HNPCC-associated malignancies involving first-degree relatives spanning at least two generations and at least one case identified before age 50.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis

  • Neurofibromatosis is a neurocutaneous condition characterised by nerve system and skin malignancies.
  • Types 1 and 2 neurofibromatoses are the Von Recklinghausen's disease, is an autosomal dominant condition.
  • Type 1 neurofibromatosis is characterised by neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait macules, freckling, and optic gliomas. It is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is distinguished by bilateral vestibular schwannomas (VS) and meningiomas. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  • Clinical monitoring and medicinal intervention are the mainstays of treatment.

questions.text: Drug of choice in Dermatitis herpetiformis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dapsone

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is an immunologic skin disease characterized by itchy papulovesicular lesions of the extremities, knees, elbows and buttocks.
  • Majority of these patients have associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy that may be clinically unrecognized.
  • Two complementary methods can manage patients with DH: 
  1. Medications: Dapsone (50–200 mg/daily) shows remarkable improvement within 1-2 days
  2. Gluten-free diet

Other options

Option A: Prednisone 40 mg daily

  • Steroids are not indicated as the first-line treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • They can partially control the itching or burning sensation.
  • Dapsone is the primary treatment for DH.

Option B: Azithromycin

  • This option is incorrect

Option D : B and C - This option is incorrect

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complained of difficulty swallowing solids and liquids for the past 6 months associated with regurgitation of food. She has lost 4kg(9 lb) during this period. There is no history of serious illness. She is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. Cardiopulmonary examination shows an S3 gallop and a systolic murmur. On barium swallow, characteristic appearance is seen on X-ray as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most common complication in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Recurrent pulmonary infections.

Achalasia cardia:

  • Achalasia is a failure of the lower oesophageal sphincter (LES) to relax caused by progressive degeneration of the myenteric oesophageal plexus, resulting in dysfunctional peristalsis, increased resting pressure of the lower oesophageal sphincter (LES), and oesophageal dilation proximal to LES.
  • It is classified as either primary (idiopathic) or secondary (in the context of another disease). In patients with achalasia, the chief complaint is dysphagia of solids and liquids, although regurgitation, retrosternal pain, and weight loss may also occur. Upper endoscopy, oesophageal barium swallow, and oesophageal manometry play complementary roles in diagnosis. While upper endoscopy oesophageal barium swallow is often obtained initially, manometry usually confirms the diagnosis, and upper endoscopy is indicated to rule out an underlying malignancy.
  • Cough can be present in achalasia patients due to aspiration of food. The dilated oesophagus can also cause airway compression resulting in recurrent pulmonary infections.
  • In good surgical candidates, achalasia is usually treated with pneumatic dilation or myotomy. In most other cases, an injection of botulinum toxin is attempted. If these measures fail to provide relief, medical therapy (e.g., nifedipine) is indicated.

Option B: Stricture of the oesophagus.

  • Oesophageal stricture is the narrowing of the gastroesophageal junction that leads to dysphagia of solids.
  • It is not a complication of achalasia cardia.

Option C: Pleurisy.

  • Pleurisy is the inflammation of the pleura that lines the lungs. Most commonly caused by a viral infection but can also occur secondary to pneumonia, lung cancer, autoimmune disease, and pulmonary embolism. Typically causes sharp chest pain that is worse with inhalation.
  • It is not a complication of achalasia cardia.

Option D: Peptic ulcer.

  • Peptic ulcer disease is a break in the continuity of the mucosal lining of the stomach or duodenum. Most commonly due to an infection with Helicobacter pylori or NSAIDs.
  • This is not a complication of achalasia cardia.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient is being monitored in a coronary care unit for two days following myocardial infarction. Revascularization was done by primary percutaneous intervention. During monitoring, an ECG is done, which shows the following rhythm:



His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and his pulse is 27 per minute. Which of the following is best for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pacemaker

  • The ECG shows a ventricular rate of 27 beats per minute and an atrial rate of 60 beats per minute. The patient has developed a third-degree heart block and needs a pacemaker for the same.
  • Heart block or AV block occurs when there is an interruption or delay in conduction between the atria and ventricles.
  • In third-degree heart block, there is complete dissociation between the P waves (representing atrial depolarization) and QRS complexes (representing ventricular depolarization), as shown in the ECG above. The dissociation of the ventricles from the atria results in the development of an escape rhythm, which implies the generation of an ectopic pacemaker (usually located near the AV node or Bundle of His).
  • The development of third-degree heart block is pathological. Patients who suffer from myocardial infarction are at risk of AV blocks in the immediate days.
  • The management plan for a hemodynamically unstable patient with a third-degree heart block includes atropine, transvenous or transcutaneous pacing, and inotropic medication. 
  • Temporary transvenous pacing of the heart is done via an electrode that is placed through a venous access site into the right atrium and/or ventricle.

Option B: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine is used as an antiarrhythmic drug to treat ventricular tachyarrhythmias. It is class Ib antiarrhythmic. It is not used for bradyarrhythmias caused by heart block.

Option C: Amiodarone

  • Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug. It is most commonly used to treat ventricular tachyarrhythmias, not AV block.

Option D: Synchronized cardioversion

  • Synchronized cardioversion is a form of cardioversion in which a low-energy shock is delivered at or just after the peak of the R-wave of the QRS complex. It is used in the management of tachycardia with evidence of hemodynamic compromise.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has come to the hospital to undergo dialysis. His Hb was 5.5 mg/dl at the time of admission. Three units of blood transfusions were given as a part of resuscitation. After the third blood transfusion, within 8 hours, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension, SpO2 was reduced to 65%, CVP was 16cm water, and PCWP was 26mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO)

  • The presence of respiratory distress after blood transfusion, elevated CVP (normal is 8-12 mm Hg) and elevated PCWP (normal is 4-12 mm Hg) refers to transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).
  • Pulmonary symptoms develop due to pulmonary oedema from excessive  volume or circulatory overload from massive blood transfusion within a short period. 
  • Usually, 1 unit of blood takes 4 hours for transfusion.  
  • Chest x-ray shows pulmonary oedema, including Kerley B lines or interlobular septa thickening.
  • Management includes-
    • Immediate stopping of transfusion and other steps for suspected transfusion reactions.
    • Placing the patient in an upright position.
    • Oxygen and diuretics can be needed in some patients.
    • In serious cases, mechanical ventilation and treatment in the intensive care unit (ICU) may be required.

Option A: Allergic

  • Allergic reactions after blood transfusion can occur due to type 1 hypersensitivity against plasma proteins in transfused blood.
  • Urticaria, pruritus, and fever develop within minutes to 2-3 hours in this condition.

Option C: TRALI

  • The typical presentation of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia (O2 saturation <90% in room air), and hypotension.
  • PCWP in TRALI is ≤ 18 mm Hg.

Option D: FNHTR

  • Febrile non-haemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) commonly occurs due to HLA mismatched blood transfusion.
  • Cytokines and bacterial contamination during blood storage are also associated with FNHTR.
  • Within 3 hours of transfusion, fever is the predominant symptom in this condition. Headache, chills and flushing are usually present.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of the right-side face, arm weakness, and difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), his pulse is 76 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 3/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left. Non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown in the image below. Which is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intravenous reteplase

  • The patient is presenting with complaints of a stroke. Non-contrast CT of the head shows a hypodense area in the left middle cerebral artery indicating acute ischemic stroke.
  • Causes of ischemic stroke include:
  • Thrombotic (a thrombus forms at the site of the infarct)
  • Embolic (an embolus travels from other parts of the body)
  • Hypoxic (due to systemic hypotension or hypoxemia)
  • Management of ischemic stroke:
  • Thrombolytic therapy (e.g., reteplase, alteplase) if the ischemic stroke occurred within 4.5 hours with no risk of haemorrhage.
  • Mechanical thrombectomy is required if there is a large artery occlusion.
  • Treating the underlying cause of the ischemic stroke.
  • Lowering a patient's blood pressure will reduce cerebral perfusion and worsen the patient; hence antihypertensives are avoided.
  • Aspiration pneumonia and deep vein thrombosis should be prevented
  • Mannitol is given when features of raised intracranial pressure are present.

Option A: Intravenous nicardipine

  • IV nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker.
  • It is not required as blood pressure is not in the range of a hypertensive crisis.

Option B: Intravenous labetalol

  • Labetalol is a beta blocker drug used as an antihypertensive and antiarrhythmic.
  • IV labetalol is unsuitable as the patient's blood pressure is not in the hypertensive crisis range.

Option D: Intravenous mannitol

  • Mannitol is given when features of raised intracranial pressure are present. This patient shows no sign of raised intracranial pressure, i.e. nausea, vomiting, or headache. Hence, no need for mannitol in this patient

questions.text: A 64-year-old male unconscious patient was brought to the emergency department with a high-grade fever. The attendee recalls a history of double vision, dysphagia, and unsteady gait in the patient. The patient’s medical history is significant for hypertension for the past 13 years, well controlled by anti-hypertensives. On examination, his temperature was 102.8 degrees Fahrenheit, and his pupils were bilaterally pinpoint. What of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Brain stem lesion

  • Pyrexia, pinpoint pupils, and unconsciousness are characteristic of Brain stem lesions.
  • Pinpoint pupils (size 1 mm) are seen due to damage to descending sympathetic pathways in the brain stem.
  • Control of temperature occurs from the hypothalamus and lateral parabrachial nucleus, located at the junction of pons and midbrain
  • Large-volume intracerebral haemorrhages in pons expand to compress on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory centre leading to high-grade fever in these patients.

Option B: Cerebellar lesion

  • The following features are characteristics of cerebellar lesions:
  1. Intention tremors which increase as the limb reaches the target
  2. Dysdiadochokinesis - alternating hand, heel-knee-shin
  3. Dysmetria - overshooting in finger-nose test
  4. Ataxia of extremities - unsteadiness of gait towards the side of the lesion
  5. Pendular reflexes - legs swing back and forth when knee jerk elicited by rebound phenomena - outstretched arm swings excessively when displaced
  6. Disturbance of equilibrium manifests as unsteadiness in walking
  7. Nystagmus - in unilateral diseases, amplitude and rate increase when looking towards the diseased side; this is an inconsistent finding
  8. Ocular dysmetria - overshoot when eyes voluntarily fixate
  9. Scanning dysarthria - especially with explosive speech - an inconsistent finding
  10. Myoclonic jerks and choreiform motions if deep nuclei involved
  11. Abnormal head tilt - also in trochlear palsy, tonsillar herniation
  12. Rhythmic nodding tremor of head - side to side or 'to and fro' movement of head.
  • ​​​​​​​Therefore, this patient’s dysphagia, double vision, pyrexia, and pinpoint pupils are not consistent with a cerebellar lesion​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Thalamic lesions

  • Patients with lesions affecting the thalamus may present with variable sensory deficits, weakness, memory impairment, aphasia, hand tremor, and dystonia.

Option D: Internal capsule lesions

  • The internal capsule (IC), a white matter structure, is a unique location where a large number of the motor and sensory fibres travel to and from the cortex
  • Ischemic strokes secondary to blockage of the perforating arteries which supply the internal capsule are known as lacunar strokes
  • It causes pure motor strokes, ataxic hemiparesis, and clumsy hand dysarthria.
  • Therefore, this patient’s dysphagia, double vision, pyrexia, and pinpoint pupils are inconsistent with the internal capsule lesions.

questions.text: A woman comes to psychiatrist with a history of spending a lot of time washing her hands. She is distressed about it but says that she is not able to stop washing. This has started to affect her social life as well. What is the best mode of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder – Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by obsessions and/or compulsions that the person feels driven to perform according to specific rules in order to prevent an imagined dreaded event.

  • OCD is the fourth most common psychiatric disorder and is usually a chronic condition

Obsessions – Recurrent persistent thoughts, impulses, or images that enter the mind despite efforts to exclude them.

  • Patient tries to resist them

Compulsions – Behavior on mental acts that follow obsession & reduce anxiety temporarily

  • Both obsession and compulsion are ego-dystonic

Presentation

  • M/C presentation – Obsession of contamination followed by compulsions of washing
  • Pathological doubts
  • Intrusive thoughts
  • Symmetry – Compulsion of slowness
  • Hoarding
  • Depression is the most common comorbidity

Treatment

  • Best – Combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy
  • Pharmacotherapy – SSRI
  • PSYCHOTHERAPY - Brief cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) based on exposure with response prevention is the treatment of choice, and can be delivered in a variety of ways:
    • Brief individual CBT (up to 10 hours) with structured self-help materials
    • CBT by telephone
    • Group CBT

questions.text: A 22-year-old female is brought by her family members with complaints of low weight. According to the mother, the patient is extremely picky about what she eats, and the amount of food taken is quite low compared to others. In the interview, the patient says that she doesn't feel like eating, and although she realizes that she is losing weight which is not good, she just can't eat more. No body image disturbances are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Avoidant -restrictive food intake disorder

Avoidant-restrictive food intake disorder is a new diagnosis in ICD-11 and DSM-5. The following characterizes it-

Previously known as feeding disorder of infancy or early childhood.

  • Insufficient quantity or variety of food intake results in weight loss (or inability to gain weight) and nutritional deficiency. The patient may report a lack of interest in eating or may avoid food due to sensory characteristics (e.g., not liking the smell or taste of food)
  • There is no disturbance of body image (This characteristic helps differentiate Anorexia nervosa, a restrictive type, from Avoidant -restrictive food intake disorder.

Option A: Anorexia nervosa, binge eating type

  • Episodes of binge eating are defined as consuming an amount of food in a discrete period (e.g., two hours) that is larger than what most people would eat in a similar amount of time under similar circumstances.
  • During episodes, patients feel they lack control over eating (e.g., they feel they cannot stop eating or control the amount or what they eat).

​​​​​​​Option B: Anorexia nervosa, restrictive type

  • Patients with avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder are often underweight.
  • In addition, bone mineral density is often diminished

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option D: Bulimia nervosa

  • Bulimia nervosa is characterized by recurrent binge eating, followed by compulsive behavior to counteract weight gain:
  • Self-induced vomiting after binge-eating (most frequent)
  • Laxative abuse
  • Transient starvation periods
  • Both occur at least once a week over 3 months

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the psychiatrist by his parents with complaints of not following the rules of the school and arguing with teachers and fellow students. The parents report that he misbehaves with them too and at times tries to provoke them. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Oppositional defiance disorder (ODD) is defined as a recurrent pattern of negativistic, defiant, disobedient, and hostile behavior towards authority figures. It is one of the most common psychiatric disorders of childhood, and whilst a risk factor for the more serious conduct disorder, the majority do not progress to more serious psychopathology or psychopathy.

Conduct disorder can be considered a more severe form of the oppositional defiant disorder. The child also shows symptoms that are direct violation of the rights of others and societal rules and norms are broken.

  • Bullying or hitting other children.
  • Stealing
  • Putting things on fire.
  • Cruelty towards animals
  • Frequent lying
  • Running away from the house

How to remember :

Oppositional act against Opposing force.

Conduct indicates Character. He/she may harm or cause violence to others.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient department due to a psychiatric disorder. She has had persistent symptoms for the past 9 months. Her symptoms have not improved with 5 trials of medications. The clinician suggests the brain stimulation method (shown below) for her:



The brain stimulation method is used for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Option A: Depression

  • Brain stimulation methods used for major depressive disorder include:
    • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)
    • Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS)
    • Transcranial direct current stimulation
    • Cranial electrical stimulation
    • Magnetic seizure therapy
    • Vagus nerve stimulation
    • Implanted cortical stimulation
  • The image is illustrative of vagal nerve stimulation (VNS), which is used for the treatment of depression.
  • VNS is an approved adjunctive long-term treatment for chronic or recurrent depressive adults with a major depressive episode who have not had a satisfactory response to four or more adequate antidepressant trials.
  • VNS involves the surgical implantation of a pulse generator in the chest connected to a stimulating electrode, which is attached to the vagus nerve in the neck.
  • VNS stimulates vagal nerve fibres, which alter serotonergic activity in the cortical and limbic structures.
  • Persistent stimulation of the vagal afferents acts as an anticonvulsant as well. It is an effective treatment for refractory epilepsy.
  • VNS is well tolerated. The adverse effects include alteration to voice, neck discomfort, cough, dysphagia, and shortness of breath, with vocal changes potentially persisting over time.

Option B: Schizophrenia​​​​​​​

  • The image above shows the vagus nerve stimulation method.
  • VNS is an FDA-approved treatment for depression and epilepsy.
  • It is not used to treat schizophrenia.
  • Schizophrenia is treated with antipsychotics medically.

Option C: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

  • The image above shows VNS.
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder is not an indication of VNS.
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder is treated medically with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and tricyclic antidepressants.

Option D: Anxiety

  • The image above shows VNS.
  • Anxiety is treated medically with benzodiazepines.
  • Anxiety is not an indication of VNS.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female diagnosed with bipolar disorder and on treatment for 6 years came to your clinic with complaints of greenish nipple discharge associated with pain in both breasts. A physical examination revealed bilateral nipple retraction with little nipple discharge. Histopathology revealed dilated ducts in both breasts. Which is the best step in managing this patient’s underlying breast condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hadfield's operation

  • The above-given clinical scenario is a classical presentation of Duct ectasia.
  • Mammary duct ectasia is a benign (non-cancerous) breast disorder that develops when the walls of a milk duct in the breast thicken and widen. This may result in fluid accumulation and duct blockage.

  • Women who are approaching menopause are more likely to experience it.
  • The treatment of choice for duct ectasia is Hadfield's operation.
    • HADFIELD's OPERATION: A periareolar incision is made, and a cone of tissue is removed with its apex just deep to the surface of the nipple and its base on the pectoral fascia.

Option A: Simple mastectomy

  • It is used to remove breast tissue in breast cancer.

Option B:  Microdochectomy

  • A microdochectomy is a surgical procedure in which a single duct is removed from the nipple-areolar complex. It is usually undertaken when a patient has nipple discharge from a single duct.
  • In duct ectasia, discharge is from multiple ducts.

Option C: Lobectomy

  • It is a type of conservative breast surgery. A lobectomy removes only the cancerous part of the breast while leaving the rest of the breast intact.
  • It is not used for duct ectasia.

questions.text: A 22-day-old girl is brought to the outpatient department due to persistent jaundice after birth. 10 days ago, her parents noticed yellow discoloration of her eyes and skin that has been progressively increasing for the last 3 days. She was born to a 24-year-old primigravida woman via normal vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was unremarkable. Further query reveals that her stools are pale in color. The patient is breastfed exclusively and has been feeding well. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, heart rate is 120/min, and respiratory rate is 26/min. Capillary refill is <2 seconds. Examination reveals a diffusely jaundiced infant. Abdominal examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen with hepatomegaly. The metabolic screen is normal, ultrasound demonstrates an absent gallbladder, and a technetium-99m iminodiacetic acid scan shows radionuclide that is concentrated in the liver but not excreted into the intestine. Which of the following is true regarding the presentation of this patient?

choices.text: This condition is usually managed non-operatively.
Surgery should be performed within 60 days of life.
Most of these patients will not require transplantation if left untreated.

questions.solution:
Option B: Surgery should be performed within 60 days of life.

  • This patient’s presentation includes persistent jaundice, yellow discolouration of her eyes and skin, mildly distended abdomen with hepatomegaly, an absent gallbladder, and a technetium-99m iminodiacetic acid scan shows radionuclide that is concentrated in the liver but not excreted into the intestine is consistent with biliary atresia.

Biliary atresia:

  • This patient has biliary atresia, a rare disease characterized by fibro-proliferative obliteration of the extrahepatic bile duct, which progresses toward hepatic fibrosis, cirrhosis, and end-stage liver failure.
  • Clinical features: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin) and pale stools that start in the first 4-8 weeks of life are the main signs of the disease. Other features include direct hyperbilirubinemia, dark urine, and hepatomegaly.
  • Diagnosis:

1. An ultrasound scan is the initial investigation which may show an absent or abnormal gallbladder and/or common bile duct.

2. Liver biopsy may indicate intrahepatic bile duct proliferation along with portal tract fibrosis.

3. Intraoperative cholangiography is a gold standard test which may show biliary obstruction.

  • Management:
  1. Surgical hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure): The Kasai procedure involves removing the blocked bile ducts and gallbladder and replacing them with a segment of a child’s own small intestine. This segment of the intestine is sewn to the liver and functions as a new extrahepatic bile duct system. It is typically performed within the first 60 days (2 months) of life. Infants treated prior to 60 days of life are less likely to achieve successful biliary drainage than older infants.
  2. Liver transplantation

This image shows the Kasai procedure.

Option A: This condition is usually managed non-operatively

  • Biliary atresia must be treated surgically with the Kasai procedure. Untreated cases may need liver transplantation; therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option C: Cystoenterostomy provides adequate biliary drainage.

  • Cystoenterostomy is the backup treatment for managing pancreatic pseudocysts after all other less invasive manoeuvres fail. The first-line therapy for symptomatic acute pancreatic pseudocysts should be endoscopic intervention using transenteric or transpapillary drainage.
  • It is not a treatment option for biliary atresia.

Option D: Most of these patients will not require transplantation if left untreated.

  • Early surgical intervention to treat biliary atresia is critical to prevent irreversible liver damage. Once the liver fails, a liver transplant is mostly required in untreated patients.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department 45 minutes after sustaining a blow to the right side of his head when his motorcycle slid on gravel and flipped on the side of the road. After the accident, the patient noted burning pain in his neck. On examination, complete quadriplegia is noted with a sensory level at C4.The patient has not passed urine since then, and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: The doctor should order a cervical x-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.
The patient should not be shifted and a portable x-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest x-ray.
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical x-ray-AP and lateral view without any cervical support

questions.solution:
• In a trauma patient, cervical stabilization is the first step in management along with the airway.
  • A cross-table lateral cervical spine x- ray is considered in the same trolley itself without shifting the patient.
  • A surgeon should accompany the patient if needed, so that patient can be transferred immediately to OT if any hemodynamic instability occurs.
  • The spine should always be immobilized assuming a spine injury until proven otherwise
  • Blunt trauma causes cord injury through direct impingement or indirect compression due to vertebral fracture or dislocation
  • Penetrating trauma causes direct cord laceration or indirectly through ischemia or fracture

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with complaints of dyspnea. He is a lifetime smoker. His pulse is 99/min, and his blood pressure is 95/66 mmHg. Examination shows swelling and redness of the face and neck. There is distention of the superficial veins of his neck and upper thorax. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest x-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step in establishing a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.solution:
Option B: CT thorax

  • SUPERIOR VENA CAVA (SVC) SYNDROME:
    • A condition caused by obstruction of blood flow in the superior vena cava (e.g., by a thrombus or external compression). This impairs venous backflow to the right atrium and results in upper venous congestion.
    • Features include a feeling of fullness in the head, dyspnea, oedema of the upper extremities, and distention of the superficial veins of the chest, face, and upper extremities.
    • The Most common cause is Lung cancer (small cell & squamous cell carcinoma), along with lymphoma and metastatic tumours responsible for more than 90% of all SVC syndrome.
    • In young adults, malignant lymphoma is the leading cause of SVC syndrome.
    • CLINICAL FEATURES:
      • Hemodynamic symptoms: Oedema of the upper extremities and face (facial plethora), the prominent venous pattern on the chest, face, and upper extremities, Jugular venous distension, Orthostatic hypotension, Syncope, and Renal failure.
      • Symptoms and signs of congestion of the neck: Dyspnea, Cough and hoarseness, Stridor, and Dysphagia
      • Neurological symptoms: Headache, Dizziness, Confusion and mental obtundation, and Visual impairmen
    • ​​​​​​​DIAGNOSIS:
      • Unstable or severely symptomatic patients: invasive venography with or without stent placement (gold standard)
      • Stable patients: 
        • ​​​​​​​CT chest with CT venography: modality of choice for most patients
        • Doppler ultrasound: initial investigation for suspected catheter-associated thrombosis

 

 

 

Option A: Total blood count with peripheral smear

  • The complete blood count is a laboratory test that measures the following:
    • Red blood cell (RBC) count
    • Haemoglobin (Hb)
    • Hematocrit (Hct)
    • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
    • Mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH)
    • Mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
    • White blood cell (WBC) count
    • Platelet count
      • A peripheral blood smear is a diagnostic test examining peripheral blood under a microscope. It can diagnose conditions that cause abnormal counts or morphology of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
      • These tests do not have a diagnostic value for SVC syndrome.

 

Option C: Start cyclophosphamide

  • Cyclophosphamide is used in the treatment of the following malignancies:
    • Solid tumours (e.g., breast cancer, ovarian cancer, small cell lung cancer)
    • Leukemias
    • Lymphomas
    • Multiple myeloma
  • However, in the case of SVC syndrome chest CT scan is necessary to rule out the cause of obstruction causing SVC syndrome.

Option D: Urgent referral to treatment​​​​​​​

  • In stable patients of SVC syndrome, the investigation of choice is a chest CT scan used to diagnose the cause of obstruction, and after the cause of SVC obstruction is known, treatment begins.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to the hospital feeling unwell for the previous few weeks, mainly complaining of muscle weakness. He denied any fevers or rigors and any change in bowel habits or vomiting. He did not report any memory or mood problems. Physical examination was remarkable for profound lethargy but otherwise, he was fully orientated, stable hemodynamically, without any significant clinical signs, including no focal neurological deficit. Blood tests on admission were remarkable for severe metabolic acidosis (pH 7.20, HCO3 11.3, base excess −17 with normal lactate of 1). From the given data all of the following can be considered as a differential diagnosis for this patient except?
questions.solution:
Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis causes hypokalemia and hypochloremia metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

CAUSES OF NON-ANION GAP ACIDOSIS

Mnemonic- USED CARP

U-Ureteraldiversion

S-Small Bowel Fistula

E-Extra Chloride (ammonium chloride, Calcium Chloride)

D-Diarrhea

C-Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Acetazolamide, Mefenamic acid)

A-Adrenal Insufficiency

R-Renal Tubular Acidosis

P-Pancreatic Fistula

CAUSES OF HIGH ANION GAP ACIDOSIS

Mnemonic- MUD PILERS

M Methanol, Metformin

U Uremia

D Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), Alcoholic Ketoacidosis or Starvation Ketosis

P Paraldehyde, Phenformin

I Iron, Isopropyl Alcohol, and Isoniazid (due to Seizures)

L Lactic Acidosis

E Ethylene Glycol, Ethyl Alcohol

R Rhabdomyolysis

S Salicylates (do not miss Chronic Salicylate Poisoning)

Option D: Pyloric stenosis can not be the differential diagnosis of this patient. Because it can cause hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

All other options are the differential diagnosis of this patient.

Learning objective:

In this question, the patient has a severe metabolic acidosis. Options must be the reason for that metabolic acidosis to consider it as the differential diagnosis of this patient. Options like renal failure, ureterosigmoidostomy, and pancreatic or biliary fistula can cause metabolic acidosis. But hypertrophic pyloric stenosis causes hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. So it is the odd one out to choose. we must know which conditions can cause metabolic acidosis and alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for the survival of the skin graft within 48 hours of the grafting?
questions.solution:
Option B: Plasma imbibition

  • This patient with a chemical burn resulting in an area of white, leathery skin and tissue necrosis encircling the right upper extremity just proximal to the elbow area needs a skin graft to prevent future complications.
  • A skin graft is characterised by a patch of skin that is surgically removed from one area of the body (donor site) and transplanted to another area where there is tissue loss (recipient site).
  • Skin grafts help repair a wound in patients with severe burns, infections, or wounds
  • It is also used in those patients who have had skin removed because of skin cancer.
  • The skin grafts cover up wounds and facilitate a faster healing process.
  • The stages of skin graft healing are mentioned in the following:
    • Imbibition
    • Inosculation
    • Revascularization
  • Imbibition: This is the first stage of the process of skin graft healing process. It occurs 24 to 48 hours after the procedure.
  • The imbibition stage is characterised by forming a thin film of fibrin and plasma. This film separates the skin graft from the underlying wound bed.
  • This film is essential and provides a moist environment. This thin film of fibrin and plasma is crucial for the survival of the graft.
  • Inosculation: This is the second stage of the process of skin graft healing and occurs around 48 hours after the procedure when a fine vascular network begins to form within the fibrin layer.
  • The new capillaries border the surface of the dermis, allowing the transfer of nutrients and oxygen.
  • Revascularization is the third and last stage of the skin graft healing process. During this process, new blood vessels invade the skin graft and restore the skin to its natural appearance.
  • The process of skin graft healing completes in a period of up to one week and is illustrated in the image below:

 

Option A: Amount of saline in graft

  • This is an incorrect option, as the amount of saline is not primarily responsible for the survival of the skin graft.

Option C: Inosculation

  • This is an incorrect option, as inosculation takes place around 48 hours after the procedure when a fine vascular network forms within the fibrin layer.

Option D: Revascularization

  • This is an incorrect option, as revascularization is the third and last stage of the skin graft healing process and does not occur within the initial 48 hours of grafting.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic complaining of a large erythematous skin pocket on his sacrum and left hip. He has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, paraplegia, and steroid-induced diabetes, diagnosed two years ago. Examination reveals large 3-4 cm pressure sores, as shown in the image below. Which would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Surgery is the only modality of the treatment
A fasciocutaneous flap should be used
Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies.
Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement.

questions.solution:
Option D: Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement

  • Pressure ulcers are also known as pressure sores, bed sores, trophic ulcers, or decubitus ulcers.
  • It results from injuries to the skin and underlying tissue from prolonged pressure on the skin.
  • The constant pressure on the skin causes tissue ischemia and cessation of nutrients and oxygen supply to the tissue, which eventually results in tissue necrosis.
  • It is more common in individuals with decreased immobility.
  • The severity of pressure ulcers is divided into four grades:
    • Grade 1: intact skin with non-blanchable erythema of a localized area.
    • Grade 2: partial thickness loss of dermis presents as a shallow open ulcer. The wound is pink. It may be associated with zero-sanguineous or serum-filled fluid.
    • Grade 3: full-thickness tissue loss. Subcutaneous fat may be exposed, but the bone, tendon, and muscle are not exposed.
    • Grade 4: full thickness tissue loss associated with bone, tendon, or muscle loss. Slough and eschar may be present.

  • Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores.

    • Good skin care with special pressure dispersion cushions or foams and use of low air-loss & air- fluidized beds.
    • Bed-bound patients should be turned at least every 2 hours.
    • Patients who use wheelchairs should lift themselves off their seats for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

  • Conservative therapy involves cleaning, debridement, and antibiotics only used for infected pressure ulcers.

  • Flap surgery is used for larger and more complicated pressure ulcers. Large skin flaps muscle & intact sensory innervations are preferred (Example: Extensor fascia lata with the lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh).

  • Grade 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement.

Option A: Surgery is the only modality of the treatment

  • Surgical treatment is reserved for patients who do not respond to conservative treatment.
  • The main goal is to prevent a pressure ulcer by decreasing the pressure on the affected side.

Option B: Fasciocutaneous flap should be used

  • Musculocutaneous flaps are the first choice in the surgical repair of pressure sores.
  • Musculocutaneous flaps are as good as fasciocutaneous flaps in reconstructing pressure sores.

Option C: Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies

  • There is limited evidence that any specific diet or herbal remedies can treat pressure sores. Herbal remedies may prevent itchiness and redness.
  • More advanced sores require medical management.
