questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with the complaint of progressively worsening ulcers in the fingertips of both hands and feet for 4 years, along with intermittent claudication of the feet whenever he is walking. After taking history, he told the doctor that he had "migratory superficial thrombophlebitis." He is a  20-pack-year smoker who is not a diabetic; his cholesterol levels are normal according to him, and his ECG findings were normal. What would be the best way for this patient to arrest the development of his disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Smoking cessation

  • This clinical feature is suggestive of Buerger’s disease, and the only measure that can stop disease progression is the cessation of smoking
  • Buerger’s disease also known as thromboangiitis obliterans, is characterized by occlusive disease of small and medium-sized arteries.
  • It is associated with superficial thrombophlebitis and Raynaud’s phenomenon in a smoker of usually less than 30 years of age.
  • The serious complication is amputation if the disease is not controlled.

Option A: Aspirin

  • It is a platelet aggregation inhibitor, usually beneficial in patients with atheromatous disease.
  • It has very little to no role in thromboangiitis obliterans.

Option B: Good glycaemic control

  • It is useful in patients with a disease due to increased blood sugar levels.
  • Because Buerger’s disease has no diabetic component, glycaemic control is useless in these patients.

Option C: Blood cholesterol control

  • It is useful in patients suffering from a disease due to the formation of atheromatous plaques in the vessel walls, resulting from increased cholesterol levels.
  • Cholesterol levels are normal in Buerger’s disease, so they don’t have a role in disease cessation.

questions.text: A 25-year old male presents to ER following a road traffic accident sustaining injuries to the lower abdomen. On examination, there is a pelvic hematoma and fracture. Physical examination shows a palpable bladder, and blood at the external urethral meatus. A digital rectal examination shows impalpable prostate. On the basis of examination, which of the following is true about the patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: The anterior urethra is the most likely place of injury
Retrograde urethrography should be done immediately
A Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the RGU is normal
Rectal examination may not reveal a large pelvic hematoma

questions.solution:
Option C: Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the RGU is normal

  • In this case, blood at the urethral meatus + pelvic hematoma and high-lying prostate are the indications of injuries to the posterior urethra.
  • Posterior urethra injuries occur with pelvic fractures, mostly in case of motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Retention of urine 
    • Blood at the urethral meatus
    • Pelvic hematoma and High lying prostate
    • Pie In sky appearance on intravenous pyelogram (IVP) in Membranous urethral injury.
  • The presence of blood at the external urethral meatus indicates that Immediate urethrography should be done. The urethra must be imaged first before any kind of urethral instrumentation.
  • Once the patient has been stabilized, the correct placement of the Foley balloon catheter inside the bladder must be checked.
  • Retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is a diagnostic imaging test performed most commonly in male patients to diagnose urethral injuries.
  • If the blood at the urethral meatus is seen after urethral injury, the RGU test is considered to determine the degree and nature of the injury and for operative planning for urethral reconstruction.
  • To perform RUG patient must be stabilized first.
  • If blunt trauma has injured the urethra of the patient and an RGU is performed, urine leakage is often seen.
  • In the case of normal RGU, both the anterior and posterior urethra should be filled with contrast after proper injection of radiopaque contrast, which is seen to jet into the bladder neck.
  • A 16-F or 18-F Foley catheter is flushed into the meatus to remove air bubbles.
  • It contains radiopaque contrast.
  • When a Foley catheter is placed inside the meatus, the Foley catheter balloon reaches the fossa navicularis.

 

Anterior urethral Injuries:

  • The site of injury is the bulbar part of the urethra
  • External blow/kick, Straddle/manhole injuries are the common causes.
  • Retrograde urethrogram (RGU) should always be the first investigation of suspected urethral injury.
  • SPC (suprapubic cystostomy) is considered to be followed by delayed repair within three months

Option A: Anterior urethra is the most likely place of injury

  • Blunt or penetrating injuries with bulbar urethra results in Anterior urethral injuries.
  • The most common site affected by anterior injuries is the bulbar urethra.
  • It can cause due to gunshot wounds or self-inflicted sexual misadventures

​​​​​​​Option B: Retrograde urethrography should be done immediately

  • Retrograde urethrogram (RUG) is the diagnostic imaging test of choice in the case of suspected urethral injury.
  • It determines the nature of the urethral injury.
  • As the patient's position is maintained obliquely at 45 º and the bottom leg flexed at 90° at the knee while the top leg is kept straight, It is recommended to do RUG after the stabilization of a patient

​​​​​​​Option D: Rectal examination may not reveal a large pelvic hematoma

  • High-speed motor vehicle accidents and fall from height are the most common mechanism of injury that results in pelvic fracture and urethral injuries.
  • A digital rectal exam reveals pelvic hematoma and obscures the prostate to palpation.
  • Pie-in-the-sky appearance is seen in this case on cystography, which is a floating bladder high in the pelvis due to a large pelvic hematoma

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency departmentwith a complaint of blood in urine for last one hour. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/60mmHg, pulse rate is 110/minute, and fullness in his left loin. On history, he reports that on the same day in the morning, he played rugby. After that, he passed frank blood in his urine. He also feels mild discomfort in his left loin. What is the diagnosis related to the above-mentioned patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• Isotope renography is the best test to establish that dilatation is caused by obstruction.
  • It would also determine the percentage function of the kidney.

  • A procedure to preserve the kidney is carried out when a renogram shows that there is more than 20 percent of renal function.
  • The operation of choice is Anderson–Hynes pyeloplasty, a procedure which is now being carried out laparoscopically.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of bruises all over the body and frequent episodes of bleeding from the gum and nose. Upon examination, she had multiple petechiae all over her body. Investigation shows isolated thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 8000/mm3 and red blood cells in urine examination, suggesting hematuria. All other diagnostic evaluations are normal. A splenectomy was done in this patient to tide over the acute crisis of uncontrollable:
questions.solution:
Option A: ITP

  • The patient has multiple petechiae with a bleeding tendency due to a low platelet count. Diagnostic tools show no definitive cause, so a diagnosis of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura is suggested.
  • A low platelet count characterizes ITP despite normal bone marrow and the absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia.
  • Low platelet count results from the development of antibodies to specific platelet membrane glycoproteins
  • Two types: Acute (in children and spontaneous resolution within two months) and Chronic (in adults and persists longer than six months)
  • Splenectomy is recommended if
    • The patient has two relapses on steroid therapy
    • Platelet count remains low
    • ITP persists for more than 6-9 months
  • Urgent splenectomy and aggressive medical therapy may play a role in the rare circumstance of severe, life-threatening bleeding in children and adults.
  • Spontaneous remission in 75% of pediatric cases. A short course of corticosteroids in both adults and children is usually followed by recovery.

Option B: TTP

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a microangiopathy which is caused by decreased activity of the von Willebrand factor-cleaving protease ADAMTS13
  • There is an increased LDH, bilirubin levels and sometimes white cell count. A blood smear shows thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anaemia.

Option C: HUS

  • HUS is a hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  • It is a triad of thrombocytopenia, acute renal impairment, and microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia.

Option D: Bone marrow suppression

  • Bone marrow suppression presents with pancytopenia, and no suggestive history is present.
  • Bone marrow biopsy should show a decrease in all cell lines.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is diagnosed with a carcinoma stomach. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass measuring 4x4 cm in the antrum. The mass indicates celiac node and right gastric node involvement. Which of the following is the preferred management option?
questions.solution:
Option B: Subtotal gastrectomy

  • The treatment varies according to the stage and location of cancer.
    • If the tumour is located in the proximal one-third of the stomach, the recommended treatment is a total gastrectomy with D2 lymphadenectomy.
    • If the tumour is located in the body as well as the antrum, the recommended treatment is a subtotal gastrectomy in conjunction with D2 lymphadenectomy.
  • The treatment for the intestinal variant of stomach carcinoma, as well as the diffuse type of stomach carcinoma, is the same.
  • With one notable exception, a total gastrectomy and D2 lymphadenectomy will be performed in cases where the cancer is diffuse and affects the distal one-third of the stomach.

 

 

 

 

Option A: Total gastrectomy

  • Total gastrectomy is not the treatment of choice for this case.

Option C: Palliative

  • Palliative surgery is not the treatment of choice for this case.

Option D: Chemotherapy

  • Chemotherapy is not the treatment of choice for this case.

questions.text: Which of the following best associates with the clinical condition that includes abdominal distension, diffuse abdominal pain, and growth of E. coli on the ascitic fluid culture medium of a patient with cirrhosis?

choices.text: Multiple organisms are isolated from ascitic fluid
3rd Generation cephalosporin is the antibiotic of choice

questions.solution:
Option D: 3rd generation cephalosporin is the antibiotic of choice

  • The given scenario is a classic case of Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) characterized by fever and abdominal pain in ascites.
    • The common culprit microorganisms include  E. coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Antibiotics must be administered just after an ascitic fluid sample has been taken for the culture and sensitivity.
    • Anbibiotics for SBP is indicated only when the patients with ascites have one of the following.
      • Temperature greater than 37.8°C (100°F)
      • Abdominal pain and tenderness
      • Altered mental status
      • Ascitic fluid polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥250 cells/microL
    • Third-generation cephalosporins are the preferred antibiotics for patients having a CLID-SOFA score < 7.
      • For patients with CLIF-SOFA scores equal to or greater than 7, IV Carbepenems are the preferred antibiotics.

 

Option A: Ascitic fluid neutrophil count is > 350 /cumm

  • The diagnostic criterion is an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of > 250/cubic millimetre.

 

Option B: Bowel perforation should be present

  • Bowel perforation is part of the diagnostic criterion of the acute abdomen, and it causes moderate to severe abdominal pain, not a dull one. It is often associated with hemodynamic instability and can cause secondary peritonitis.

Option C: Multiple organisms are isolated from ascitic fluid

  • Multiple enteric organisms are present in peritoneal lavage in the settings of bowel perforation. 
    • SBP is caused by one of many microorganisms, including
      • Escherichia coli
      • Klebsiella pneumoniae
      • Streptococcus pneumoniae
      • Enterobacteriaceae
      • Staphylococcus
      • Pseudomonas
      • Other streptococcal species

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a family history of hyperparathyroidism was brought to the OPD with complaints of loin pain. On evaluation, multiple renal calculi were noted in both kidneys. Serum calcium, PTH, and prolactin are elevated. Which of the following organs was most likely affected first in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Parathyroid

  • In the clinical scenario mentioned above, the patient has MEN1 syndrome, and the parathyroid gland is the first organ affected by this syndrome.
  • MEN1 (Wermer’s syndrome):
    • Due to germline mutation in the MEN1 gene located in chromosome 11 that encodes menin
    • Autosomal dominant hereditary cancer syndrome
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Earliest and most common manifestation (develops in 80% to 100% of patients by 40 years)
      • Four-gland hyperplasia with asymmetrical enlargement of the parathyroid gland is usually found
      • It is usually benign
      • Hypercalcemia is usually the first biochemical abnormality detected in patients with MEN1
      • Treatment - Total parathyroidectomy with heterotopic intramuscular autotransplantation of parathyroid tissue grafts into skeletal muscle or subtotal parathyroidectomy, leaving a vascularized remnant of one parathyroid gland in situ in the neck
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours
      • Second most frequent of MEN1
      • Associated with risk of malignant progression
      • PETs are the most common cause of syndrome-associated death
      • Most common functional neuroendocrine tumors associated with MEN1 are Gastrinomas (50%) (multiple and metastatic at diagnosis) followed by Insulinomas (10% to 15%)
      • Treatment involves resection to prevent liver metastasis and progression of the disease
    • Pituitary adenomas
      • Most common - Prolactinomas (10% to 50%)​​​​​​​

Option B: Thyroid

  • The Thyroid gland remains unaffected in MEN1 syndrome.

Option C: Adrenal gland

  • Adrenal glands are not affected in MEN1 syndrome. Pheochromocytomas are seen in MEN2.

Option D: Testis

  • Testes are not affected in patients with MEN1 syndrome.

questions.text: A 37-year-old Indian man who had recently moved to Taiwan presented with right upper quadrant pain and intermittent low-grade fever. Both sonography and computed tomography demonstrated a cystic lesion with vesicles at its periphery in segments 6 and 7 of the liver. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hydatid cyst

  • An Infection causes a hydatid cyst by the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus in its larval or cyst stage.
  • Dog intestine (definitive host) → Ova ingested by humans (accidental intermediate host) → Portal vein → Liver
  • The Common lobe is the Right lobe (anterior inferior of inferior posterior segments).
  • The Symptoms are Dull right upper quadrant pain and Abdominal distension.
  • Eosinophilia is present in 30% of patients.
  • The Complications are Infection may involve other organs, and rupture (allergic or anaphylactic reaction).
  • Diagnosis includes Serology (ELISA test for echinococcal antigens).
  • ELISA test for echinococcal antigens is positive in 85% of patients.
  • The test will be negative if the cyst has not leaked or does not contain scolices or if the parasite is no longer viable.
  • Ultrasound and CT scan show the following:
    • Well-defined hypodense lesions with a distinct wall
    • Budding signs of the cyst membrane contain free-floating hyperechoic hydatid sand
    • Multiloculated cyst
    • Floating membrane
    • Rosette's appearance (when daughter cysts are present)
    • Ring-like calcification of the pericytes
    • A calcified cyst ( dead or inactive cyst)

 

Option A: Polycystic liver disease

  • Ultrasound imaging will show hyperechoic areas in a subcapsular portion of the liver.
  • CT scan and MRI shows hyperdense well-circumscribed lesions.

Option B: Amoebic liver abscess

  • The amoebic liver abscess typically has high serum transaminase, Leukocytosis, and elevated Alkaline phosphatase.
  • On imaging, the amoebic liver abscess will be found in the right lobe.
  • Ultrasound shows hypoechoic mass.
  • CT Scan shows low-density mass with the peripheral enhancing rim.

Option D: Pyogenic liver abscess

  • Liver abscess presents with a high fever.
  • On imaging, the pyogenic liver disease shows a Centrally non-enhancing abscess cavity with an enhancing capsule.
  • This is usually a contrast enhancement pattern.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with acute pancreatitis complaints of recurrent episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and hemoglobin of 5.8 gm/dL, requiring transfusions of red cell units. Gastroscopy showed diffuse fundal gastric varices but no esophageal varices. A CT scan showed liquefactive necrosis of pancreatic parenchyma and splenomegaly with diffuse varices around the gastrosplenic and gastrohepatic ligament. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Splenectomy

  • Acute pancreatitis causes splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery.
  • This aneurysm causes splenomegaly.
  • Splenomegaly causes gastric varices, mainly along the greater curvature of the stomach and fundus.
  • Left-sided portal hypertension is also called SINISTRAL hypertension.
  • The treatment of choice is Splenectomy.

Option B: Portocaval shunt

  • The portocaval shunt is an abnormal vein connecting the blood supply from the intestine to the vein that returns blood to the heart, bypassing the liver called shunting.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient has a problem with the spleen, so Splenectomy should be done.

Option C: Splenorenal shunt

  • This is the surgical process in which the splenic vein is detached from the portal vein and reattached to the left kidney vein, called the renal vein, to relieve pressure, causing a portal system shunt.

Option D: None of the above

  • Splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery cause splenomegaly due to acute pancreatitis, so splenectomy should be done.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department after he sustained a burn injury to his right arm when his hand was trapped in a steam-rolling machine for making carpets under high temperatures. He has severe burn in his right arm. On examination, a third-degree circumferential burn wound is noted in the right arm and forearm. Which of the following has to be closely monitored in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Peripheral pulse and circulation

  • This patient has circumferential burns to his right arm and forearm, which can lead to compartment syndrome.
  • Circulation to the peripheries should be assessed as compartment syndrome may develop.
  • Full-thickness burns with a rigid eschar can form a tourniquet effect as oedema progresses, leading to compromised venous outflow and, eventually, arterial inflow.
  • Most common in circumferential extremity burns.
  • Warning signs of impending compartment syndrome may include
    • Paresthesias
    • Pain
    • Decreased capillary refill
    • Progression to loss of distal pulses
  • Fasciotomy is done to relieve pressure.

Option A: Blood gases

  • Blood gases can detect inhalational injury. However, this patient’s circumferential burn makes monitoring of peripheral pulses necessary.

Option B: Carboxyhemoglobin level

  • Carboxyhemoglobin level is measured in carbon monoxide poisoning as oxygen saturation may falsely appear normal on pulse oximetry.

Option C: Myoglobinuria

  • Myoglobinuria is a sign of rhabdomyolysis, commonly occurring in electrical burns and crush injuries.
  • In thermal burns, rhabdomyolysis is not common.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the OPD for an annual physical examination. After noting a PSA level of 12.3 ng/dL, you refer him to a urologist for further workup. Following a prostatic biopsy, the results show the presence of adenocarcinoma of the prostate, which is given a Gleason score of 8. The Gleason score is a measurement of:

choices.text: The extent of cancer within the prostate gland
The extent of the cancer within the abdomen
The likelihood that the cancer will grow and spread
The number of cancer cells expressing prostate specific antigen (PSA) on their cell surface

questions.solution:
• Gleason’s Grading and Scoring System and Gleason’s Grade Group

    Gleason’s GradeRange from 1-5

    1. Most differentiated cells

    5. Most undifferentiated cells

    Cribriform Pattern --GRADE 4

    Comedo Pattern -- GRADE 5

    Gleason’s score Range from 2- 1

  • Gleason grading system: Developed to provide a measurement of the potential for prostate cancer to grow and spread

Option A: False statement

Gleason's score has no relation to the extent of cancer within the prostate gland.

Option B: False statement

Gleason's score has no relation to the extent of cancer within the abdomen.

Option D: False statement

Gleason's score has no relation with the expression of prostate-specific antigen.

Learning objective:

Prostate biopsies involve the sampling of tissue from several different areas of the gland (normally at least six). Two samples that appear to be most heavily involved, then histologically graded on a scale from 1 to 5 numbers are combined to give a Gleason score of 2 to 10

questions.text: Mark the correct statement about gallstone illeus:

choices.text: The most common fistula is cholecystocolic
Most common site of obstruction is jejunum

questions.solution:
Option D: Most commonly seen in elderly

  • Obstruction of the intestinal lumen from a gall stone carries the misnomer gall stone ileus, which is, in fact, a mechanical blockage. It occurs when a large gallstone erodes through the wall of the gallbladder directly into the intestine via a choledochoenteric fistula, which results in the air entering the biliary tree (pneumobilia).  
  • Most of these fistulas occur in older patients and may be caused by inflammation in the gallbladder or simply pressure necrosis.
  • The patient presents with clinical evidence of mechanical small bowel obstruction.
  • Plain radiographs demonstrate air-fluid levels consistent with small bowel obstruction.
  • Proximal stones can become impacted in the pylorus or proximal duodenum, causing gastric outlet obstruction (Bouveret syndrome).
  • Pneumobilia, which may be identified only by CT scan, is a ubiquitous finding because the fistula that permits a stone to pass into the duodenum allows air into the gall bladder and biliary tree.

Option A: The most common site of the fistula is cholecystocolic

  • Most common is choledochoduodenal fistula. 

Option B: Stone moves from the gallbladder and drops into GIT through the fistula causing obstruction in the jejunal part of the small intestine

  • It occurs when a large gallstone erodes through the wall of the gallbladder directly into the intestine via a choledochoenteric fistula, which results in the air entering the biliary tree 
  • The blockage can occur anywhere in the small intestine but occurs most commonly in the distal ileum, about 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve.

Option C: Rigler’s triad: Large bowel obstruction+ Pneumobilia + Ectopic gallstone

  • Rigler’s triad for gallstone ileus:
    • Small bowel obstruction
    • Pneumobilia
    • Ectopic gallstone
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the surgical outpatient department complaining of slowly progressive leg edema for three days. She gives no history of any other abnormalities. She has no history of any chronic illnesses. She is vitally stable. The patient's physical examination revealed non-pitting bilateral leg edema that does not improve with elevation. According to Brunner’s clinical classification of lymphedema, the patient’s pathology falls under which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Grade II

  • This is a case of grade II lymphedema in which the patient presents with complaints of slowly progressive leg edema for 3 days. She is vitally stable.
  • The physical examination of the patient revealed non-pitting bilateral leg edema that does not significantly reduce upon elevation.
  • According to Brunner’s clinical classification of lymphedema, the patient’s pathology comes under grade II.
  • The grade II lymphedema doesn’t significantly reduce upon elevation of the legs.

Option A: Grade I

  • The grade I lymphedema is pitting edema.
  • It is a type of edema which completely resolves on elevation. It also resolves after bed rest.

Option C: Grade III

  • Grade III lymphedema is a type of edema in which there are irreversible skin changes.
  • It results in fibrosis papillae.

Option D: Grade IV

  • Grade IV lymphedema is a type of edema in which ulceration of the affected area occurs.
  • Cerebral edema is also included in this category.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of vomiting blood, abdominal distension , and yellowing of eyes. He has a ten-year history of drinking 1-3 bottles of wine daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice, palmar erythema, spider nevi on his chest, dilated veins on the anterior abdominal wall, and 2+ oedema of the lower extremities. The abdomen is soft and diffusely tender; there is shifting dullness to percussion. His albumin is 1.3 g/dL, bilirubin is 54.8mg/dL, and prothrombin time is 32 seconds (INR = 3.3). Hepatitis serology is negative. Which scoring system cannot be used to assess whether the patient is a suitable candidate for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Myocardial perfusion imaging(MPI)

  • MPI stands for myocardial perfusion imaging.
  • It uses radionuclide (Tc99m) to detect bundle branch blocks, baseline ST segment depressions, and drug effects.

Option A: Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP)

  • Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score is used to assess the severity of cirrhosis.
  • It is based on five variables:
    • Bilirubin level
    • Albumin level
    • INR
    • Encephalopathy
    • Ascites

Option B: Monoethylglycinexylidide (MEGX)

  • Monoethylglycinexylidide (MEGX) score is a rapid and simple test that can assess the function of the liver and is widely used for liver transplantation in critical care medicines.
  • It measures MEGX formation after the administration of lidocaine.
  • It is approximately 80% sensitive and specific in diagnosing cirrhosis.

Option C: Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD)

  • Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is based on bilirubin and creatinine levels and the international normalized ratio (INR).
  • It predicts survival in cirrhosis patients, especially those waiting for a liver transplant.
  • A minimum MELD score of 18 is necessary to have a survival benefit post-transplant
  • Pediatric donor livers are distributed to pediatric patients preferentially. The Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) score is used in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the emergency department by paramedics after sustaining a road traffic accident 30 minutes ago. The patient is conscious and aware of his surroundings. He reports pain in his right shoulder. On physical examination, tenderness is found on the clavicle of the right side. He is unable to raise the right arm due to severe shoulder pain. The physician suspects a clavicular fracture. Which of the following site of the clavicle is most likely to be fractured?
questions.solution:
Option D: Middle third

  • Clavicular fractures occur due to falls on the shoulder and road traffic accidents.
  • It presents with pain in the shoulder, inability to lift the arm, bruising, swelling, and deformity over the site of the fracture and dropped shoulder.
  • Clavicular fractures can be categorized into 3 groups:
    • Group I (80%): Fractures of the middle third
    • Group II (15%): Fractures of the medial third
    • Group III (5%): Fractures of the lateral third
  • Open clavicle fractures are associated with high rates of pulmonary and closed-head injuries.
  • Treatment is mainly non-operative with a sling, physical therapy, and analgesics.
  • The risk of nonunion after midshaft fracture is higher in female and elderly patients and with fractures that are displaced, shortened more than 2 cm, or comminuted.
  • Lateral fractures have higher rates of nonunion compared with midshaft fractures.

Option A: Lateral third

  • Lateral third injuries constitute group III of injuries.
  • They account for only 5% of clavicular fractures.

Option B: Coracoid end

  • The coracoid end is a part of the lateral third of the clavicle.
  • Later third fractures account for only 5% of fractures.

Option C: Sternal end

  • The sternal end is a part of the medial third of the clavicle.
  • Medial third fractures account for 15% of fractures.

questions.text: You are a group of 6 medical students going to a weekend party in Goa. One of your friends' head hit a sandbank as he dived into the waves and was floating on the water for approximately 30 seconds. One of you realized he was having trouble and checked on him. All of you are experienced first aiders and were first responders to the accident. Upon initial examination, his pupils are equal and reactive to light. He showed no other signs of injury. He complained that he could not feel his arms and legs. You quickly diagnosed it as a case of spinal shock and took him to a nearby trauma center. Upon arrival, knowing that you all are medical students, the trauma surgeon asks you what is the first reflex to recover after spinal shock.
questions.solution:
Option A: Bulbocavernosus reflex

  • Spinal shock is the physiological dysfunction that follows structural injury to the spine. Spinal shock usually lasts less than 48 hours, and the reflexes return to normal.
  • The return of the bulbocavernosus reflex indicates the resolution of spinal shock.
  • 1st reflex to recover is bulbocavernosus reflex (S2-S4).
  • Tested by squeezing the penis in males or applying pressure on the clitoris in females.
  • The normal response is the contraction of the anal sphincter.
  • If the patient has in situ Foley catheter, it can be gently pulled to test anal contraction in both genders.

Option B: Abdominal reflex

  • Abdominal reflex is not the first one to return after spinal shock.

Option C: Plantar reflex

  • Plantar reflex returns after the bulbocavernosus reflex

Option D: Ankle reflex

  • Bulbocavernosus reflex returns first after a spinal shock, not the ankle reflex.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a swollen knee after getting hit over the lateral aspect of the knee two hours ago. On examination, joint line tenderness is present on the medial side. The anterior drawer test is negative. X-ray shows no fracture. Which of the following structure is most likely to be damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a medial meniscus tear.

Option B: Medial meniscus

  • Young, active patients: traumatic (i.e., axial loading and rotation action with a fixed foot during physical activity) and in older patients: degenerative (e.g., continuous work in a squatting position)
  • Knee pain: exacerbated by weight‑bearing or physical activity
  • Joint line tenderness (medial or lateral)
  • Restricted knee extension with possible knee instability
  • A locked knee may occur if the torn meniscus obstructs knee movement.
  • May hear a clicking sound or have a popping or locking sensation
  • Arthroscopy: Both diagnostic and therapeutic with a sensitivity and specificity of ∼ 100%. Diagnostic step of choice if MRI is contraindicated (e.g., patient with metal prostheses)

Option A: Anterior cruciate ligament:

  • Most commonly damaged ligament
  • Low-energy noncontact: sports injuries with a twisting mechanism, e.g., football, soccer, basketball, baseball, alpine skiing, and gymnastics.
  • Patients often report a popping sound shortly before the onset of symptoms.
  • Knee swelling (e.g., due to hemarthrosis), pain, and instability.
  • Positive anterior drawer test: With the knee joint at 90° flexion, the examiner fixes the foot on the table and pulls the proximal tibia forward.
  • Increased tibial anterior gliding (compared to the opposite knee) and a soft endpoint indicate an ACL tear.
  • Joint aspiration (in severe joint effusions): hemarthrosis
  • MRI (confirmatory test)

Option C: Posterior cruciate ligament

  • Initially, vague symptoms: minimal (or absent) posterior knee pain, swelling, decreased functional range of motion.
  • Positive posterior drawer test: With the patient lying supine and the knee at 90° flexion, the examiner fixes the foot on the table and pushes the proximal tibia backward.
  • Increased tibial posterior gliding (compared to the opposite knee) and a soft endpoint indicate PCL injury.

Option D: Lateral meniscus

  • Joint line tenderness is on the lateral aspect.
  • Audible pop when the examiner performs internal rotation of the tibia and applies varus stress while extending the knee.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male has been admitted to the hospital with severe nausea and vomiting for the past two days. He also complains of fatigue and poor appetite. His medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years. His medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, his temperature is 98.6F, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, his pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 16/min. Mucous membranes are dry. 

Lab Shows : 

Calcium 12.8 mg/dL

Phosphate 1.9 mg/dL

Albumin is 4.0 

PTH is elevated 

Vitamin D is normal

One year ago, he was diagnosed with kidney stones. A radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph is showing loss of lamina dura (i.e., thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as a thin white line, is resorbed) which confirms the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism.

Option D: Hyperparathyroidism

  • Caused by a parathyroid adenoma, carcinoma, or hyperplasia
  • Elevated PTH leads to increased serum calcium due to increased renal and gastrointestinal absorption of calcium
  • Increased renal excretion of phosphate leads to hypophosphatemia.
  • Symptoms are given below:

Symptoms and signs of excess parathyroid hormone secretion

Symptoms and signs of hypercalcemia
Bone disease
Nepharolithaisis
Hypophosphatemia
Increased production of calcitroil
Proximal renal tubular acidosis
Hypomagnesemia
Hyperuricemia and gout
Anemia

Diagnosis is confirmed with elevated PTH, calcium, and a low level of phosphate in the serum.

Option A: Rickets

  • Rickets- Enamel defect
  • Cupping, splaying, flaring
  • White line of Frankel seen in Healing rickets

Option B: Osteomalacia

  • Osteomalacia- No tooth abnormality
  • The adult counterpart of rickets
  • Tetracycline labeling is used to calculate turnover
  • Osteoid/ Osteon > 1 and Triradiate pelvis
  • Gold standard Investigation: Biopsy

Option C: Deficiency of vitamin C

  • Deficiency of vitamin C ( Scurvy): Bleeding gums + Dentine defects

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his wife with complaints of left-side chest pain radiating to the neck and jaw for 1 hour. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has been a known case of hypertension for five years. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The ECG of the patient was done, which revealed ST elevation in the anterior leads. The patient had an inadequate response to all non-surgical therapies. The patient was posted for coronary artery bypass graft surgery. After the administration of injection midazolam, fentanyl, and vecuronium, the ideal position for introducing a macintosh laryngoscope in this patient would be which of the following?

choices.text: Flexion of the lower cervical spine and extension of the head

questions.solution:
Option B: Flexion of the lower cervical spine and extension of the head

  • This is a case of anterior wall myocardial infarction in which the patient presents with complaints of left-side chest pain radiating to the neck and jaw for 1 hour. The ECG of the patient was done, which revealed ST elevation in the anterior leads. The patient had an inadequate response to all non-surgical therapies. The patient was posted for coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
  • For laryngoscopy to be successful, a line of sight from the mouth to the larynx must be achieved. It involves the alignment of three anatomical axes-oral, pharyngeal and laryngeal. The sniffing position approximates this alignment.
  • Cervical flexion by elevating the head by 7-9 cm produces approximately 35 degrees of flexion and aligns the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes.
  • Maximal head extension of the atlantooccipital joint (80 degrees) brings all three axes into alignment. This is called the morning sniffing position.

Option A: Shoulder elevation

  • Shoulder elevation is not normally done while introducing a macintosh laryngoscope.
  • The elevation of the shoulder should only be done in obese patients.

Option C: Flat on the bed

  • The patient should not be lying flat on the bed during the introduction of the laryngoscope.
  • The patient should be placed in a sniffing position unless the C-spine injury is suspected.

Option D: Hyperextension of neck

  • Hyperextension of the neck is not done during the positioning of the laryngoscope.
  • The neck is mildly flexed at the inferior cervical vertebrae and is extended at the atlanto-occipital joint.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is diagnosed with vestibular schwannoma expanding into the cerebellopontine angle. A sitting craniotomy under general anesthesia is planned. The most sensitive technique to detect venous air embolism during the intraoperative period in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Option B: TEE

  • The combination of precordial doppler and expired CO2 monitoring has high sensitivity and specificity, rapid response, and quantitatively measures the venous air embolism (VAE) event and indicates the course of recovery from the VAE event, which is in current practice.
  • Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE) is more sensitive than precordial doppler, which offers the advantage of identifying the right-to-left shunting of air.
  • Expired nitrogen analysis is theoretically attractive and has less sensitivity.
  • For air embolism diagnosis, the most sensitive monitor is TEE, doppler ultrasonography, capnography, ECG, and SpO2.
  • Following are the stages of VAE based on the results of TEE.
Stage TEE
0 No emboli in RA, RV and RVOT
I Single gas bubbles in RA, RV and RVOT
II Gas emboli filling less than half the diameter of RA, RV and RVOT
III Gas emboli filling more than half the diameter of RA, RV and RVOT
IV Gas emboli completely filling the diameter of RA, RV and RVOT

Option A: ECG

  • ECG is not a sensitive technique to detect VAE. The most preferred one is TEE in terms of sensitivity.

Option C: BIS

  • The bispectral index monitor processes electroencephalographic signals to obtain a value that reflects the patient's level of consciousness.
  • The bispectral index (BIS) monitor collects raw EEG data through its sensors and uses an algorithm to analyse and interpret the data.
  • BIS does not monoitor VAE.

Option D: Doppler

  • Precordial is the most sensitive non-invasive technique. However, TEE is invasive but more sensitive than precordial doppler.

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese female presents to the orthopaedics outpatient department with chief complaints of pain, stiffness, crepitus, and loss of function in the right knee from the last 8 months. She is on a pharmacological drug but has no improvement in her condition. She is planned for right total knee replacement surgery after a few days. When will be the antibiotic prophylaxis given to the patient?
questions.solution: Option D: Just before the tourniquet application

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, P2 L2 posted for puerperal sterilization in a family welfare camp in a hilly area. The Bain circuit was used to provide total intravenous anaesthesia with spontaneous ventilation as some major leaks in the circle system carbon dioxide absorber. Carbon dioxide elimination in this patient mainly depends on which factor?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fresh gas flow

  • To eliminate CO2 and prevent rebreathing, these systems depend on a higher rate of fresh gas inflow.
  • Fresh gas flow refers to the mixture of medical gases and volatile anaesthetic agents which is produced by an anaesthetic machine. The flow rate and composition of the fresh gas flow are determined by the anaesthetist.
  • Typically the fresh gas flow emerges from the common gas outlet, a specific outlet on the anaesthetic machine to which the breathing attachment is then connected.
  • Some older forms of breathing attachment, such as the Magill attachment, require high fresh gas flows (e.g. 7 litres/min) to prevent the patient from rebreathing their own expired carbon dioxide. More modern systems, e.g. the circle breathing attachment, use soda lime to absorb carbon dioxide, so that expired gas becomes suitable to re-use. With a very efficient circle system, the fresh gas flow may be reduced to the patient's minimum oxygen requirements (e.g. 250ml/min), plus a little volatile.

Option A: Type of circuit

  • All non-rebreathing (NRB) circuits lack unidirectional valves and soda lime carbon dioxide absorption.
  • The amount of rebreathing is highly dependent on the dilution of expirations with the high fresh gas flow (FGF) in all. Work of breathing is low in all (no unidirectional valves or soda lime granules to create resistance).
  • Minimum FGF in practice, most anaesthetists will provide a minimum of 5 L/min for children up to adults to prevent rebreathing.

Option C: Type of ventilation

  • There are two main types of anaesthesia ventilators: bellows type and piston type. We will discuss each one in depth.
  • Keep in mind, however, that machines can also be classified by what power source each one uses (purely pneumatic, pneumatic and electrical, or purely electrical).
  • Although it is important to know how your anaesthesia ventilator is powered, we prefer to classify them as to their mechanism of action.
  • The third type of anaesthesia ventilator is the servo type. Formerly made by Siemens, they are now produced and marketed by Maquet. Those clinicians with experience in critical care may be familiar with the servo ventilator. These ventilators were modified to deliver volatile agents, and some even had rebreathing capability from an attached carbon dioxide absorber.

Option D: Age of patient

  • Ageing is associated with a progressive loss of functional reserve in all organ systems.
  • However, there is considerable individual variability in the onset and extent of these changes.
  • Nevertheless, even the healthy older adult has reduced physiologic reserve such that organ systems may be compromised during illness and/or surgical stress.
  • Physiologic changes specifically impact anaesthetic care, in part by increasing susceptibility to anaesthetic drugs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the emergency department after binge drinking at a party and complains of chest pain following an episode of vomiting. A chest radiograph of this patient is shown below. Which of the following signs is demonstrated in this radiograph?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Naclerio V sign

  • A pneumomediastinum, which frequently results from an esophageal rupture, is characterized by the Naclerio V sign on plain film in patients.
  • It seems to be a collection of air in a V shape.
  • Mediastinal gas along the left lower lateral mediastinal boundary creates one of the V's arms.
  • The gas between the left medial hemidiaphragm and the parietal pleura produces the opposite limb.
  • Seen in Boerhaave syndrome.

Option A: Silhouette Sign

  • The term "silhouette sign" should be referred to as "loss of silhouette sign" or "loss of outline sign" since it refers to the loss of a silhouette in a true sense.
  • The silhouette is defined by the differential x-ray photon attenuation of two neighboring structures, such as the heart boundaries versus the adjacent lung segments.
  • The silhouette sign alludes to the pathological loss of this difference.
  • Only pathology in direct anatomical touch with a mediastinal boundary may hide it.
    Silhouette Sign" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://learningradiology.com/images/chestimages1/rmlmasssilhouette-ann.jpg" style="width: 415px; height: 215.281px; margin: 0px;" />

Option C: Spinnaker Sign

  • On newborn chest radiographs, the spinnaker sign, sometimes called the angel wing sign, is a marker of pneumomediastinum.
  • Air surrounds the thymus, and the lobes are laterally dislocated and resemble spinnaker sails.
  • It is different from the sail sign appearance of the normal thymus.

Option D: Hilum Overlay Sign

  • The hilum overlay sign can be used to determine if an opacity on a frontal chest radiograph in the lung hilum area is inside the hilum as opposed to anterior or posterior.
  • The sign shows preservation of the hilar vessels' visual appearance, excluding anomalies restricted to the middle mediastinum.
  • Hilum overlay sign indicates the mass is either in the anterior or posterior mediastinum but not in the middle mediastinum.
    overlay sign | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/3109744/fdb8edd6fb76d329edba5d443abd76_gallery.jpeg" style="width: 271.227px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by the rescue team after a road traffic accident. The patient is in an unconscious state with a GCS of 8/15. On examination, the patient has an open wound on the parietal area of the head. The wound was washed and stitched, and the patient was sent for a brain CT scan. The CT brain showed no midline shift but multiple tiny haemorrhages in the brain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Diffuse axonal injuries

  • This is a case of diffuse axonal injury.

  • The patient sustained a head injury due to a road traffic accident. The CT brain of the patient shows multiple tiny hemorrhages in the brain.

  • These multiple tiny hemorrhages are called diffuse axonal injuries.

  • Diffuse axonal injury: -

    • Occurs due to shearing of white matter

    • This occurs mainly because of rotational acceleration

  • Shows multiple petechial hemorrhages, usually at the junction of white and grey matter

  • CT scan may be normal in some cases, so MRI is the investigation of choice.

  • A young patient with RTA→ NCCT- normal/ petechial hemorrhages→ Suspect diffuse axonal injury→ MRI (IOC for DAI).

Option A: Cerebral contusion

  • Cerebral contusion-

  • NCCT image showing hemorrhagic contusion in the bilateral basis-frontal lobe.

Option B: Cerebral laceration

  • A cerebral lesion is a tear in the brain tissue. On CT brain, it gives a salt and paper appearance.

Option C: Multiple cerebral infarcts

  • Multiple cerebral infarcts-

  • NCCT image showing multiple hypodense areas in the right frontal and left frontoparietal and occipital lobe s/o infarcts.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented with a six-month history of global headaches, loss of balance, and a change in facial sensation. Central nervous system examination revealed reduced sensation on the left side, a GCS of 15/15, and all other cranial nerves were otherwise normal. Contrast-enhanced CT scans revealed an intracranial lesion at the CPA angle. On further evaluation, MR Spectroscopy showed an alanine peak . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Alanine Peak on MRS is seen at 1.4 ppm in Meningioma
  • Meningiomas also show choline peak at 3.2 ppm.
  • Glutamate-glutamine (Glx, peak at 2.1-2.6 ppm) and Glutathione (GSH, peak at 2.95 ppm) may be more specific potential markers in meningioma.

Figure: Alanine peak in Meningioma

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with chest trauma presents to the emergency department with sudden onset respiratory distress and shortness of breath. The patient also reports severe chest pain. His past medical history is significant for asthma. He has ten pack-year-smoking history. Examination reveals raised JVP and distended neck veins. The skin appears bluish on examination. The pulse is 138/min, blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, the temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), respiratory rate is 27/min, and SpO2 is 90%. Chest X-ray shows deep sulcus sign in expiration phase. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Pneumothorax

  • Pneumothorax is characterized by air in the lungs and chest wall cavity.

  • Pneumothorax can lead to the collapse of the lungs

  • Pneumothorax can develop due to the rupture of bullae or any external penetrating injury.

  • The symptoms of pneumothorax include hypotension, tachycardia, chest pain, shortness of breath, bluish skin, etc.

  • A physical examination will reveal unequal breath sounds, hyper resonance to percussion, and decreased chest wall movements.

  • Pneumothorax can be traumatic pneumothorax, tension pneumothorax, primary spontaneous pneumothorax, and secondary spontaneous pneumothorax.

  • A deep sulcus sign is seen On the Supine chest x-ray in the Expiration phase in a case of pneumothorax, where the lucency of air in the costophrenic angle gives the appearance of a deep sulcus.

  • The deep sulcus sign is an indirect indicator of pneumothorax.

 

  • Other Findings of Pneumothorax on CXR include absent bronchoalveolar markings, visceral pleural reflection, jet black lungs, etc.

  • Pneumothorax can be treated via immediate needle decompression. A chest tube may also be placed.

Option B: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion is characterized by the presence of excessive fluid between the layers of the pleura.

  • CXR of pleural effusion is characterized by blunting costophrenic angle, cardiophrenic angle, and fluid in horizontal and oblique fissures.
    effusion | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/53183623/f69b9ba15aa08e02024c4dc168ab80aa0dfc09c8bde1662cd7ce62d13c7b016d_gallery.jpeg" style="width: 249.842px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

Option C: Tuberculosis

  • Mycobacteria tuberculosis can cause pulmonary tuberculosis.

  • Pulmonary cavitation is also a hallmark of pulmonary tuberculosis.

  • Symptoms of pulmonary tuberculosis include cough, hemoptysis, night sweats, and weight loss.
    X-ray - Pulmonary disease - Tuberculosis" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://www.radiologymasterclass.co.uk/images/chest-images/gallery-pulmonary/tb_1.jpg?mtime=20210304211318&focal=none" style="width: 415px; height: 216.261px; margin: 0px;" />

Option D: Pneumonia

  • Pneumonia is an infection of the lung parenchyma.

  • It is characterized by high-grade fever. Fever may be low grade in case of viral infection.

  • A single lobe's pulmonary infiltration characterizes lobar pneumonia.

questions.text: During a primigravida's delivery in the delivery room, after successfully delivering the head, the doctor encounters difficulty in delivering the shoulders with traction. Subsequently, the doctor performs McRobert's procedure. What nerve injury may occur in the mother due to this maneuver?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option D: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

  • The McRobert's procedure is employed to deliver babies with shoulder dystocia
  • The helpers grip and press the maternal foot cephalad, causing hyperflexion of the maternal hips and knees and minor hip abduction, resulting in a 1-2 cm superior displacement of the pubic symphysis.
  • It causes sacral extension or counter-nutation as well.
  • The angle formed by L5 and the sacral promontory flattens and widens as the sacrum advances posteriorly.
  • The fetus's posterior shoulder travels posteriorly and inferiorly towards the pelvis as the sacral promontory flattens.
  • This positional adjustment permits the anterior shoulder to migrate out from behind the pubic symphysis, allowing for easier delivery.
  • The flattening of the sacrum promontory increases the effectiveness of the force produced by spontaneous uterine contractions and maternal pushing attempts.
  • It can cause compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh as it involves sudden hyperflexion of the maternal thigh over the abdomen.

Option A: Common peroneal nerve

  • Common peroneal nerve injury has been linked to prolonged squatting during childbirth, hyperflexion of the knees during delivery, and direct compression of the nerve over the fibular head by the patient gripping her legs with fingers over the anterior tibia and palms over the fibular head.
  • Certain types of stirrups, which may be used for pushing in patients with epidurals during the second stage of labour, may also induce compression of the common peroneal nerve.
  • It appears more prevalent during gynecologic surgery when the patient must be positioned in stirrups for the lithotomy posture.

Option B: Obturator nerve

  • The descending foetal head or forceps might compress the obturator nerve when it reaches the pelvic brim.
  • The lithotomy posture leads the obturator nerve to angulate as it exits the obturator foramen.
  • Pudendal nerve blocks have also been linked to hematomas and obturator nerve entrapment.

Option C: Lumbosacral trunk

  • The L-4 and L-5 nerve roots compose the lumbosacral trunk. Except at its terminal segment at the pelvic brim, where the S-1 nerve root unites it to form the sciatic nerve, it travels in close contact with the ala of the sacrum next to the sacroiliac joint and is cushioned by the psoas muscle. The plexus becomes vulnerable to compression as the foetal head descends towards the pelvis.
  • Radicular symptoms can also be caused by intervertebral disc bulges, ruptures, trauma, infection, inflammation, or muscular spasms.
  • Foot drop and other neurologic symptoms associated with peripheral mononeuropathies (single or several) of the nerves that branch from the plexus might result from a lumbosacral plexus or trunk injury.
  • Fetal macrosomia, malpresentation (occiput posterior or brow presentation), and specific pelvic traits such as platypelloid pelvis, shallow anterior sacral ala, and flattened sacral promontory are also risk factors for lumbosacral plexus or trunk injuries.

questions.text: A postpartum woman presents with a painful and engorged right breast. On examination, the breast is enlarged, and tender, and appears warmer than the surrounding skin. Ultrasound suggests generalized inflammatory changes. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient's condition?

choices.text: The source of the infection is usually the infant’s gastrointestinal tract
Frank abscesses may develop and require drainage
The most common offending organism is Escherichia coli.

questions.solution:
Option C: Frank abscesses may develop and require drainage

  • The presence of painful, engorged, tender unilateral breast with USG s/o generalized inflammatory changes suggests mastitis.
  • Acute puerperal mastitis:
  • The most common organism is a staphylococcus aureus (especially MRSA). Other organisms include coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and Streptococcus viridans.
  • The most common source of infection is the baby's nasopharynx.
  • Symptoms and signs:
  • Fever with chills, myalgia, malaise
  • Engorged and tender breast
  • Mostly unilateral
  • Approximately 10 per cent of women with mastitis develop an abscess that requires drainage.
  • Breast milk expression, antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally four times daily, may be started empirically.
  • Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin hypersensitive
  • A lactating woman presenting with painful, tender unilateral signs of inflammation suggests mastitis.
  • It is treated with penicillins and breast milk expression. It may complicate a breast abscess if not treated.

Option A: The initial treatment is tetracyclines

  • Tetracyclines are contraindicated in breast feeding and are not first line for treating Staph infections.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option B: The source of the infection is usually the infant’s gastrointestinal tract

  • Mastitis is an infection of the tissue of the breast that occurs most frequently during the time of breastfeeding.
  • It can occur when bacteria from the baby's mouth enter a milk duct through a crack in the nipple.
  • Most common source if infection is baby's nasopharynx.

Option D: The most common offending organism is Escherichia coli.

  • Breast abscess usually occurs during lactation; the responsible organism is often S. Aureus. Breast abscess in non-lactating women is extremely rare, and limited data is available in the literature regarding this entity.

questions.text: An obstetrician, prior to vaginal delivery, plans an episiotomy in the second stage of labour. In which of these patients can a midline episiotomy be considered superior to a mediolateral episiotomy during the delivery of a fetus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Second gravida with moderate anaemia:

  • A midline episiotomy is associated with a higher risk of third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Following factors are associated with increased risk:
    • Nulliparity
    • Second-stage arrest of labor
    • Persistent occiput-posterior position
    • Mid or low forceps
    • Use of local anesthetics
    • Asian race.
  • A mediolateral episiotomy should be performed in these mentioned situations
  • A multiparous patient with anemia does not have an increased risk for third or fourth-degree laceration and since the patient is anemic, with a midline episiotomy, blood loss is less and healing is better making it a better option.
  • Midline episiotomies are easier to fix and have a smaller incidence of surgical breakdown, less pain, and lower blood loss, less incidence of dyspareunia. However, the incidence of extensions of the incision to include the rectum is considerably higher than with mediolateral episiotomies, which makes the most important consideration while taking an episiotomy such that mediolateral are preferred.

Option A: Nulligravida with thick perineum:

  • A nulligravid woman with thick perineum is at higher risk of third and fourth-degree perineal tears.
  • Therefore, in such patients, a mediolateral episiotomy is preferred.

Option B: Prolonged second stage:

  • In a prolonged second stage, there is an increased risk of perineal tears and extension of episiotomy.
  • Hence, a mediolateral episiotomy is preferred in this case.

Option D: Before application of forceps:

  • Before applying forceps, a midline episiotomy is contraindicated due to the increased risk of perineal tears and extension of episiotomy.

questions.text: A senior consultant on rounds of labor room asks his residents to tell him the bishop’s score for a primigravida with severe pre-eclampsia admitted at 37 weeks. This score in this patient is used to assess which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chances of favourable induction

  • The Bishop scoring system is based on a digital cervical exam of a patient with a zero point minimum and 13 point maximum. The scoring system utilizes cervical dilation, position, effacement, consistency of the cervix, and fetal station
  • The bishop score an important determination in the prediction of successful induction of labour
  • The pelvic score can be ascertained in a patient at the time of induction by a digital cervical exam to determine if cervical ripening is necessary before induction.
  • A Bishop score of 4 or less identifies an unfavorable cervix and may be an indication of cervical ripening.
  • Hence a score of 5 or more is favorable.
  • Bishop score before inducing labor should be >=8
  • A score of 9 conveys a high likelihood of a successful induction.
  • BISHOP SCORE=.............................(total) Date of Bishop Score: ........./...../........
    Score 0 1 2 3
    Dilation (in cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5
    Length (in cm) >4 3-4 1-2 0
    Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
    Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
    Head: station -3 -2 -1,0 +1,+2

    ‘Effacement’ of the cervix is now replaced by ‘Length’ of the cervix from the original bishop score.

 

Option A: Intrapartum fetal well being

  • Intrapartum fetal well being can be determined by the assessment of fetal heart rate, best done  by Cardiotocography (CTG).

 

Option C: Risk of eclampsia

  • Pre-eclampsia happens when a woman who previously had normal blood pressure suddenly develops high blood pressure (≥140/≥90 mmHg) and protein in her urine or other problems after 20 weeks of pregnancy. Women who have chronic hypertension can also get pre-eclampsia.
  • Pre-eclampsia with the occurrence of seizures (usually tonic-clonic) is known as eclampsia.
  • Bishop score cannot help assess the risk of eclampsia occurrence

 

Option D: Events of active labour

  • Events in active labour are assessed by serial monitoring of baby and mother by general examination, abdominal and pelvic examination and assessment of fetal heart rate with CTG. These are best comprehended when plotted on a partograph.

questions.text: A 30-year-old gravida 2, para 1, female at 37 weeks gestational age, is here for a routine visit. Her first baby was a vaginal delivery of a 4.3 kg baby boy after 30 min of pushing. The present fetus is breech. A vaginal exam demonstrates that the cervix is 50% effaced and 1 to 2 cm dilated. The presenting breech is high out of the pelvis. The estimated fetal weight is about 3.2 kg. A sonogram confirms a fetus with a frank breech, normal amniotic fluid present, and the head is well flexed. Which of the following is not a correct management option in this case?

choices.text: Allow the patient to undergo a vaginal breech delivery whenever she goes into labour
Perform an emergency cesarean section now
Pinard's manoeuvre can be done for the delivery of extended legs
Schedule an external cephalic version in the next few days

questions.solution:
Option B: Perform an emergency cesarean section

At 37 weeks of gestation, there is no indication to conduct an elective lower-section caesarian section (LSCS) unless there are other obstetric factors, such as a previous LSCS or placenta previa.

Indications for LSCS in breech:

  • Breech with an extended head
  • Complicated breech such as one associated with twins pregnancy, macrosomic baby, bad obstetric history.
  • Footling breech
  • Other obstetric indications

Option A: Allow the patient to undergo a vaginal breech delivery whenever she goes into labour

  • Spontaneous vaginal delivery can be attempted in the frank breech.
  • Extended breech, also known as frank breech, is the most favourable of all breech types since it has the lowest chance of cord prolapse.

Option C: Pinard's manoeuvre can be done for delivery of extended legs

  • Pinard's manoeuvre is performed for extended legs in a breech baby
  • It involves reaching the popliteal fossa, flexing the knee, and then holding the sacrum anteriorly and anterior superior iliac spine on the sides with both hands and pulling the baby out.

Option D: Schedule an external cephalic version in the next few days

  • An external cephalic version (ECV) can be considered as the gestational age is 37 weeks, and the patient is not in labour.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G2P1, presents with labor pain at term. She has a history of previous lower segment cesarean section (LSCS). On examination, there are good contractions, the cervix is 2 cm dilated, and the interspinous diameter is 9 cm, there is Scar Dehiscence. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Forceps application in the second stage

questions.solution:
The correct option is 1. Allow spontaneous labor a watch on scar tenderness.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Allow spontaneous labour with a watch on scar tenderness: This is the most appropriate initial step. After a previous lower segment cesarean section (LSCS), allowing spontaneous labor is generally a safe approach. Monitoring scar tenderness and uterine contractions is important to assess the risk of uterine rupture at the previous scar site. If there is no evidence of scar dehiscence or uterine rupture, vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) can be attempted.

  2. Allow spontaneous progress, liberal episiotomy: While allowing spontaneous progress is a reasonable approach, the concept of "liberal episiotomy" is not widely supported. Episiotomy rates have decreased in modern obstetric practice due to recognition of potential harms. Episiotomies are typically performed when necessary and not in a "liberal" manner.

  3. Forceps application in the second stage: Forceps application may be considered in certain situations during the second stage of labor, but it's not the most appropriate initial step in this scenario. Prior LSCS history requires careful monitoring for scar integrity, and using forceps would not specifically address this concern.

  4. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS is not indicated in this scenario. A previous LSCS does not automatically mandate another cesarean delivery. Vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) is often considered if the woman is an appropriate candidate and if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female nearing her delivery date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and documented that the head was at +1 station. Where is the exact position of the head?

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.solution:
Option C: Just below the ischial spine

A fetal station of +1 implies that the leading point of the head is just below the ischial spines as these spines are considered station 0, and the diameter between the ischial spines (interspinous diameter) is the shortest transverse diameter of the pelvis.

  • The station is the leading point of the head.
  • Station 0 = head at the level of Ischial spines
  • + means below Ischial spines
  • - means above Ischial spines
  • Numbers 1 and 2 denote distance below or above the Ischial spine.
  • Ischial spines are considered the bony landmark about which the fetal head station is assessed. These spines are considered station 0, and the diameter between the ischial spines (interspinous diameter) is the shortest transverse diameter of the pelvis. All stations below this level are denoted with a + sign, and stations above this level are denoted with a - sign.

Option A: High up in the false pelvis

  • The false pelvis is bounded on either side by the ilium.
  • Head high up in false pelvis would imply a station of -3 and above

Option B: Just above the ischial spine

  • The ischial spine is part of the posterior border of the body of the ischium bone of the pelvis.
  • Normally the ischial spines are the narrowest part of the pelvis.
  •  0 station. This is when the baby's head is even with the ischial spines. Station just above ischial spines would be -1

Option D: At the perineum

  • Station at the perineum is +3 to +5

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravida presents to the obstetric outpatient department for her first prenatal check-up at 10 weeks of gestation. She has had a history of mitral regurgitation for 7 years which was treated with mitral valve replacement 3 years ago. Since then, she has been taking her oral anticoagulants. Which of the following fetal anomalies are most likely to be seen in this patient’s anomaly scan?
questions.solution:
Option B: Craniofacial malformation

  • The oral anticoagulant most commonly used is warfarin.
  • Warfarin use in pregnant women can lead to craniofacial malformation in the fetus.
  • Exposure between the 6th and 9th weeks of pregnancy may result in warfarin embryopathy/fetal warfarin syndrome.
  • Warfarin use can cause stippling of vertebrae and femoral epiphyses in the fetus.
  • Nasal hypoplasia with depression of the nasal bridge may be present. Choanal atresia of the fetus, which results in respiratory distress, may also occur.
  • Exposure later in pregnancy leads to internal bleeding in the fetus, particularly the brain.
  • Therefore, pregnant women are shifted to heparin during pregnancy, specially in first and last trimester.
  • However, women with mechanical heart valves continue treatment with warfarin (in second trimester), with levels monitored frequently.

 

Option A: Long bones defect

  • Long bone formation is affected by tetracyclines.
  • It is not associated with warfarin use.

 

Option C: Cardiovascular malformation 

  • Cardiovascular malformations can be caused by several drugs, including lithium and cocaine.
  • Warfarin use is not associated with cardiac malformations.

 

Option D: Osteochondrodysplasia

  • Osteochondrodysplasia is caused by a mutation in the COMP (cartilage oligomeric matrix protein) gene, which results in short stature.
  • The genetic disorder is not associated with warfarin use.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes at 40 weeks gestation , her fundal height measures 34 cm. USG is done which shows the maximum vertical pocket of liquor < 2cm and AFI of 3 cm. Which of the following is false regarding this case scenario?

choices.text: Do induction if vaginal delivery is not contraindicated
During labour, cord compression is common in these patients
If cervix is unfavourable, immediate LSCS needs to be done

questions.solution:
Option C : The above-given case scenario is of a pregnant female at term with Oligohydramnios.

  • The patients with oligohydramnios at term should be delivered.Induction of labor is done if vaginal delivery is not contraindicated. The patient with an unfavorable cervix should undergo cervical ripening after assessment of fetal well-being. If fetal testing is reassuring, the unfavorable cervix can be ripened and vaginal delivery is done after that.

Oligohydramnios can cause fetal and maternal complications :

Fetal Complications :

  • Intra-Uterine death
  • Cord compression
  • Deformities (Like deformed shape of skull, wry neck, etc)
  • Fetal pulmonary hypoplasia

Maternal complications :

  • Prolonged labor
  • Increased operative interference due to malpresentation

Option A : Induction of labor is done if vaginal delivery is not contraindicated.

Option B : During labour, cord compression can occur as liquor acts as a cushion between fetal parts , umbilical cord and uterus. Less liquor causes more risk of cord compression.

Option D : Strict intrapartum surveillance is required as olighydramnios in labour is at an increased risk of fetal hypoxia, cord compression

questions.text: A 36-year-old Gravidity 2, parity 0 woman comes to the Gynaecological OPD for preconceptional counselling. She had previous miscarriages due to spontaneous abortions during the second trimester. The patient developed vaginal bleeding and mild suprapubic pain in both pregnancies, and both resulted in abortions. She takes folic acid and a multivitamin. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for eight years and drank alcohol occasionally but stopped both after her second pregnancy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 94/min, and her blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in assessing the cause of her previous abortions?
questions.solution:
Option A: TVS

As there is H/O recurrent second-trimester abortions, so we prefer to do TVS to rule out:

  • Uterine anomalies such as the septate uterus, bicornuate uterus
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Others- include fibroids (submucosal), polyps and endometritis.

Causes of recurrent second-trimester abortion

  • Anatomical: Uterine anomalies like septate, bicornuate, and cervical incompetence: Most common
  • Maternal disease: DM, HTN, Hypothyroidism, SLE
  • Drug abuse: Cocaine, Smoking
  • Inherited or acquired thrombophilias
  • Chromosomal
  • Infections: May cause T2 losses but not recurrent losses

Anatomical abnormalities like cervical incompetence and uterine anomalies like septate, bicornuate and cervical incompetence are the most common causes of recurrent second-trimester abortions. These may be evaluated by TVS. However, a laparo-hysteroscopy is the investigation of choice.

 

Option B: Hysteroscopy

  • The first step in this patient should be a TVS as it is non-invasive and can detect cervical incompetence by measuring cervical legth and also detect uterine anomalies, however a hysteroscopy (along with laparoscopy) may be required at a later stage to look for and confirm uterine anomalies.

 

Option C: Endometrial biopsy

  • Endometrial biopsy is used to detect luteal phase defects, endometrial infections such as TB, which are more important causes of infertility than abortions.

 

Option D: Karyotyping

  •  Karyotyping is useful for detecting chromosomal abnormalities which are most common causes of first trimester abortions.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with primary infertility is treated with IVF (In vitro fertilization). She becomes pregnant and attends a clinic for an ultrasound at 6 weeks of her pregnancy. Ultrasound reveals a live intrauterine pregnancy along with another gestational sac seen in the left adnexal region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Heterotopic pregnancy

  • Heterotopic pregnancy is a rare complication of pregnancy in which both extrauterine (ectopic pregnancy) and intrauterine pregnancy occur simultaneously.
  • It may also be referred to as a combined ectopic pregnancy /multiple-sited pregnancy or co-incident pregnancy.
  • Heterotopic pregnancy occurs when one embryo implants normally in the walls of the uterus and the other embryo implants ectopically outside the uterine cavity, such as in the fallopian tube.
  • The following ultrasound view provides an example of heterotopic pregnancy in which an intrauterine, as well as an extrauterine gestational sac, is visible:

  • The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy has now increased to around 1 in 3000 pregnancies due to the advent of IVF (In vitro fertilization).
  • Heterotopic pregnancy is more likely associated with any of the following:
    • Conception achieved by assisted reproductive techniques
    • Persistent or rising hCG levels after dilatation and curettage for an induced or spontaneous abortion
    • A uterine fundus larger than menstrual dates
    • More than one corpus luteum
    • Absent vaginal bleeding in the presence of signs and symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy
    • Sonographic evidence of uterine and extrauterine pregnancy.

Option A: Dizygotic twins

  • Dizygotic twins are twins formed from two different embryos, but both are intrauterine. However, in this case, one sac is seen in the uterus and the other in the adnexal region, most likely the fallopian tube.

Option C: Superfecundation

  • Superfecundation implies the fertilization of two or more ova from the same cycle by sperm from separate acts of sexual intercourse, which can lead to twin babies from two separate biological fathers. However, the co-existence of an intrauterine and extrauterine gestational sac is consistent with heterotopic pregnancy.

Option D: Monozygotic twins

  • Monozygotic twins are twins formed after the splitting of one zygote, but again both are intrauterine. In hetrotopic pregnancy, one gestational sac is intrauterine and the other, extrauterine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of cycles of severe lower abdominal pain during her menstrual cycles for the last 2 months. The pain was not relieved with medication. The physician diagnosed her with primary dysmenorrhea after evaluation. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: No clinically significant pelvis pathology is found
Menorrhagia and dyspareunia are associated with this type of dysmenorrhea
Endometriosis & PID are important causes of primary dysmenorrhea

questions.solution:
Option A: No clinically significant pelvis pathology is found

  • The woman is suffering from primary amenorrhea. Hence there is no significant pelvis pathology found.
  • Dysmenorrhea is the occurrence of severe and frequent cramps and pain during your period. It can be primary or secondary.
  • Primary dysmenorrhea:
    • The pain begins a few hours before or after a menstrual period.
    • It may last 48 to 72 hours.
    • No pelvic pathology.
    • No systemic symptoms.
    • Seen in a normal woman.
  • Secondary dysmenorrhea:
    • It is due to some other physical cause. It usually starts later in life. It may be caused by other medical conditions, such as pelvic inflammatory disease or endometriosis.
    • 3-4 days before menstruation and last throughout periods.
    • Associated with pelvic pathology m/c endometriosis.
    • Systemic symptoms are seen.
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea
    • The Fibrinolytic system in the uterus is responsible for less/non-clumping blood.
    • In the total absence of this system, the endometrium is shed like the cast of the endometrial cavity.

Option B: Menorrhagia and dyspareunia are associated with this type of dysmenorrhea

  • Menorrhagia and dyspareunia point towards a pelvic pathology such as endometriosis, pelvic inflammation or fibroids, hence these are associated with secondary dysmenorrhea.

Option C:  More commonly seen after 3rd decade

  • Primary dysmenorrhea occurs with the start of menstruation, usually in the second decade.

Option D: Endometriosis & PID are important causes of primary dysmenorrhea

  • They are causes of secondary dysmenorrhea

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of sudden-onset abdominal distension, vomiting, and difficulty in breathing in a 32-year-old patient with a history of primary infertility, positive pregnancy test, and severe ascites on ultrasound, who had undergone ovulation induction and ovulation triggered with injection hCG?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome

  • All symptoms are suggestive of severe Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS).
  • The history of infertility treatment is the key to diagnosis in this case.
  • Severe ascites can lead to abdominal distension, vomiting and respiratory difficulty.
  • OHSS can occur during pregnancy; in fact, it is more severe during pregnancy.
