  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment.
  • A woman with a history of ovulation induction with ovulation trigger, presenting with complaints of pain in the abdomen and abdominal distension, must always raise suspicion of OHSS.
  • A positive UPT should not raise confusion, as OHSS can be present in pregnancy, too. However, an ectopic pregnancy must be ruled out in such a case.
  • OHSS can range from mild to critical in severity.
  • Different types of presentations of OHSS in severity are given in the chart below.
Mild OHSS

Abdominal bloating

Mild abdominal pain

Ovarian size usually < 8 cm
Moderate OHSS

Moderate abdominal pain

Nausea ± vomiting

Ultrasound evidence of ascites

Ovarian size usually 8 to 12 cm
Severe OHSS

Clinical ascites (occasionally pleural effusion)

Oliguria

Hemoconcentration hematocrit (> 45%)

Hypoproteinemia

Ovarian size usually > 12 cm
Critical OHSS

Tense ascites or large pleural effusion

Hematocrit (> 55%)

White cell count > 25000

Oligouria/ anuria

Thromboembolism

Acute respiratory distress syndrome

Option A: Choriocarcinoma

  • Choriocarcinoma presents with vaginal bleeding that too after a few weeks of pregnancy that resulted in either a vaginal delivery, abortion or molar pregnancy.

Option B: Molar pregnancy

  • Molar pregnancy presents with pervaginal bleeding, and there is a snowstorm appearance of the gestational sac on ultrasound.

Option D: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

  • Although abdominal pain and distension could be a presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy but would occur only as early as 4-6 weeks of conception.

questions.text: A 27-year-old presents to Gynaecology OPD with complaints of failure to conceive for the last 3 years. The patient with primary infertility is under evaluation for the cause. She has a history of regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. The pain usually starts a few days before periods and subsides on day 2. Pelvic examination reveals a fixed uterus with nodularity in the posterior fornix. Her hysterosalpingogram and husband's semen analysis are expected. Which of the following is the best tool to get a diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Laparoscopy

  • History of infertility, congestive dysmenorrhea, and fixed uterus with nodularity in POD suggests endometriosis. Endometriosis is best diagnosed by laparoscopy.
  • The role of laparoscopy in endometriosis includes:
    • Laparoscopy can detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
    • It can also locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
    • It can be used to take a biopsy.
    • And surgically treat endometriosis by ablation and removal.

Option A: Ultrasound

  • Ultrasound may show an echo-free cyst whose wall is thick and irregular suggesting a chocolate ovarian cyst, however is not useful in detection of peritoneal endometriosis.

Option C: Laparotomy

  • Laparotomy is invasive and unnecessary for diagnosis of endometriosis.

Option D: Endometrial curettage

  • Endometriosis is best diagnosed by laparoscopy, not by endometrial curettage. Endometrial currettage can detect endometrial hyperplasia, cancer and infections like TB.

questions.text: A 48-year-old menopausal woman presents with perineal itching. On examination, there is mild vulvar atrophy. A biopsy taken from the site is negative for malignancy.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Estrogen ointment

  • Vulvar atrophy and itching in the pre-menopausal and menopausal age group are due to a deficiency of estrogen that causes dryness of the vulva, which causes itching.
  • The ideal treatment for this manifestation of post-menopausal urogenital atrophy is some form of Hormone Replacement.
  • Topical estrogen is most effective with minimal systemic side effects.
    • Local estrogens are better: Estriol cream
    • Local DHEA application
    • Oral ospemifene: SERM: Reduces dyspareunia
  • Note that vulvar itching is a common symptom of vulvar cancer; therefore, a local examination must be done to see for lesions such as growth or leukoplakia.
  • In case of such a lesion or if the itching is not relieved with topical treatment, a biopsy must be done to rule out Ca vulva.

 

Option B: Antihistamines

  • Antihistamines would relieve itching temporarily but not treat the vulval atrophy due to estrogen deficiency.

 

Option C: Tamoxifen

  • A selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) is used in breast cancer prevention and treatment.
  • It has an antiestrogenic effect on the breast and an estrogenic effect on the uterus and bone.
  • Its indications are
  1. Pre-menopausal estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer
  2. Vaginal atrophy (related to menopause)
  3. Prostate cancer for prevention of gynecomastia
  • Side effects
  1. Hot flashes
  2. Increase risk of endometrial cancer
  3. Increase risk of thromboembolic events
  4. Increase risk of uterine sarcoma

Hence this is not the ideal treatment for menopausal woman where a topical estrogen preparation can be safely used.

 

Option D: Oral antifungal treatment

  • Oral antifungal drugs treat fungal infections, most common on skin, nails and hair.
  • These are used to treat dermatophytosis and chronic yeast infections.

questions.text: A 58-year-old postmenopausal woman is referred to a gynecologic clinic by her family physician for irregular vaginal bleeding of 6 months duration. On speculum examination, a smooth and congested 5 x 2 cm elongated mass protrudes through the cervix. This was removed in the OPD with minimal twisting. Microscopic examination of the tissue shows a mass with cystic hyperplasia and a central vascular channel surrounded on three sides by epithelium. The vaginal bleeding has now stopped completely for 6 months. An ultrasonogram post-procedure is normal. What is the lesion described here?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bleeding is from an endometrial polyp

  • Endometrial polyps are focal endometrial outgrowths that contain a variable amount of stroma, glands and blood vessels which influence their appearance as finger-like endometrial projections and have a classical histopathological picture of mass with cystic hyperplasia and a central vascular channel surrounded by three sides by epithelium.
  • They may be small in size or large enough to protrude through the cervix.
  • Smaller ones can spontaneously resolve, and larger ones may persist, so they need removal as soon as diagnosed because they can cause heavy uterine bleeding, abnormal uterine bleeding, postmenopausal bleeding and also affects fertility in the reproductive age group.
  • Malignant transformation develops in 1%-2% of the polyp.
  • Abnormal bleeding is the most common symptom of an endometrial polyp.
  • Many of the postmenopausal bleedings, in up to 10% of cases, are due to polyps.
  • It's advisable to do an ultrasound to make sure that there are not more of these in the uterus, which may protrude out and cause symptoms later.

Option A: Cancer cervix

  • Carcinoma of the cervix does not protrude like a smooth mass and cannot be treated in OPD. Excision may result in heavy bleeding. Ca cervix is instead an irregular and friable growth

Option C: Gestational trophoblastic disease

  • The gestational trophoblastic disease or moar pregnancy is unlikely here in a postmenopausal patient. 

Option D: Endocervical cancer

  • Carcinoma of the cervix does not protrude like a smooth mass and cannot be treated in OPD. Excision may result in heavy bleeding. Ca cervix is instead an irregular and friable growth

questions.text: A 54-yrs-old woman undergoes a laparotomy because of a pelvic mass. At exploratory laparotomy, a unilateral ovarian neoplasm is discovered that is accompanied by a large omental metastasis. Frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic serous cystadenocarcinoma. The most appropriate intraoperative course of action is:-

choices.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy.
Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy
Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.solution:
Option D: Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage-IIIC). This is managed by comprehensive surgical staging, maximal cytoreduction, and adjuvant chemotherapy.

Management of ovarian epithelial cancer:

  • Early:
    • Low risk : Stage 1A and 1B, low-grade : surgical staging
    • If High risk : Stage 1C, high-grade : surgical staging + adjuvant chemotherapy
  • Advanced:
    • Stage II, III, IV = Maximal cytoreduction + Adjuvant chemotherapy
  • Steps of comprehensive surgical staging
    • Vertical midline incision
    • Ascitic fluid for cytology
    • If no ascites: Take peritoneal washings
    • Biopsy of suspicious lesions and diaphragm
    • Omentectomy
    • Retroperitoneal lymph node evaluation
  • Important points:
    • Maximal cytoreduction: Means removal of entire pelvic tumor + resection of metastasis
    • Optimal debulking: Less than 1 cm of residual lesion
    • Fertility sparing surgery (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy): Stage 1A with low grade, borderline tumors
    • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Stage III and IV with massive ascites, massive pleural effusion, unresectable tumor. It increases the chances of optimal debulking.

Option A: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC). Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy is insufficient.

Option B: Omentectomy and ovarian cystectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC). Omentectomy and ovarian cystectomy is insufficient

Option C: Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy

  • The patient in question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC). Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy is insufficient.

questions.text: A 38 year old woman presenting with irregular heavy menstrual cycles underwent an endometrial biopsy which shows simple endometrial hyperplasia. Which of the following could have been a cause for such condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Polycystic ovarian disease

  • In chronic anovulatory patients with PCOS, persistently elevated estrogen levels which are uninterrupted by progesterone, increase the risk of endometrial carcinoma.
  • These endometrial cancers are usually well differentiated, stage I lesions with a cure rate of more than 90%. Endometrial biopsy should be considered in PCOS patients, especially if accompanied by abnormal bleeding, increasing weight, and advanced age.Prevention of endometrial cancer is a core management goal for patients with PCOS.
  • Also, the risk of ovarian cancer is increased two- to threefold in women with PCOS.
  • Other complications associated with PCOD:
  • Infertility
  • Gestational diabetes or eclampsia
  • Miscarriage or immature birth
  • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Metabolic syndromes: Hypertension, diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, cardiovascular disease
  •  
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus or prediabetes
  • Orthopnea
  • Depression, anxiety and eating disorders
  •  

Option A: Endodermal sinus tumour

  • It is also called a yolk sac tumour. It is a type of germ cell cancer. This tumor does not secrete estrogens and thus is not associated with endometrial hyperplasia.

Option B: Dysgerminoma

  • It is a germ cells tumor seen in young women. This tumor does not secrete estrogens and thus is not associated with endometrial hyperplasia.

Option D: Carcinoma of the cervix

  • It is not associated with endometrial hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 38- year woman operated on a lower segment uterine fibroid. She had an uneventful surgery. Post-operatively the urine output decreased, up to 20 ml/hr. Rapid IV fluid infusions were given with an injection of Lasix, and output increased to 70 ml/hr. The urine was clear. A patient complained of flank pain which was gradually progressing. What is the most common cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Unilateral ureteric injury.

  • Decreased urine post-operatively and flank pain point towards ureteric injury. Here flank pain usually suggests that the ureter has been ligated and is causing proximal hydroureteronephrosis. Increased urine output with fluid and Lasix is due to increased urine production and excretion from the normal ureter.
  • Bladder injury usually presents with decreased output, hematuria, or urinary leak from the vault.
  • Management of postoperative ureteric injury:
    • CT urogram and a urinalysis.
    • If an obstruction is noted on a CT scan, it is usually present near the ureterovesical junction. The immediate step is the attempted passage of a stent through the ureter under cystoscopic guidance. If a catheter can be passed through the ureter, it should be left in place for at least 4 to 6 weeks, allowing sutures to absorb and the obstruction or kinking to release.
    • If the catheter cannot be passed through the ureter, the best course is to perform abdominal exploratory surgery and repair the ureter at the site of obstruction.
    • A temporary percutaneous nephrostomy tube may be considered if exploratory surgery cannot be performed immediately.

Option A: Acute renal failure

  • Acute renal failure causes the following symptoms:
    • Oliguria.
    • Oedema.
    • Fatigue or tiredness.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Confusion.
    • Nausea.
    • Seizures or comas in severe cases.
    • Chest pain or pressure.
  • Progressive flank pain is not a symptom of acute renal failure.

Option C: Bladder injury

  • It is a false statement as bladder injury causes hematuria, not oliguria, and flank pain is unrelated to bladder injury.

Option D: Haemorrhage

  • Bleeding is not related to progressive flank pain. It may cause anaemia, hypovolemia, shock etc.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of amenorrhea. On her examination and imaging, all Mullerian derivatives are absent and she is diagnosed to have mullerian agenesis.  Which one of the following is correct about this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Wide array of uterine abnormalities

  • The case discussed above is Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser's (MRHK) syndrome.
  • It is a condition where the Mullerian duct is not formed; hence, its derivates like vagina, uterus and tubes are not made. The ovary is spared because it is formed from the genital ridge. It is also known as Mullerian agenesis.
  • It occurs in 1:5000–1:20,000 women.
  • Features include:
    • Primary Amenorrhoea.
    • Partial or complete absence of the vagina.
    • A wide array of uterine abnormalities.
    • Skeletal/renal and other associated abnormalities.
    • A normal female appearance and secondary sexual characteristics.
    • Normal 46 XX karyotype.
  • The ovaries are anatomically and functionally normal. The uterus is represented by a nodule (rudimentary uterus) with a hypoplastic or dimple vagina.
  • Treatment can be nonsurgical or surgical. 

Option A: Presence of normal vagina

  • There is a complete absence of a vagina in Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser's (MRHK) syndrome. As the Mullerian duct is not formed, its derivates like vagina, uterus and tubes are not made.

Option C: Wide array of ovarian abnormalities

  • There are no ovarian abnormalities in Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser's (MRHK) syndrome. The ovary is spared because it is formed from the genital ridge.

Option D: 47 XXY karyotype

  • Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser (MRHK) syndrome has a normal 46 XX karyotype.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a male baby at 37 weeks of gestation at home. After ten days, the parents brought the baby to a local hospital due to the baby's refusal to feed. The mother reveals that the baby did not receive any vaccinations until now. The pediatrician recommends polio vaccination. When was the baby supposed to get his first dose?
questions.solution:
Option B: At birth

  • OPV zero dose: Given at birth / as early as possible within the first 15 days of life.
  • LATEST NATIONAL IMMUNIZATION SCHEDULE (NIS): 2019
Vaccine Schedule
Pentavalent (DPT + Hep B + Hib), OPV 6 weeks, 10 weeks and 14 weeks
Measles and Vitamin A 9-12 months
DPT booster, OPV booster, Measles2* 16-24 months

Option A: Before giving DPT

  • DTaP vaccine can prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussispertussis. Diphtheria and pertussis spread from person to person.
  • Tetanus enters the body through cuts or wounds. DIPHTHERIA (D) can lead to difficulty breathing, heart failure, paralysis, or death.
  • Vaccine schedule: Give one dose at each age: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 through 18 months, and 4 through 6 years.
  • DPT can also be given in combination with the polio vaccine.

Option C: When the child has diarrhoea

  • Symptoms of polio start with Flu-like symptoms such as headache, sore throat, nausea, diarrhoea, fever, and fatigue are characteristics of abortive polio.
  • Abortive poliomyelitis, a mild viremic form, accounts for around 4% to 8% of infections.
  • There may be gastroenteritis, influenza-like illness, and mild respiratory tract infections, which usually subside within 1 week.
  •  Around 1% of the clinical cases present as aseptic meningitis.

Option D: When the child has polio

  • Children usually get the inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) at ages 2 months, 4 months, 6–18 months, and 4–6 years.
  • Sometimes IPV is given in a combination vaccine along with other vaccines. In this case, a child might receive a fifth dose of IPV. This is safe.
  • Infants and young children are at the greatest risk. Poliovirus infections are more common during the summer and autumn seasons.
  • The risk for paralysis from the virus increases with age.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with sudden abdominal distension and generalized swelling for 2 days. Examination shows generalized edema, positive shifting dullness, and normal vitals. Renal function tests are normal, but urine analysis reveals significant proteinuria. What is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: Minimal change disease

  • Generalised oedema in a 4-year-old child with massive proteinuria but no hypertension, haematuria & normal renal function suggests a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change in disease.
  • It is also known as lipoid nephrosis or nil disease
  • The underlying cause of MCD is systemic T-cell dysfunction resulting in a glomerular permeability factor. This circulating factor directly damages the glomerular capillary wall, resulting in marked proteinuria and foot process effacement. 
  • Sudden onset over days to a week or two of the signs and symptoms of the nephrotic syndrome, often following an upper respiratory or systemic infection.

Option A: Membranous glomerulonephritis

  • Onset is insidious
  • The mesangium is normal, with no hypercellularity, and all glomeruli are involved. The capillary walls are thick with patent capillary lumina.
  •  Sub-epithelial deposits are visualised.

Option C: Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

  • A history suggestive of preceding streptococcal infection may include a preceding infective episode such as pharyngitis, tonsillitis, or pyoderma.
  • Haematuria is often the first clinical manifestation of PSGN.

Option D: IgA Nephropathy

  • The disease is mostly associated with upper respiratory tract infections, mostly acute pharyngotonsillitis.
  • Gross hematuria appears within the first 48-72 hours after the infection begins, persists for less than 3 days and is accompanied by loin pain, presumably due to renal capsular swelling.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to the hospital with a complaint of immaturity in his voice. On examination, you made a provisional diagnosis of delayed puberty. Which of the following is the most common cause of delayed puberty?
questions.solution:
Option C: Constitutional

  • There are a lot of causes for delayed puberty. The most common cause is Constitutional.
  • Child's height is less than expected during childhood but normal final adult height is attained.
  • It is the most common cause of delayed puberty in boys more than in girls.
  • Lack of pubertal changes by 14 yrs of age.
  • Growth retardation & delayed bone age
  • Family history of delayed puberty is present
  • Bone Age < Chronological age

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of multiple pathological fractures. He has had a history of deafness for 3 months. Blood picture reveals Low phosphorus and calcium levels with normal Vitamin D levels and elevated PTH. The X-rays of the pelvis and ribs are shown in the images provided.. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Osteopetrosis

  • Osteopetrosis/ Marble bone disease:
  • Bone within bone appearance on X-ray (increased bone density)
  • Mutation in the CLCN7 gene leads to defective bone resorption
  • CLINICAL FEATURES
    • Neurological symptoms due to increased thickness of skull foramina.
    • Pancytopenia due to loss of bone marrow.
    • Risk of severe infections.
    • Macrocephaly, deafness.
    • Extramedullary hematopoiesis leading to hepatosplenomegaly.
  • X-ray findings: bone within bone appearance on X-ray
  • Investigation: Low phosphorus and calcium levels with normal Vitamin D levels and elevated PTH.

Low levels of phosphorus and calcium can occur in osteopetrosis due to the following reasons:

  1. Impaired bone remodeling: Osteopetrosis disrupts the normal balance between bone resorption and bone formation. With defective osteoclasts, bone resorption is impaired, leading to reduced release of calcium and phosphorus from the bones into the bloodstream.

  2. Altered mineralization: Osteopetrosis can affect the proper mineralization of bone tissue. Although bone density is increased, the mineral composition may be abnormal. This can lead to reduced availability of calcium and phosphorus, making them less accessible for maintaining appropriate levels in the bloodstream.

  3. Inefficient absorption: Osteopetrosis can also affect the absorption of calcium and phosphorus from the gastrointestinal tract. If the gastrointestinal system is not adequately absorbing these minerals from the diet, it can result in low levels in the bloodstream.

Option B: Osteomalacia

  • Looser zones are seen
  • Fractures at the proximal femur are commonly seen
  • Generalised muscle and bone weakness

Option C: Osteosclerosis

  • A generalised increase in bone density.
  • Involves both cortical and spongy bone
  • Physiologic osteosclerosis resolves in a few months after birth
  • Confused with disorders like osteopetrosis​​​​​​​

Option D: Histiocytosis X

  • Langerhans cell Histiocytosis can present with bone pains. However, it also presents with purplish papules and an eczematous rash.
  • X-ray in Histiocytosis shows well-defined, punched-out lytic lesions with sclerotic borders.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of mild abdominal pain and splenomegaly. She vomits blood occasionally. The child's growth parameters are within normal limits for age, and there is no history of jaundice, pruritus, or significant alcohol consumption in the family. Laboratory investigations reveal normal liver function tests, but ultrasonography shows evidence of portal hypertension and splenomegaly. An upper GI endoscopy shows the presence of esophageal varices. A liver biopsy rules out cirrhosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis (NCPF)

  • Clues in this Ques are: Upper GI bleeding, splenomegaly, no ascites or hepatomegaly, no jaundice: Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis.
  • Hematemesis (Upper GI bleed), Malena and splenomegaly are suggestive of portal hypertension due to non-cirrhotic causes.
  • Portal hypertension due to cirrhosis present with jaundice, ascites, hepatosplenomegaly and, less often, upper GI bleeding
  • Differences between cirrhotic and non-cirrhotic portal hypertension:
    • In Non-cirrhotic portal hypertension, a History of jaundice, oedema, ascites and overt hepatic encephalopathy are Not commonly seen.
    • There may be Splenomegaly  (Mild-moderate-massive).
    • The Synthetic function of the liver is Well preserved.
    • The transaminases may or may not be Deranged.

Option A: Budd-Chiari syndrome

  • Budd Chiari syndrome is hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction.
  • It is caused by thrombosis or compression due to some external aetiology.
  • It causes ascites and hepatomegaly due to symptoms of congestive liver disease and liver failure.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option C: Cirrhosis

  • Cirrhosis is due to a hepatitis cardiac region called cardiac cirrhosis.
  • It presents with ascites, abdominal discomfort and hepatomegaly.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option D: Veno-occlusive disease

  • When the small blood vessels inside the liver are blocked, it causes veno-occlusive disease, also known as called sinusoidal obstruction syndrome.
  • Chemotherapy or Radiation therapy ( at Higher doses) are the most common causes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravid woman at 35 weeks of gestation, presents to the outpatient department for a routine antenatal visit. The pregnancy was marked by an abnormal fetal ultrasound in the second trimester, showing mild edema and hepatosplenomegaly in the fetus. Further evaluation through amniocentesis confirmed the presence of a hematological disorder. Despite optimal prenatal care, she delivers a stillborn baby with more severe generalized edema. The woman is of Mediterranean descent. Her Indian husband's genetic screening reveals he is a carrier of the disorder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis that explains the fetal outcome?
questions.solution:
Option B: β-thalassemia

  • Beta thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by reduced or absent synthesis of hemoglobin beta chains, leading to severe anemia. In severe cases (thalassemia major), it can cause hepatosplenomegaly and anemia severe enough to lead to fetal or neonatal death. Edema can occur due to severe anemia, and it is a known complication of thalassemia major.

Option A: α-thalassemia

  • Alpha thalassemia typically presents with mild anemia and usually does not cause enlargement of the liver and spleen (hepatosplenomegaly) in the fetus or newborn. It does not directly lead to edema all over the body.

Option C: Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Heredity spherocytosis is an inherited disorder.
  • It is characterized by hemolytic anemia.
  • Other symptoms include paler, jaundice, gallstones and splenomegaly.

Option D: ABO incompatibility

  • ABO incompatibility might lead to sudden death.
  • But in ABO, incompatibility history of blood transfusion is significant.
  • It may not directly lead to hepatosplenomegaly and widespread edema.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought by his parents to the outpatient with complaints of changes in distal fingers and nails of the hand. His parents also report that he develops bluish discolouration of the skin upon playing. He is a known case of  ventricular septal defect (VSD); surgical correction of the defect was advised, but his parents denied surgery. The patient was born full-term at 38 weeks gestation to a 24-year-old primigravida woman via normal vaginal delivery. He has met all the developmental milestones. He is up to date with his current vaccination. On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 98/70 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88/min, and his respiratory rate is 18/min. Hand examination shows swelling of distal fingers along with nail clubbing, as shown below in the image. Cardiac examination shows a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border and a loud P2 component of the second heart sound S2. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Option B: Eisenmenger syndrome

  • This patient's presentation, including swelling of the fingers, clubbing of the nails, and cyanosis with an established diagnosis of the ventricular septal defect (VSD), is highly suggestive of Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Eisenmenger syndrome: Any untreated congenital cardiac defect with intracardiac communication that leads to pulmonary hypertension and causes reversal of shunt (left-to-right to right-to-left shunt) with subsequent development of cyanosis is called Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Features of Eisenmenger syndrome: Greyish or bluish discolouration of the skin, clubbing of the nails, swelling of distal fingers, chest pain, and coughing up blood.

Ventricular septal defect (VSD):

  • VSD is an abnormal opening in the interventricular septum, causing the blood to flow from the left to the right side of the heart.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic and heal spontaneously with age, but large VSDs are medically and/or surgically treated.  
  • Unrepaired, large VSD results in permanent pulmonary hypertension with resultant Eisenmenger syndrome.
  • Holosystolic murmur may also be heard on auscultation.

Option  A: Infective endocarditis

  • Infective endocarditis presents with VSD, clubbing without cyanosis, along with fever.
  • This patient is afebrile, and clubbing is associated with cyanosis, which is more consistent with Eisenmenger syndrome.

Option C: Cyanotic spell

  • Episodic central cyanosis due to total occlusion of right ventricle outflow in a patient with congenital heart disease such as Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is called a cyanotic spell.
  • Clubbing with cyanosis in the setting of VSD is more consistent with Eisenmenger syndrome.

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus

  • The persistence of the connection between the pulmonary artery & aorta after birth is called patent ductus arteriosus.
  • It presents with continuous machinery murmur, not with holosystolic murmur.

questions.text: A preterm neonate delivered at 32 weeks with very low birth weight develops hypoxia and respiratory distress. On examination, his lips and extremities were cyanosed and cold. He needed an emergency transfer to the NICU for neonatal resuscitation. Which of the following is considered while resuscitating the neonate?

choices.text: Self-inflating bag should not be used without a reservoir
Self-inflating bag cannot deliver free-flow oxygen
A flow-inflating bag can deliver free-flow oxygen

questions.solution:
Option A: T-tube delivers free-flow oxygen

  • In neonatal resuscitation, a t-tube delivers free-flow oxygen.
  • It is used as a primary resuscitation device in newborns.
  • It uses high resistance expiratory valve to produce positive end-expiratory pressure.
  • It provides prolonged inflation breaths.

Option B: Self-inflating bag should not be used without a reservoir

  • Self-inflating bag can be used without a reservoir, but FiO2 delivered will be less.
  • The reservoir is used for spontaneously breathing patients.

Option C: Self-inflating bag cannot deliver free-flow oxygen

  • Self-inflating bag can deliver free-flow oxygen.
  • It delivers free-flow oxygen when closed but not tightly closed to the infant's face.

Option D: Flow inflating bag can deliver free flow oxygen

  • Flow-inflating bags can deliver free-flow oxygen.
  • Though inflating flow bag requires a constant fresh flow of oxygen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx for the past month. He is a chronic smoker and has a 15-pack-year smoking history. After further examination, the biopsy revealed glottic laryngeal carcinoma limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and no regional lymph node metastasis. Which of the following is the best treatment for this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Concurrent chemoradiation

This patient has hoarseness and foreign body sensation, with a biopsy showing T3N0 stage glottic laryngeal carcinoma. The treatment is best done with concurrent chemoradiation therapy.

Treatment of glottic cancer is done as follows:

  • T1/T2 stage
    • Radiotherapy
    • Follow-up of 6 weeks required
  • T1a stage
    • Laser cordotomy
  • T3 stage
    • Concurrent chemoradiotherapy: To avoid total laryngectomy in stage III and IV glottic laryngeal cancers, induction chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy or concurrent chemoradiation showed better locoregional control of disease than laryngectomy with postoperative radiotherapy. Also, it helps to preserve the laryngeal function.
  • Exception (where surgery is used)
    • Bulky lesion
    • Associated lymph nodes
    • Multiple sites involvement
  • T4a stage
    • Combined modality
    • Surgery with chemotherapy & radiotherapy

Option A: Radical radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy

  • To avoid total laryngectomy in stage III and IV glottic laryngeal cancers, induction chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy or concurrent chemoradiation showed better locoregional control of disease than laryngectomy with postoperative radiotherapy

Option B: Radical radiotherapy without chemotherapy

  • Curative radiotherapy is reserved for early lesions (T1 and T2) that neither impair cord mobility nor invade cartilage or cervical nodes.
  • It does not give good results in lesions with fixed cords, subglottic extension, cartilage invasion, and nodal metastases. These lesions require surgery or concurrent chemoradiation as it preserves the speech and prevents total laryngectomy.

Option C: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery

  • Chemotherapy followed by surgery is done for advanced tumors with nodal metastases and cartilage involvement (T4).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with hoarseness of voice for the last two days. Two weeks ago, he was admitted to the intensive care unit due to a COVID-19 infection complicated by respiratory failure. He underwent endotracheal intubation and was kept on mechanical ventilation. On a laryngoscopy, he is found to have the following lesion:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Intubation granuloma

  • The picture shows mass involving the vocal process of arytenoid - typical of Intubation Granuloma.
  • These are formed by the proliferation of granulation tissue with epithelial hyperplasia.
  • They result from injury to the thin mucoperichondrium over the vocal processes from mechanical trauma, either following intubation or from the repeated high-velocity impact of the vocal processes against each other from throat clearing, coughing, or talking in a habitually low-pitched, creaky, hyper-functional manner.
  • They may be unilateral or bilateral and range from a nodular, diffuse thickening over the vocal process to large pedunculated, exophytic masses obscuring the posterior glottis.
  • Patients with a change in voice and vocal fatigue, a constant tickling sensation, discomfort, or pain localized to the posterosuperior aspect of the larynx, worsens phonation, coughing, and throat clearing. Pain can radiate to the ear.
  • The main treatment principles include reducing the effects of laryngeal irritants, i.e., stopping smoking, improving vocal hygiene, treating any respiratory tract infections, allergies, and gastroesophageal reflux.
  • Voice therapy has also shown some benefits.

Option A: Carcinoma of the larynx

This is false because:

  • Carcinoma of the larynx is less likely in this patient with a recent history of intubation.
  • Patients can present with a long history of hoarseness, weight loss, and smoking.
  • Diagnosis can be made by direct visualization using laryngoscopy followed by biopsy and CT scan to check for metastasis.

Option B: Vocal Nodules

This is false because:

  • Vocal nodules are benign growths that form on vocal folds.
  • Over time the vocal nodules become hard and callous.
  • Patients usually have a history of voice overuse.

Option C: Laryngomalacia

This is false because:

  • Laryngomalacia is defined as increased laxity of supraglottic structures.
  • Clinical presentation of laryngomalacia begins during the neonatal period and presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens when supine and improves in the prone position.
  • Laryngoscopy shows the collapse of the supraglottic structure with inspiration and omega-shaped epiglottis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic due to pain in her throat and upper neck for 2 weeks. The pain is sudden in onset, sharp radiates to the right ear, and gets aggravated on swallowing. The lateral skull x-ray of the patient is shown below:



What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Eagle syndrome

  • Eagle syndrome is due to an elongated (>3cm) styloid process or calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.
  • It is also called styalgia.
  • The patient usually complains of sharp nerve pain in the tonsillar fossa and upper neck, which radiates to the ipsilateral ear.
  • The pain aggravates with swallowing, jaw, and neck movement.
  • Other symptoms include difficulty swallowing, foreign object sensation in the throat, and ringing in the ears.
  • The vascular form of Eagle syndrome presents with a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke due to impingement of the styloid process onto the internal carotid artery.
  • Compression of the internal jugular vein may lead to increased intracranial pressure sometimes.
  • Diagnosis can be made by transoral palpation of the styloid process in the tonsillar fossa and by an anteroposterior view radiograph with an open mouth or lateral view radiograph of the skull.
  • Treatment is by partial styloidectomy transoral or cervical approach.

Option B: Apert syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Apert syndrome, also known as type I acrocephalosyndactyly, is a syndrome that is predominantly characterized by skull and limb malformations.
  • Radiographic features of Apert syndrome include:
    • Craniofacial: Craniosynostosis(brachycephaly); facial hypoplasia
    • Limb: Syndactyly (tends to be complex)

Option C: Stickler syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Stickler syndrome (hereditary progressive arthro-ophthalmodystrophy) is a group of rare genetic disorders affecting connective tissue, specifically collagen.
  • Stickler syndrome is a subtype of collagenopathy, types II and XI.
  • It presents as prominent eyes, a small nose, and a receding chin giving a scooped-out appearance of the face.
  • No involvement of the styloid process is seen.

Option D: Usher syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Usher syndrome (USH) is the leading genetic cause of combined hearing and vision loss.
  • No involvement of the styloid process is seen.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the office with complaints of headaches more during the daytime. X-ray paranasal sinuses reveal the following finding:





Which of the following is not true about the lesion?

choices.text: The most common site is the frontal sinus

questions.solution:
Option C: Does not grow into orbit

  • The picture gives a radio-opaque mass arising in left frontal sinus. It must be a bone-forming tumour that gives it the radio-opaque appearance, so it is a Frontal Osteoma.
  • Well-circumscribed, sharply-marginated round and very dense lesions, usually less than 2 cm in size.
  • Usually grow into the sinus.
  • It grows into the orbits as well.

Osteoma

  • Most commonly seen in the frontal sinus.
  • Most common tumour of the paranasal sinuses.
  • Most frequently seen in the frontal and ethmoid sinuses.
  • The benign tumour of membranous bone consists of dense, compact bone.
  • They may remain asymptomatic, being discovered incidentally on X-rays.
  • Treatment is indicated when they become symptomatic, obstructing sinus ostium, mucocele formation due to blocking of ostium or when they erode through the dura causing intracranial infection or CSF rhinorrhea.
  • The selection of surgical resection method depends on tumour location.
  • Patients should be observed for recurrence with periodic examinations and imaging techniques.
  • Follow-up should be performed at least at 1-year intervals after the surgery.

  • The lesion is well-circumscribed and consists of dense, mature cortical bone.
  • Osteomas are classified into compact (cortical) and spongy (trabecular) types.
  • Multiple osteomas are seen in the setting of Gardner syndrome, an autosomal-dominant disorder characterized by gastrointestinal (G.I.) polyps and skin and soft tissue tumours. The G.I. polyps have a 100% risk of undergoing malignant transformation.

Option A: The most common site is the frontal sinus

  • Although the statement that the frontal sinus is the most common site is true, the question asks what statement is false.

Option B: May remain asymptomatic

  • Although the statement is true that many osteomas remain asymptomatic, the question asks for the false statement.

Option D: Treat when symptomatic

  • Although the statement is correct that osteomas are treated when they become symptomatic, it is not the correct answer as the question asks for the wrong statement.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came to the ENT outpatient department with a complaint of dizziness while waking up from the bed. The patient has no hearing loss and ringing ears. The patient has no family history of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, or others. He had an appendectomy operation at the age of 35. The patient is a non-smoker. On physical examination, the patient developed nystagmus in the below-depicted maneuver. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vestibular exercises

  • 80 % of BPPV (Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) cases can be treated with Epley's maneuver, which is a vestibular exercise.

Epley’s maneuver:

  • The principle of this maneuver is to reposition the otoconial debris from the posterior semi-circular canal back into the utricle. The doctor stands behind the patient and the assistant on the side. The patient is made to sit on the table so that when he is made to lie down, his head is beyond the edge of the table, as is done in the Dix-Hallpike maneuver. His face is turned 45° to the affected side.
    • The image depicted here is the Dix-hall pike maneuver.
    • The most common cause of peripheral vertigo.
    • It occurs during sudden head movements - lasts for a sec to a few minutes.
    • Due to faulty otoconia in the semi-circular ampulla.
    • Treatment: Vestibular exercises, Epley's maneuver
  • The maneuver consists of five positions:
    • Position 1: With the head turned 45°, the patient is made to lie down in a head-hanging position (Dix-Hallpike). It will cause vertigo and nystagmus. Wait till vertigo and nystagmus subside.
    • Position 2: The Head is now turned so that the affected ear is facing up at a 90° rotation.
    • Position 3: The whole body and head are now rotated away from the affected ear to a lateral recumbent position in a 90° -rotation face-down position.
    • Position 4: The patient is now brought to a sitting position with the head still turned to the unaffected side by 45°.
    • Position 5: The head is now turned forward, and the chin is brought down.

Option B: Vestibular sedatives

  • The drugs used to sedate the vestibular labyrinth are called vestibular sedatives or anti-vertigo drugs. These drugs do much more harm than benefit and can only provide temporary relief from the symptom of acute vertigo or head spinning.

Option C: Antihistamine

  • Antihistamines are medicines that work against or block histamine. Antihistamines suppress the histamine-induced wheal response (swelling) and flare response (vasodilation) by blocking the binding of histamine to its receptors or reducing histamine receptor activity on nerves, vascular smooth muscle, glandular cells, endothelium, and mast cells.

Option D: Diuretics

  • Diuretics (also called water pills or fluid pills) increase the amount of urine you produce. It relieves symptoms such as ankle swelling and helps to lower blood pressure. The three main types of diuretics are thiazides, loop diuretics, and potassium-sparing diuretics.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to ENT OPD with complaints of facial weakness for 2 weeks. After investigation and examinations, the patient was diagnosed with Bell's palsy after excluding all other causes. He was on steroids for 2 weeks, but it showed no improvement. What would be the next best step in managing patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option D: Electrophysiological nerve testing

  • This is a case of Bell's palsy caused to due facial nerve injury.
  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.
  • This test's most clinically helpful use is to objectively assess facial nerve function once spontaneous motion is lost in acquired paralysis or if it had never been seen in congenital paralysis. The test is not an absolute predictor for return of function but, when used with clinical information, makes the assessment of prognosis more rational.
  • ENoG is most useful between the 4th and 21st day of the onset of complete paralysis.
  • The fall of summating potential to 10% of the normal value indicates surgical decompression (90% degeneration).
  • Degeneration of 90% occurring in the first 14 days indicates poor recovery of function.
  • A faster rate of degeneration occurring in <14 days has a poorer prognosis.

Medical management of Bell's palsy

Steroids:

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If the patient reports within 1 week, the adult prednisolone dose is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. The patient is seen on the fifth day.
  • If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered in the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and tapered in the next 5 days (a total of 20 days).
  • Contraindications to using steroids include pregnancy, diabetes, hypertension, peptic ulcer, pulmonary tuberculosis, and glaucoma.

Surgical Treatment:

  • Nerve decompression relieves pressure on the nerve fibers and thus improves nerve microcirculation.
  • Vertical and tympanic segments of the nerve are decompressed. Some workers have suggested total decompression, including labyrinthine segment by postural and middle fossa approach.
  • 80-90% of the patients recover fully. 10-15% recover incompletely and may be left with some stigmata of degeneration. Recurrent facial palsy may not recover fully.
  • The prognosis is good in incomplete Bell’s palsy (95% complete recovery) and in those where clinical recovery starts within 3 weeks of onset (75% complete recovery).

 Option A: Physiotherapy

  • It is a false statement.
  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.

Option B: Stop steroids abruptly

  • It is a false statement.
  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.

Option C: Vasodilators

  • It is a false statement.

  • For 2 weeks, the patient has been on steroids; an ENoG on day 14 can help us know if there is a faster degeneration of the nerve and predict the prognosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of progressive hearing loss in her left ear over the past few months. On examination, a tuning fork test reveals bilateral conductive hearing loss, worse in the left ear. There are no signs of middle ear infection or fluid. Pure-tone audiometry confirms bilateral conductive hearing loss, and speech discrimination is normal. The Rinne test shows a positive result in the right ear and a negative result in the left ear. Weber test lateralizes to the right ear. The patient has no history of recurrent ear infections. She denies any recent trauma or exposure to loud noise. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case presents a young female with progressive hearing loss and bilateral conductive hearing loss, worse in the left ear. The tuning fork test and Rinne test results are consistent with conductive hearing loss on the left side. The Weber test lateralizes to the right ear, suggesting that the right ear has better hearing compared to the left.

The presence of bilateral conductive hearing loss without any signs of middle ear infection or fluid points towards a chronic, non-inflammatory condition affecting the middle ear. Additionally, the absence of recurrent ear infections or recent trauma excludes options D (Cholesteatoma)

A) Meniere's disease is characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It typically presents unilaterally. The patient in this case does not have vertigo or sensorineural hearing loss, making Meniere's disease less likely.

B) Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is a benign tumor that can cause unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, along with tinnitus and imbalance. Bilateral conductive hearing loss, as seen in this patient, is not typical of acoustic neuroma.

C) Otosclerosis is the most likely diagnosis in this case. It is a condition characterized by abnormal bone growth in the middle ear, specifically around the stapes footplate. This can lead to progressive conductive hearing loss. The Rinne test result showing a negative result on the left (bone conduction better than air conduction) is typical of otosclerosis.

Correct Answer: C) Otosclerosis

Management for otosclerosis may involve hearing aids or surgical intervention, such as a stapedectomy, to improve hearing. Regular follow-up and counseling regarding the condition's progression are also crucial for the patient's long-term care.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to recurrent, profuse bleeding from the nasal cavity for 1 day. He had undergone surgery for a profuse nasal bleed 10 days ago. Also, surgery was performed for conductive deafness in the right year. The picture below shows the surgical findings of the right ear:



Which of the following is the most likely cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Juvenile angiofibroma

  • Juvenile angiofibroma (JA) is a unique tumour presenting almost exclusively in adolescent males.
  • It is an androgen-dependent tumour.
  • Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation of juvenile angiofibromas in young adolescent males.
  • Conductive hearing loss occurs due to obstruction of the eustachian tube resulting in serous otitis media.
  • The picture shows grommet insertion done along with surgery of juvenile angiofibromas to treat serous otitis media.
  • The tumour usually arises from the lateral wall of the posterior nasal cavity close to the sphenopalatine foramen and the pterygoid base.
  • It is a vascular tumour most commonly supplied by the sphenopalatine artery.
  • A biopsy is contraindicated since it might precipitate bleeding.
  • Due to this location, nasal obstruction and nasal bleeding may be symptoms presented by adolescents.
  • Although the tumour is histopathologically classified as a benign lesion, bony erosions of the pterygoid, the clivus, and the sphenoid sinus floor are common hallmarks of juvenile angiofibromas.
  • Holman-Miller sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior maxillary wall seen on a CT scan (shown above).
  • It is locally invasive, invading the cheek, orbit, brain, nose
  • The tumour grows into the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, and pterygopalatine fossa, running behind the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, pushing forward as the tumour grows.
  • Laterally it extends into the pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, and cheek.
  • Juvenile angiofibroma is best treated by surgical excision.
  • Patients with advanced and recurrent Juvenile angiofibromas thought not to be amenable to complete resection with acceptable morbidity are treated with radiotherapy.

Option A: Adenoiditis

  • Adenoids present as:
    • Bilateral nasal obstruction resulting in mouth breathing and high-arched palate
    • Adenoid facies
    • Elongated face, pinched nose
    • Overcrowding of anterior teeth
    • Bilateral serous otitis media→ Bilateral conductive hearing loss
    • Recurrent upper respiratory infection
    • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • It does not present with nasal bleeding.
  • Treatment is with adenoidectomy alone.

Option C: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents as:
    • Neck mass (usually high-level V and level II)
    • Otitis media with effusion/Eustachian tube dysfunction
    • Unilateral hearing loss
    • Blood in saliva
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Tinnitus
    • Cranial nerve palsy
  • Treatment Options
    • State I-II: Radiation alone
    • Stage III-IV: Chemoradiation
    • Persistent disease: Salvage surgery
    • Recurrent disease: Reirradiation or salvage surgery
  • It does not present with nasal bleeding.

Option D: Thornwaldt's bursitis

  • Thornwaldt's bursitis is a cystic and fluctuant swelling in the posterior wall of the nasopharynx.
  • It presents as follows:
    • Persistent postnasal discharge with crusting in the nasopharynx.
    • Nasal obstruction due to swelling in the nasopharynx.
    • Obstruction to eustachian tube and serous otitis media.
    • Dull type of occipital headache.
    • Recurrent sore throat.
    • Low-grade fever
  • Treatment: Antibiotics are given to treat infection, marsupialization of the cystic swelling, and adequate removal of its lining membrane.
  • It does not present with nasal bleeding.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought by his mother to Ophthalmology OPD with an abnormal head posture while reading and writing. He is not having any pain or other complaints. On examination, the right eye shows Entropia. The doctor suspects it to be strabismus. A refraction test is advised for further evaluation and confirmation of this condition and measurement of its angle. Which of the following drug is used before doing this test?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atropine

  • The most common cause of squint in children is accommodative esotropia, i.e. due to uncorrected refractive error, which in children is mostly hypermetropia.
  • So for refraction testing, we need the cycloplegic drug to paralyze the ciliary muscles and reveal the true refraction of the child.
  • This drug is used to both prevent and treat specific eye problems as well as eye exams like refraction and such as uveitis.
  • It is a member of the anticholinergic drug family.
  • The smaller the children, the more powerful the accommodation.
  • The most powerful cycloplegic drug is atropine, which is indicated in children below 5 years old.

Option A: Pilocarpine

  • Glaucoma and other eye diseases are managed with pilocarpine.
  • It is also used To treat presbyopia and utilize eye drops (age-related eye or vision problems).
  • Pilocarpine is parasympathomimetic and thus not used.

Option C: Tropicamide

  • Tropicamide is less potent than cycloplegic.
  • Tropicamide is used to dilate (enlarge) the pupil so the medical professional can see behind your eye.
  • It is used before eye examinations like cycloplegic refraction and fundus examinations.
  • Tropicamide can be applied both before and following eye surgery.

Option D: Lidocaine

  • Lidocaine is a member of the class of drugs known as local anesthetics.
  • Before several surgeries, this medication is injected into the eye to create numbness or lack of feeling.
  • It functions by obstructing the signals at the eye's nerve terminals.
  • Lidocaine is a local anesthetic and not a cycloplegic.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with recent onset photophobia within 24 hours and a sloughing corneal ulcer. There is a greenish ulcer base. Which of the following can be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pseudomonas

  • Pseudomonas Ulcer
    • Rapid onset & Greenish ulcer base.
    • Produce biofilm that causes resistance.
    • Most common cause of infection in contact lens users.

Option A: Nocardia

  • Nocardia is a rare cause of ocular infections. Ocular infections caused by Nocardia include keratitis, scleritis, conjunctivitis, canaliculitis, dacrocystitis, orbital cellulitis, and endophthalmitis. Corneal infections are the most common.
  • The diagnosis is often missed or delayed as the clinical picture may resemble other causative organisms.
  • Patients often suffer from significant ocular morbidity for a prolonged period before an accurate diagnosis is made.
  • Nocardia infections do not respond to commonly used first-line medications for bacterial keratitis, such as fluoroquinolones. With the initiation of appropriate therapy, Nocardia infections respond promptly and carry a good prognosis.​​​​​​​
  • This patient has a pseudomonas ulcer based on the presentation.

Option B: Herpes

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a very common, lifelong infection that often is asymptomatic.
  • Ocular manifestations of HSV- I and HSV- II include blepharoconjunctivitis, epithelial keratitis, stromal keratitis (necrotizing or non-necrotizing), iridocyclitis, and/or acute retinal necrosis.​​​​​​​
  • This patient has a pseudomonas ulcer based on the presentation.

Option D: Acanthamoeba

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis, first recognized in 1973, is a rare, vision-threatening, parasitic infection seen most often in contact lens wearers.
  • It is often characterized by pain out of proportion to findings and the late clinical appearance of a stromal ring-shaped infiltrate. It is both difficult to diagnose and difficult to treat.​​​​​​​
  • This patient has a pseudomonas ulcer based on the presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the ophthalmology department with three days history of mild irritation, watering, and localized redness in the right eye, as shown below. Her past medical history reveals that she is a known case of hypertension and takes lisinopril 5mg daily. On history, it is confirmed that she is compliant with her medication. Her blood pressure at the visit is 125/85 mmHg. The resident ophthalmologist wants to differentiate between scleritis and episcleritis. He instills 10% phenylephrine, and there is quick blanching of the vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nodular episcleritis:

  • The image shows a purplish nodule on the medial epicanthus with surrounding injected blood vessels.
  • They are not reaching the limbus, though.
  • This is a presentation of nodular episcleritis.
  • Vasoconstricting eye drops (phenylephrine) allow episcleritis to be differentiated from scleritis. They cause blanching of the vessels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior uveitis:

  • It affects the iris at the front of the eye and not the medial epicanthus with surrounding injected blood vessels.

Option B - Nodular scleritis:

  • Phenylephrine drops do not cause blanching of the vessels in scleritis.
  • There is a blue coloration of the eyes (deep inflammation).

Option D - Scleromalacia perforans:

  • Scleromalacia perforans is an anterior necrotizing scleritis without inflammation.
  • It is a rare eye disorder causing damage to episcleral and scleral vessels.
  • Usually associated with autoimmune disorders.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man was referred to your clinic for evaluation of a shallow anterior chamber in both eyes. The causes of the Shallow Anterior chamber in this patient could be all except?

choices.text: Pupil block due to vitreous bulge after Intra Capsular Cataract Extraction

questions.solution:
Option D: Pathological Myopia

  • Pathological myopia causes a deep anterior chamber.
  • Small axial length causes a shallow anterior chamber.
  • Pupil block also would decrease it by doing pupillary block as it would do the bulge. AC would be shallow in the periphery.
  • Iris bombe also causes protrusion of the iris and shallow AC.
  • Aphakia & myopia have a deep Anterior Chamber.
  • In aphakic patients, there will be H/O of limbal surgery (scar on limbus), JET BLACK pupil and tremulousness of iris k/a iridodonesis along with the deep anterior chamber.

Option A: Hypermetropia with small axial length

  • In hypermetropia, the cornea is flatter, or the axial length is too short. Therefore, the images do not focus by the time they reach the retina. For clear vision, a hypermetropic eye must accommodate to increase its lenticular power to bring distant objects into focus on the retina.
  • Axial length (AL) is the combination of anterior chamber depth, lens thickness and vitreous chamber depth, and it is the most significant contributor to refractive error. Myopia results from an increase in AL outside of the normal rate expected for age.
  • Axial hypermetropia is the commonest type. The total refractive power of the eye is normal, but there is an axial shortening of the eyeball. About 1 mm shortening of the anteroposterior length of the eye results in about 3 Dioptres (D) of hypermetropia.
  • Thus the concave lens is used to correct myopia, and the convex lens is used to correct hypermetropia.

Option B: Pupil block due to vitreous bulge after IntraCapsular Cataract Extraction

  • Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) involves the removal of the lens and the surrounding lens capsule in one piece. The procedure has a relatively high rate of complications due to the large incision required and the pressure placed on the vitreous body.
  • Pupillary block glaucoma may commonly occur secondary to Aphakia or pseudophakia with either anterior vitreous displacement, dislocated anterior or posterior intraocular lens, or pupillary capture by intraocular lens implant. Ectopia lentis. Phacomorphic glaucoma due to cataractous lens intumescence.
  • The definitive procedure to break the pupillary block is a peripheral iridectomy. This procedure can usually be accomplished using a laser, but sometimes, a surgical iridectomy may be necessary in the case of severe inflammation.

Option C: Iris Bombe

  • Iris bombe is a condition in which there is an apposition of the iris to the lens or anterior vitreous, preventing the aqueous from flowing from the posterior to the anterior chamber. The pressure in the posterior chamber rises, resulting in anterior bowing of the peripheral iris and obstruction of the trabecular meshwork.
  • Iris bombe is induced by the formation of the posterior synechiae and pupillary block. Because intraocular pressure (IOP) elevation during iris bombe is caused by angle closure, iridotomy is a treatment option for reducing IOP.
  • The iris bombe and pupillary block (due to synechiae to the IOL) could be treated noninvasively with laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI). Alternatively, surgical iridectomy and synechialysis (of posterior synechiae around the pupil) could be performed to relieve the pupillary block.
  • Laser iridotomy also called laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI), is a method by which ophthalmologists create a microscopic hole in the iris using a laser to open the angle (or internal drainage system of the eye) in patients with narrow or closed angles.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man who was recently diagnosed as a case of HIV positive was started on highly active antiretroviral therapy and presented to the eye OPD with the complaints of 'floaters' with painless diminution of vision associated with photophobia and mild redness. On ocular exam, inflammatory cells and opacities in the vitreous, edema of the retina, and choroid were observed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior uveitis

  • Based on the history, signs, and symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is posterior uveitis (Immune recovery uveitis).
  • With the initiation of HAART, there is an upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-2, IL-6, and TNF alfa, and the T lymphocyte fraction (increases to a range of 100 cells/mm3).
  • Present understanding is that with an increase in the body's mechanism to mount an immune response, the body mounts a response to previously quiet and hence undiagnosed opportunistic infections such as CMV retinitis.
  • Clinical manifestations can be varied and most commonly involve the posterior segment of the eye, though anterior, intermediate uveitis is also reported. Papillitis may also be a feature.
  • Inflammations of the posterior uvea exhibit the general characteristics of those affecting the anterior part of the uveal tract.
  • They may appear either in the form of isolated foci of inflammation or they may be diffuse.
  • The typical symptoms of posterior uveitis include the presence of 'floaters' with or without a diminution of vision, which is often painless but occasionally accompanied by pain, photophobia, and some redness if there is associated involvement of the anterior segment.
  • Signs include detectable inflammatory cells and opacities in the vitreous, exudates or infiltration in the retina or choroid, oedema of the retina and choroid, and sheathing of vessels.

Option A: Keratitis

  • Keratitis is a cornea inflammation characterized by corneal edema, cellular infiltration, and ciliary congestion. It is classified as.
  • Topographical (morphological) classification:
    • Ulcerative keratitis (corneal ulcer.
    • Non-ulcerative keratitis.
  • Etiological classification:
    • Infective keratitis.
    • Allergic keratitis.
    • Trophic keratitis
    • Keratitis is associated with diseases of the skin and mucous membranes.
    • Keratitis associated with systemic collagen vascular disorders.
    • Traumatic keratitis.
    • Idiopathic keratitis.

Option B: Anterior Uveitis

  • Though anterior uveitis almost always presents as a combined inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, the reaction may be more marked in the iris or ciliary body. Clinically it may present as acute or chronic anterior uveitis. The main symptoms of acute anterior uveitis are pain, photophobia, redness, lacrimation, and decreased vision. In chronic uveitis, however, the eye may be white with minimal symptoms, even signs of severe inflammation.
  • Clinical Features are as under:
    • Pain.
    • Redness.
    • Photophobia and blepharospasm.
    • Lacrimation.
    • Defective vision.
  • The following signs can be observed:
    • Lid edema.
    • Circumcorneal congestion.
    • Corneal edema.
    • Keratic precipitates.
    • Posterior corneal opacities.
    • Anterior chamber signs.
    • Aqueous cells.
    • Aqueous flare.
    • Hyphema.

Option D: Optic neuritis

  • Optic neuritis includes inflammatory and demyelinating disorders of the optic nerve.
  • Optic neuritis may be asymptomatic or may be associated with the following symptoms:
    • Visual loss.
    • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
    • Visual obscuration in bright light.
    • Impairment of color vision.
    • Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and exposure to heat.
    • Depth perception.
    • Pain.
  • Signs are as follows:
    • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
    • Color vision is often severely impaired.
    • The pupil shows ill-sustained constriction to light. Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is a diagnostic sign.
    • Hyperaemia of the disc and blurring of the margins.
    • Visual field changes. 
    • The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
    • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.
    • Visually evoked response (VER) shows reduced amplitude and delay in the transmission time.

Type

Site of inflammation

Synonyms

Anterior uveitis

Anterior chamber

Iritis

Iridocyclitis

Intermediate uveitis

Vitreous

Anterior cyclitis

Pars planitis

Posterior cyclitis

Hyalitis

Posterior uveitis

Retina and choroid

Focal or diffuse choroiditis

Chorioretinitis

Retinochoroiditis

Retinitis

Neuroretinitis

Panuveitis

Anterior chamber and vitreous and retina or choroid 

Diffuse

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of painful swelling of the left eye and rapidly progressive loss of vision for the past 1 week. She works in a nursing home. She is otherwise vitally stable. On examination of the left eye, proptosis, complete ophthalmoplegia with eyelid swelling and decreased vision were noted. The right eye was essentially normal. Which of the following is a complication of the diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Exposure keratopathy

  • The is a case of orbital cellulitis in which the patient presents with complaints of painful swelling of the left eye and rapidly progressive loss of vision for the past 1 week.
  • On examination of the left eye, proptosis, complete ophthalmoplegia with eyelid swelling and decreased vision were noted. The right eye was essentially normal.
  • Orbital cellulitis : Inflammation of soft tissue contained within the orbit.

  • Complications
    • Exposure keratopathy
    • Compression of the optic nerve
    • Central retinal artery occlusion
    • Orbital abscess
    • Intracranial spread of infections
    • Septicemia.

Option B: Bell’s palsy

  • Bell's palsy is partial or complete paralysis of the facial nerve.
  • It causes weakness in the unilateral side of the face.
  • It may be caused by herpes zoster virus, also known as Ramsay hunt syndrome.

Option C: Parotitis

  • Orbital cellulitis does not cause parotitis.
  • It is a painful swelling of the parotid gland.
  • Parotitis is most commonly caused by a virus such as mumps, herpes, or Epstein-Barr virus.

Option D: Retinal detachment

  • Retinal detachment is not a complication of orbital cellulitis.
  • The most common cause of retinal detachment is ageing.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man from Europe living in India presents to a physician with complaints of gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision for 1 month. He says he could earlier drive the car home by himself but cannot do so now. He is a retired navy officer. He is otherwise vitally stable. The fundus examination is given below. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Given the symptoms described (gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision) and the patient's age, the most likely diagnosis is age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is a common eye condition among people over 50 and can cause significant vision loss.

The best treatment modality for wet AMD, which is characterized by the growth of abnormal blood vessels behind the retina, is Anti-VEGF therapy. Anti-VEGF drugs (such as ranibizumab, aflibercept, or bevacizumab) are injected into the eye to inhibit the growth of these abnormal blood vessels, preserving the remaining vision and sometimes even improving sight. This approach has been a significant advancement in the management of wet AMD.

Therefore, the correct answer is

Option D. Anti-VEGF therapy.

Options A, B, and C are not appropriate treatments for wet AMD. Vitrectomy is a surgical procedure used for conditions involving the vitreous humor of the eye. Macular grid photocoagulation is a technique used in specific cases of diabetic macular edema and might not be suitable for wet AMD. Spontaneous healing is not a realistic option for progressive vision loss due to conditions like wet AMD.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to ER after her brother threw a caterpillar into her right eye. On examination, she has conjunctival redness, swelling and decreased vision. She also complains of ocular pain. The visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. Numerous caterpillar hairs are embedded in the periocular skin, eyelids, and the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva of the right eye. Which of the following is a likely complication seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ophthalmia nodosa

  • Conjunctival inflammatory nodule due to caterpillar hair or tarantula hair.
  • It can lead to chronic conjunctivitis and visually disabling corneal scars, cataracts, vitreous and macular edema.
  • Treatment: Removal of the offending agent and managing inflammation through topical anti-inflammatory agents such as NSAIDs and steroids with antibiotic cover to prevent secondary infections.

Option A: Intraocular melanoma

  • Malignant melanoma occurs typically at the limbus in older adults.
  • It spreads over the surface of the eyeball.
  • Recurrences and metastases occur elsewhere in the body commonly.
  • It is treated by enucleation of the globe or exenteration of the orbit in cases of extraocular extension.

Option C: Pterygium

  • Degenerative and hyperplastic condition of the conjunctiva.

Option D: Pinguecula

  • It is a triangular yellow patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus in the palpebral aperture.
  • It commonly occurs in elderly persons exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • It is seen first on the nasal side.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of a papule on his penis for the past few days. According to him, the lesions are painless and non-itchy. On examination, the lesion dimples on either side when squeezed. A central punctum is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Epidermal inclusion cyst

  • This patient lesion on the penis that has a central punctum most likely has an epidermal inclusion cyst.
  • Epidermoid cyst, also called an epidermal cyst, epidermal inclusion cyst, or, improperly, "sebaceous cyst," is the most common cutaneous cyst. It can occur anywhere on the body and typically presents as an asymptomatic, skin-colored dermal nodule, often with a clinically visible central punctum.
  • Epidermoid cysts may be primary or arise from the implantation of the follicular epithelium in the dermis due to trauma or from a comedo.
  • Lesions may remain stable or progressively enlarge. Spontaneous inflammation and rupture can occur, with significant involvement of surrounding tissue.
  • The diagnosis of epidermoid cyst is usually clinical, based upon the clinical appearance of a discrete cyst or nodule, often with a central punctum, that is freely movable on palpation.
  • Treatment of stable, uninfected epidermoid cysts is not necessary unless desired by the patient. Inflamed, ruptured cysts that are not infected may resolve spontaneously without therapy, although they tend to recur.
  • Injection of triamcinolone acetonide (3 mg/mL for the face and 10 mg/mL for the trunk) into the inflamed lesion can hasten the resolution of inflammation.
  • Excision of the lesion is the treatment of choice for lesions that are not inflamed.

Option A: Benign melanocytic nevus

  • Benign melanocytic nevus is a cutaneous condition characterized by well-circumscribed, round or ovoid lesions, generally measuring from 2 to 6 mm in diameter. It does not contain punctum.

Option B: Dermatofibroma

  • In dermatofibroma, the lesion is not well demarcated visually, is firm, and dimples downward when compressed laterally. This patient’s lesions are more suggestive of an inclusion cyst.

Option D: Keloids

  • Keloids are firm, rubbery lesions or shiny, fibrous nodules and vary from pink to color skin or red to dark brown. The punctum is absent. This patient most likely has an inclusion cyst.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old gravida-2, para-1 female, presents to the hospital at the 34th week of gestation with a complaint of sudden onset of multiple painful lesions almost all over her body for the past few hours. She also reports mild fever and fatigue. She also complains of bilateral knee joint pain. On general physical examination, her pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, temperature is 100.2°F, and respiratory rate is 18/min. On examination of the knee, there is no redness or swelling. Skin examination shows generalized vesiculobullous lesions that have pustular tips with a surrounding red hue, as shown in the image below: 



Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Prednisolone

This patient with mild fever, fatigue, arthralgia, and vesiculobullous lesions most likely has Impetigo Herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis of pregnancy)

Impetigo Herpetiformis:

  • Most of the patients have associated signs of toxicity such as fever, chills, leukocytosis, and lethargy.
  • When generalized, it is known as Von Zumbusch disease (whole body involved).
  • Von Zumbusch disease is the most severe type of psoriasis and can lead to death.
  • Impact on fetal outcome → placental insufficiency→ fetal abnormalities.
  • Systemic steroids are the drug of choice.
  • Systemic steroids (pregnancy B category) > Cyclosporine (pregnancy C category).
Indications of Systemic steroids in psoriasis
  1. Impetigo Herpetiformis
  2. Acute erythrodermic psoriasis
  3. Acute generalized pustular psoriasis
  4. Unstable psoriasis
  5. Severe cases of psoriatic arthritis

Option A: Dapsone

  • Leprosy (Hansen's disease) and dermatitis herpetiformis are treated with dapsone.

Option B: Isotretinoin

  • Oral retinoids are the treatment of choice in non-pregnant patients.

Option D: Methotrexate

  • Methotrexate is an immunosuppressant. It suppresses the immunological response. Rheumatoid arthritis is one of the inflammatory disorders for which methotrexate is used.

questions.text: A 25-day-old female child presents with a diffuse vesiculobullous rash localized to the extremities and the trunk, following the lines of blaschko. Pitted toenails are also found. The child had a history of seizures at birth. Which of the following is not a feature of this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Ocular involvement is seen in almost 100% of cases and is typically unilateral

questions.solution:
Option D: Ocular involvement is seen in almost 100% of cases and is typically unilateral

This patient, with diffuse vesiculobullous rash localized to the extremities and the trunk, following the lines of blaschko, pitted toenails, and a history of seizures on birth, most likely suffers from Incontinentia pigmenti.

  • Incontinentia pigmenti is an X-linked dominant condition.
  • Developmental defects of eye, teeth, CNS with cutaneous lesions.
  • Four clinical stages
    1. Inflammatory macules, papules, vesicle
    2. Hyperkeratotic & verrucous lesions
    3. Grey-brown pigmentation
    4. Atrophic, hypopigmented & depigmented
  • Initially hyperpigmented lesions; as it progresses towards the 4th stage, it becomes hypopigmented
  • Lesions follow the lines of blaschko
  • In this disease, ophthalmologic findings occur in 20-35% of patients, and asymmetric involvement is common. So, option D is not a feature.

Option A: X-linked dominant

  • Incontinentia pigmenti is an X-linked dominant condition.

Option B: Primary skin abnormality

  • Incontinentia pigmenti is a primary skin disorder.

Option C: Avascularity of the peripheral retina

  • Incontinentia pigmenti is characterized by retinal Vaso-occlusive events with resultant ischemia, the primary mechanism in ocular pathology.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of blistering skin lesions. On examination, skin blistering and denudation involving >30% of body surface areas are observed. There are erosions of the lips and oral cavity with hemorrhagic crusting. The lesions are shown below:



Keeping in view the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most common triggering factor of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Drug-induced

  • This patient with blistering skin lesions involving mucous membranes and greater than 30% body surface area most likely has toxic epidermal necrolysis.
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, most commonly triggered by medications, characterized by extensive necrosis and detachment of the epidermis. Mucous membranes are affected in over 90 percent of patients, usually at two or more distinct sites (ocular, oral, and genital).
  • According to a widely accepted classification, SJS and TEN are considered a disease continuum and are distinguished chiefly by severity, based upon the percentage of body surface affected by blisters and erosions:
    • SJS is the less severe condition, in which skin detachment is <10 percent of the body surface      
    • TEN involves detachment of >30 percent of the body surface area (BSA) 
    • SJS/TEN overlap describes patients with skin detachment of 10 to 30 percent of BSA.

  • Medications are the leading trigger of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) in both adults and children. The risk of SJS/TEN seems to be limited to the first eight weeks of treatment. Drugs used for a longer time are unlikely to be the cause of SJS/TEN. The typical exposure period before reaction onset is four days to four weeks of first continuous use of the drug. However, approximately 25 to 33 percent of cases, and probably an even higher proportion of pediatric cases, cannot be attributed to a drug.

Carbamazepine-induced SJS/TEN is associated with HLA B1502.

Category Names of the drugs
Antibiotics  Penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfonamides, macrolides, fluoroquinolones
Antiepileptics  Carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbitione, valproic acid, lamotrigine  
Miscellaneous  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (excluding oxicams), paracetamol, nimesulide  
Others  Allopurinol, nevirapine, ayurvedic and homeopathic medicines 

Option A: Bacterial infection

  • The most common causative factor for TEN is medication intake. Although mycoplasma pneumoniae infection can cause toxic epidermal necrolysis, it is the second most common trigger after medications.

Option B: Viral infection

  • Patients with HIV infection have been reported to have an increased risk of drug reactions and a 100-fold higher risk of SJS/TEN than the general population. However, viruses rarely cause toxic epidermal necrolysis.

Option D: Idiopathic

  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis is rarely idiopathic. In about 90-95% of cases, it is triggered by some secondary factors. Medications intake is the most common triggering factor for toxic epidermal necrolysis.
